Both looked\r\nup with a smile of welcome at the entrance of a tall, fine-looking young\r\nman, whom each greeted with \xe2\x80\x98Good morning, Philip.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good morning, Laura. Good morning, Charles; I am glad you are\r\ndownstairs again! How are you to-day?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No way remarkable, thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer, somewhat wearily given\r\nby Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You walked?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Where\xe2\x80\x99s my uncle? I called at the post-office, and brought a\r\nletter for him. It has the Moorworth post-mark,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, producing it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The post-town to Redclyffe; Sir Guy Morville\xe2\x80\x99s place.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That old Sir Guy! What can he have to do with my father?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you not know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, \xe2\x80\x98that my uncle is to be guardian to the\r\nboy--his grandson?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh? No, I did not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98when old Sir Guy made it an especial point that my\r\nfather should take the guardianship, he only consented on condition\r\nthat my uncle should be joined with him; so now my uncle is alone in\r\nthe trust, and I cannot help thinking something must have happened at\r\nRedclyffe. It is certainly not Sir Guy\xe2\x80\x99s writing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It must wait, unless your curiosity will carry you out in search of\r\npapa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98he is somewhere about, zealously supplying the\r\nplace of Jenkins.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really, Philip,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98there is no telling how much good you\r\nhave done him by convincing him of Jenkins\xe2\x80\x99 dishonesty. To say nothing\r\nof the benefit of being no longer cheated, the pleasure of having to\r\noverlook the farming is untold.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPhilip smiled, and came to the table where she was drawing. \xe2\x80\x98Do you know\r\nthis place?\xe2\x80\x99 said she, looking up in his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stylehurst itself! What is it taken from?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From this pencil sketch of your sister\xe2\x80\x99s, which I found in mamma\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nscrap book.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are making it very like, only the spire is too slender, and that\r\ntree--can\xe2\x80\x99t you alter the foliage?--it is an ash.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it? I took it for an elm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And surely those trees in the foreground should be greener, to throw\r\nback the middle distance. That is the peak of South Moor exactly, if it\r\nlooked further off.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe began the alterations, while Philip stood watching her progress,\r\na shade of melancholy gathering on his face. Suddenly, a voice called\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Laura! Are you there? Open the door, and you will see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn Philip\xe2\x80\x99s opening it, in came a tall camellia; the laughing face,\r\nand light, shining curls of the bearer peeping through the dark green\r\nleaves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you! Oh, is it you, Philip? Oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t take it. I must bring my\r\nown camellia to show Charlie.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You make the most of that one flower,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only see how many buds!\xe2\x80\x99 and she placed it by his sofa. Is it not a\r\nperfect blossom, so pure a white, and so regular! And I am so proud of\r\nhaving beaten mamma and all the gardeners, for not another will be out\r\nthis fortnight; and this is to go to the horticultural show. Sam would\r\nhardly trust me to bring it in, though it was my nursing, not his.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Amy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, when the flower had been duly admired, \xe2\x80\x98you\r\nmust let me put it into the window, for you. It is too heavy for you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, take care,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Amabel, but too late; for, as he took it from\r\nher, the solitary flower struck against Charles\xe2\x80\x99s little table, and was\r\nbroken off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O Amy, I am very sorry. What a pity! How did it happen?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind,\xe2\x80\x99 she answered; \xe2\x80\x98it will last a long time in water.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was very unlucky--I am very sorry--especially because of the\r\nhorticultural show.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Make all your apologies to Sam,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98his feelings will be more\r\nhurt than mine. I dare say my poor flower would have caught cold at the\r\nshow, and never held up its head again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer tone was gay; but Charles, who saw her face in the glass, betrayed\r\nher by saying, \xe2\x80\x98Winking away a tear, O Amy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never nursed a dear gazelle!\xe2\x80\x99 quoted Amy, with a merry laugh; and\r\nbefore any more could be said, there entered a middle-aged gentleman,\r\nshort and slight, with a fresh, weather-beaten, good-natured face, gray\r\nwhiskers, quick eyes, and a hasty, undecided air in look and movement.\r\nHe greeted Philip heartily, and the letter was given to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha! Eh? Let us look. Not old Sir Guy\xe2\x80\x99s hand. Eh? What can be the\r\nmatter? What? Dead! This is a sudden thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dead! Who? Sir Guy Morville?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, quite suddenly--poor old man.\xe2\x80\x99 Then stepping to the door, he\r\nopened it, and called, \xe2\x80\x98Mamma; just step here a minute, will you,\r\nmamma?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe summons was obeyed by a tall, handsome lady, and behind her crept,\r\nwith doubtful steps, as if she knew not how far to venture, a little\r\ngirl of eleven, her turned-up nose and shrewd face full of curiosity.\r\nShe darted up to Amabel; who, though she shook her head, and held up her\r\nfinger, smiled, and took the little girl\xe2\x80\x99s hand, listening meanwhile to\r\nthe announcement, \xe2\x80\x98Do you hear this, mamma? Here\xe2\x80\x99s a shocking thing! Sir\r\nGuy Morville dead, quite suddenly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed! Well, poor man, I suppose no one ever repented or suffered more\r\nthan he. Who writes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His grandson--poor boy! I can hardly make out his letter.\xe2\x80\x99 Holding it\r\nhalf a yard from his eyes, so that all could see a few lines of hasty,\r\nirregular writing, in a forcible hand, bearing marks of having been\r\npenned under great distress and agitation, he read aloud:--\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cDEAR MR. EDMONSTONE,--\r\n\r\nMy dear grandfather died at six this morning. He had an attack of\r\napoplexy yesterday evening, and never spoke again, though for a short\r\ntime he knew me. We hope he suffered little. Markham will make all\r\narrangements. We propose that the funeral should take place on Tuesday;\r\nI hope you will be able to come. I would write to my cousin, Philip\r\nMorville, if I knew his address; but I depend on you for saying all that\r\nought to be said. Excuse this illegible letter,--I hardly know what I\r\nwrite.\r\n\r\n                                 \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cYours, very sincerely,\r\n                                      \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cGuy Morville.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, \xe2\x80\x98he writes with a great deal of proper\r\nfeeling.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How very sad for him to be left alone there!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very sad--very,\xe2\x80\x99 said her husband. \xe2\x80\x98I must start off to him at\r\nonce--yes, at once. Should you not say so--eh, Philip?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly. I think I had better go with you. It would be the correct\r\nthing, and I should not like to fail in any token of respect for poor\r\nold Sir Guy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course--of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98it would be the correct\r\nthing. I am sure he was always very civil to us, and you are next heir\r\nafter this boy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLittle Charlotte made a sort of jump, lifted her eyebrows, and stared at\r\nAmabel.\r\n\r\nPhilip answered. \xe2\x80\x98That is not worth a thought; but since he and I\r\nare now the only representatives of the two branches of the house of\r\nMorville, it shall not be my fault if the enmity is not forgotten.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Buried in oblivion would sound more magnanimous,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; at\r\nwhich Amabel laughed so uncontrollably, that she was forced to hide\r\nher head on her little sister\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder. Charlotte laughed too, an\r\nimprudent proceeding, as it attracted attention. Her father smiled,\r\nsaying, half-reprovingly--\xe2\x80\x98So you are there, inquisitive pussy-cat?\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nat her mother\xe2\x80\x99s question,--\xe2\x80\x98Charlotte, what business have you here?\xe2\x80\x99 She\r\nstole back to her lessons, looking very small, without the satisfaction\r\nof hearing her mother\xe2\x80\x99s compassionate words--\xe2\x80\x98Poor child!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How old is he?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Edmonstone, returning to the former subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is of the same age as Laura--seventeen and a half,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you remember my brother saying what a satisfaction\r\nit was to see such a noble baby as she was, after such a poor little\r\nmiserable thing as the one at Redclyffe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is grown into a fine spirited fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose we must have him here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone. Should you not\r\nsay so--eh, Philip?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly; I should think it very good for him. Indeed, his\r\ngrandfather\xe2\x80\x99s death has happened at a most favourable time for him. The\r\npoor old man had such a dread of his going wrong that he kept him--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know--as tight as a drum.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With strictness that I should think very bad for a boy of his impatient\r\ntemper. It would have been a very dangerous experiment to send him at\r\nonce among the temptations of Oxford, after such discipline and solitude\r\nas he has been used to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk of it,\xe2\x80\x99 interrupted Mr. Edmonstone, spreading out his hands\r\nin a deprecating manner. \xe2\x80\x98We must do the best we can with him, for I\r\nhave got him on my hands till he is five-and-twenty--his grandfather\r\nhas tied him up till then. If we can keep him out of mischief, well and\r\ngood; if not, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have him all to yourself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, to my sorrow. If your poor father was alive, Philip, I should be\r\nfree of all care. I\xe2\x80\x99ve a pretty deal on my hands,\xe2\x80\x99 he proceeded, looking\r\nmore important than troubled. \xe2\x80\x98All that great Redclyffe estate is no\r\nsinecure, to say nothing of the youth himself. If all the world will\r\ncome to me, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. I must go and speak to the men, if I am to\r\nbe off to Redclyffe tomorrow. Will you come, Philip?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must go back soon, thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Philip. \xe2\x80\x98I must see about my\r\nleave; only we should first settle when to set off.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis arranged, Mr. Edmonstone hurried away, and Charles began by saying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Isn\xe2\x80\x99t there a ghost at Redclyffe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So it is said,\xe2\x80\x99 answered his cousin; \xe2\x80\x98though I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it is\r\ncertain whose it is. There is a room called Sir Hugh\xe2\x80\x99s Chamber, over\r\nthe gateway, but the honour of naming it is undecided between Hugo de\r\nMorville, who murdered Thomas a Becket, and his namesake, the first\r\nBaronet, who lived in the time of William of Orange, when the quarrel\r\nbegan with our branch of the family. Do you know the history of it,\r\naunt?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was about some property,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98though I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nthe rights of it. But the Morvilles were always a fiery, violent race,\r\nand the enmity once begun between Sir Hugh and his brother, was kept\r\nup, generation after generation, in a most unjustifiable way. Even I\r\ncan remember when the Morvilles of Redclyffe used to be spoken of in our\r\nfamily like a sort of ogres.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not undeservedly, I should think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98This poor old man, who\r\nis just dead, ran a strange career. Stories of his duels and mad freaks\r\nare still extant.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor man! I believe he went all lengths,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What was the true version of that horrible story about his son?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nPhilip. \xe2\x80\x98Did he strike him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no! it was bad enough without that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was an only child, and lost his mother early. He was very ill\r\nbrought up, and was as impetuous and violent as Sir Guy himself, though\r\nwith much kindliness and generosity. He was only nineteen when he made a\r\nrunaway marriage with a girl of sixteen, the sister of a violin player,\r\nwho was at that time in fashion. His father was very much offended, and\r\nthere was much dreadfully violent conduct on each side. At last, the\r\nyoung man was driven to seek a reconciliation. He brought his wife to\r\nMoorworth, and rode to Redclyffe, to have an interview with his father.\r\nUnhappily, Sir Guy was giving a dinner to the hunt, and had been\r\ndrinking. He not only refused to see him, but I am afraid he used\r\nshocking language, and said something about bidding him go back to\r\nhis fiddling brother in-law. The son was waiting in the hall, heard\r\neverything, threw himself on his horse, and rushed away in the dark. His\r\nforehead struck against the branch of a tree, and he was killed on the\r\nspot.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The poor wife?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amabel, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She died the next day, when this boy was born.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Frightful!\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98It might well make a reformation in old Sir\r\nGuy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have heard that nothing could be more awful than the stillness\r\nthat fell on that wretched party, even before they knew what had\r\nhappened--before Colonel Harewood, who had been called aside by the\r\nservants, could resolve to come and fetch away the father. No wonder Sir\r\nGuy was a changed man from that hour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was then that he sent for my father,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what made him think of doing so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know Colonel Harewood\xe2\x80\x99s house at Stylehurst? Many years ago, when\r\nthe St. Mildred\xe2\x80\x99s races used to be so much more in fashion, Sir Guy and\r\nColonel Harewood, and some men of that stamp, took that house amongst\r\nthem, and used to spend some time there every year, to attend to\r\nsomething about the training of the horses. There were some malpractices\r\nof their servants, that did so much harm in the parish, that my brother\r\nwas obliged to remonstrate. Sir Guy was very angry at first, but behaved\r\nbetter at last than any of the others. I suspect he was struck by\r\nmy dear brother\xe2\x80\x99s bold, uncompromising ways, for he took to him to a\r\ncertain degree--and my brother could not help being interested in him,\r\nthere seemed to be so much goodness in his nature. I saw him once, and\r\nnever did I meet any one who gave me so much the idea of a finished\r\ngentleman. When the poor son was about fourteen, he was with a tutor in\r\nthe neighbourhood, and used to be a good deal at Stylehurst, and, after\r\nthe unhappy marriage, my brother happened to meet him in London, heard\r\nhis story, and tried to bring about a reconciliation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha!\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98did not they come to Stylehurst? I have a dim\r\nrecollection of somebody very tall, and a lady who sung.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; your father asked them to stay there, that he might judge of her,\r\nand wrote to Sir Guy that she was a little, gentle, childish thing,\r\ncapable of being moulded to anything, and representing the mischief of\r\nleaving them to such society as that of her brother, who was actually\r\nmaintaining them. That letter was never answered, but about ten days\r\nor a fortnight after this terrible accident, Colonel Harewood wrote to\r\nentreat my brother to come to Redclyffe, saying poor Sir Guy had eagerly\r\ncaught at the mention of his name. Of course he went at once, and he\r\ntold me that he never, in all his experience as a clergyman, saw any one\r\nso completely broken down with grief.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nI found a great many of his letters among my father\xe2\x80\x99s papers,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nPhilip; \xe2\x80\x98and it was a very touching one that he wrote to me on my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s death. Those Redclyffe people certainly have great force of\r\ncharacter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And was it then he settled his property on my uncle?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98My brother did not like his doing so, but\r\nhe would not be at rest till it was settled. It was in vain to put him\r\nin mind of his grandchild, for he would not believe it could live; and,\r\nindeed, its life hung on a thread. I remember my brother telling me how\r\nhe went to Moorworth to see it--for it could not be brought home--in\r\nhopes of bringing, back a report that might cheer its grandfather, but\r\nhow he found it so weak and delicate, that he did not dare to try to\r\nmake him take interest in it. It was not till the child was two or three\r\nyears old, that Sir Guy ventured to let himself grow fond of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir Guy was a very striking person,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98I shall not easily\r\nforget my visit to Redclyffe four years ago. It was more like a scene in\r\na romance than anything real--the fine old red sandstone house crumbling\r\naway in the exposed parts, the arched gateway covered with ivy; the\r\ngreat quadrangle where the sun never shone, and full of echoes; the\r\nlarge hall and black wainscoted rooms, which the candles never would\r\nlight up. It is a fit place to be haunted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That poor boy alone there!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98I am glad you and\r\nyour uncle are going to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell us about him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was the most incongruous thing there,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98There was a\r\ncalm, deep melancholy about the old man added to the grand courtesy\r\nwhich showed he had been what old books call a fine gentleman, that made\r\nhim suit his house as a hermit does his cell, or a knight his castle;\r\nbut breaking in on this \xe2\x80\x9cpenseroso\xe2\x80\x9d scene, there was Guy--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In what way?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Always in wild spirits, rushing about, playing antics, provoking the\r\nsolemn echoes with shouting, whooping, singing, whistling. There was\r\nsomething in that whistle of his that always made me angry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How did this suit old Sir Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was curious to see how Guy could rattle on to him, pour out the\r\nwhole history of his doings, laughing, rubbing his hands, springing\r\nabout with animation--all with as little answer as if he had been\r\ntalking to a statue.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you mean that Sir Guy did not like it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He did in his own way. There was now and then a glance or a nod, to\r\nshow that he was attending; but it was such slight encouragement, that\r\nany less buoyant spirits must have been checked.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you like him, on the whole?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Laura. \xe2\x80\x98I hope he has not\r\nthis tremendous Morville temper? Oh, you don\xe2\x80\x99t say so. What a grievous\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is a fine fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98but I did not think Sir Guy managed\r\nhim well. Poor old man, he was quite wrapped up in him, and only thought\r\nhow to keep him out of harm\xe2\x80\x99s way. He would never let him be with other\r\nboys, and kept him so fettered by rules, so strictly watched, and so\r\nsternly called to account, that I cannot think how any boy could stand\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yet, you say, he told everything freely to his grandfather,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 added her mother, \xe2\x80\x98I was going to say that, as long as that went\r\non, I should think all safe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I said before,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Philip, \xe2\x80\x98he has a great deal of frankness,\r\nmuch of the making of a fine character; but he is a thorough Morville. I\r\nremember something that will show you his best and worst sides. You know\r\nRedclyffe is a beautiful place, with magnificent cliffs overhanging the\r\nsea, and fine woods crowning them. On one of the most inaccessible\r\nof these crags there was a hawk\xe2\x80\x99s nest, about half-way down, so that\r\nlooking from the top of the precipice, we could see the old birds fly\r\nin and out. Well, what does Master Guy do, but go down this headlong\r\ndescent after the nest. How he escaped alive no one could guess; and his\r\ngrandfather could not bear to look at the place afterwards--but climb\r\nit he did, and came back with two young hawks, buttoned up inside his\r\njacket.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a regular brick for you!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charles, delighted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His heart was set on training these birds. He turned the library upside\r\ndown in search of books on falconry, and spent every spare moment on\r\nthem. At last, a servant left some door open, and they escaped. I shall\r\nnever forget Guy\xe2\x80\x99s passion; I am sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t exaggerate when I say he\r\nwas perfectly beside himself with anger.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor boy!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Served the rascal right,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing had any effect on him till his grandfather came out, and, at\r\nthe sight of him, he was tamed in an instant, hung his head, came up to\r\nhis grandfather, and said--\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d Sir Guy answered, \xe2\x80\x9cMy poor\r\nboy!\xe2\x80\x9d and there was not another word. I saw Guy no more that day, and\r\nall the next he was quiet and subdued. But the most remarkable part of\r\nthe story is to come. A couple of days afterwards we were walking in\r\nthe woods, when, at the sound of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s whistle, we heard a flapping and\r\nrustling, and beheld, tumbling along, with their clipped wings, these\r\ntwo identical hawks, very glad to be caught. They drew themselves up\r\nproudly for him to stroke them, and their yellow eyes looked at him with\r\npositive affection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty creatures!\xe2\x80\x99 said Amabel. \xe2\x80\x98That is a very nice end to the story.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is not the end,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98I was surprised to see Guy so sober,\r\ninstead of going into one of his usual raptures. He took them home; but\r\nthe first thing I heard in the morning was, that he was gone to offer\r\nthem to a farmer, to keep the birds from his fruit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did he do it of his own accord?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That was just what I wanted to know; but any hint about them brought\r\nsuch a cloud over his face that I thought it would be wanton to irritate\r\nhim by questions. However, I must be going. Good-bye, Amy, I hope your\r\nCamellia will have another blossom before I come back. At least, I shall\r\nescape the horticultural meeting.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98Put the feud in your pocket till you can\r\nbury it in old Sir Guy\xe2\x80\x99s grave, unless you mean to fight it out with his\r\ngrandson, which would be more romantic and exciting.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPhilip was gone before he could finish. Mrs. Edmonstone looked annoyed,\r\nand Laura said, \xe2\x80\x98Charlie, I wish you would not let your spirits carry\r\nyou away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish I had anything else to carry me away!\xe2\x80\x99 was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said his mother, looking sadly at him. \xe2\x80\x98Your high spirits are a\r\nblessing; but why misuse them? If they are given to support you through\r\npain and confinement, why make mischief with them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles looked more impatient than abashed, and the compunction seemed\r\nchiefly to rest with Amabel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98I must go and see after my poor little\r\nprisoner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, as she went; \xe2\x80\x98it was no kindness in you to encourage\r\nCharlotte to stay, Amy, when you know how often that inquisitive temper\r\nhas got her into scrapes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, regretfully; \xe2\x80\x98but I had not the heart to send\r\nher away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is just what Philip says, that you only want bones and sinews in\r\nyour character to--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, Laura,\xe2\x80\x99 interrupted Charles, \xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t hear Philip\xe2\x80\x99s criticisms\r\nof my sister, I had rather she had no bones at all, than that they stuck\r\nout and ran into me. There are plenty of angles already in the world,\r\nwithout sharpening hers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe possessed himself of Amy\xe2\x80\x99s round, plump, childish hand, and spread\r\nout over it his still whiter, and very bony fingers, pinching her \xe2\x80\x98soft\r\npinky cushions,\xe2\x80\x99 as he called them, \xe2\x80\x98not meant for studying anatomy\r\nupon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! you two spoil each other sadly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, smiling, as she left\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what do Philip and Laura do to each other?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Improve each other, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amabel, in a shy, simple tone, at\r\nwhich Charles laughed heartily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish I was as sensible as Laura!\xe2\x80\x99 said she, presently, with a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never was a more absurd wish,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, tormenting her hand still\r\nmore, and pulling her curls; \xe2\x80\x98unwish it forthwith. Where should I be\r\nwithout silly little Amy? If every one weighed my wit before laughing, I\r\nshould not often be in disgrace for my high spirits, as they call them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am so little younger than Laura,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, still sadly, though\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Folly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98you are quite wise enough for your age, while\r\nLaura is so prematurely wise, that I am in constant dread that nature\r\nwill take her revenge by causing her to do something strikingly\r\nfoolish!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Amy, indignantly. \xe2\x80\x98Laura do anything foolish!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What I should enjoy,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Charles, \xe2\x80\x98would be to see her over head\r\nand ears in love with this hero, and Philip properly jealous.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you say such things, Charlie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why? was there ever a beauty who did not fall in love with her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nward?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; but she ought to live alone with her very old father and horribly\r\ngrim maiden aunt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, Amy, you shall be the maiden, aunt.\xe2\x80\x99 And as Laura returned\r\nat that moment, he announced to her that they had been agreeing that no\r\nhero ever failed to fall in love with his guardian\xe2\x80\x99s beautiful daughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If his guardian had a beautiful daughter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, resolved not to\r\nbe disconcerted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you ever hear such barefaced fishing for compliments?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nCharles; but Amabel, who did not like her sister to be teased, and\r\nwas also conscious of having wasted a good deal of time, sat down to\r\npractise. Laura returned to her drawing, and Charles, with a yawn,\r\nlistlessly turned over a newspaper, while his fair delicate features,\r\nwhich would have been handsome but that they were blanched, sharpened,\r\nand worn with pain, gradually lost their animated and rather satirical\r\nexpression, and assumed an air of weariness and discontent.\r\n\r\nCharles was at this time nineteen, and for the last ten years had been\r\nafflicted with a disease in the hip-joint, which, in spite of the\r\nmost anxious care, caused him frequent and severe suffering, and had\r\noccasioned such a contraction of the limb as to cripple him completely,\r\nwhile his general health was so much affected as to render him an object\r\nof constant anxiety. His mother had always been his most devoted and\r\nindefatigable nurse, giving up everything for his sake, and watching him\r\nnight and day. His father attended to his least caprice, and his sisters\r\nwere, of course, his slaves; so that he was the undisputed sovereign of\r\nthe whole family.\r\n\r\nThe two elder girls had been entirely under a governess till a month\r\nor two before the opening of our story, when Laura was old enough to\r\nbe introduced; and the governess departing, the two sisters became\r\nCharles\xe2\x80\x99s companions in the drawing-room, while Mrs. Edmonstone, who had\r\na peculiar taste and talent for teaching, undertook little Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlessons herself.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 2\r\n\r\n     If the ill spirit have so fair a house,\r\n     Good things will strive to dwell with\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\n                                --THE TEMPEST\r\n\r\n\r\nOne of the pleasantest rooms at Hollywell was Mrs. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndressing-room--large and bay-windowed, over the drawing-room, having\r\nlittle of the dressing-room but the name, and a toilet-table with a\r\nblack and gold japanned glass, and curiously shaped boxes to match; her\r\nroom opened into it on one side, and Charles\xe2\x80\x99s on the other; it was a\r\nsort of up-stairs parlour, where she taught Charlotte, cast up accounts,\r\nspoke to servants, and wrote notes, and where Charles was usually to\r\nbe found, when unequal to coming down-stairs. It had an air of great\r\nsnugness, with its large folding-screen, covered with prints and\r\ncaricatures of ancient date, its book-shelves, its tables, its\r\npeculiarly easy arm-chairs, the great invalid sofa, and the grate, which\r\nalways lighted up better than any other in the house.\r\n\r\nIn the bright glow of the fire, with the shutters closed and curtains\r\ndrawn, lay Charles on his couch, one Monday evening, in a gorgeous\r\ndressing-gown of a Chinese pattern, all over pagodas, while little\r\nCharlotte sat opposite to him, curled up on a footstool. He was not\r\nalways very civil to Charlotte; she sometimes came into collision with\r\nhim, for she, too, was a pet, and had a will of her own, and at other\r\ntimes she could bore him; but just now they had a common interest, and\r\nhe was gracious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is striking six, so they must soon be here. I wish mamma would let\r\nme go down; but I must wait till after dinner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then, Charlotte, as soon as you come in, hold up your hands, and\r\nexclaim, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a guy!\xe2\x80\x9d There will be a compliment!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Charlie; I promised mamma and Laura that you should get me into no\r\nmore scrapes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you? The next promise you make had better depend upon yourself\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But Amy said I must be quiet, because poor Sir Guy will be too\r\nsorrowful to like a racket; and when Amy tells me to be quiet, I know\r\nthat I must, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Most true,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think you shall like Sir Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall be able to determine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, sententiously, \xe2\x80\x98when I\r\nhave seen whether he brushes his hair to the right or left.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip brushes his to the left.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then undoubtedly Sir Guy will brush his to the right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is there not some horrid story about those Morvilles of Redclyffe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nasked Charlotte. \xe2\x80\x98I asked Laura, and she told me not to be curious, so\r\nI knew there was something in it; and then I asked Amy, and she said it\r\nwould be no pleasure to me to know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! I would have you prepared.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, what is it? Oh! dear Charlie! are you really going to tell me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you ever hear of a deadly feud?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have read of them in the history of Scotland. They went on hating\r\nand killing each other for ever. There was one man who made his enemy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchildren eat out of a pig-trough, and another who cut off his head.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His own?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, his enemy\xe2\x80\x99s, and put it on the table, at breakfast, with a piece of\r\nbread in its mouth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well; whenever Sir Guy serves up Philip\xe2\x80\x99s head at breakfast, with\r\na piece of bread in his mouth, let me know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharlotte started up. \xe2\x80\x98Charles, what do you mean? Such things don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhappen now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nevertheless, there is a deadly feud between the two branches of the\r\nhouse of Morville.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it is very wrong,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, looking frightened.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wrong? Of course it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip won\xe2\x80\x99t do anything wrong. But how will they ever get on?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see? It must be our serious endeavour to keep the peace, and\r\nprevent occasions of discord.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think anything will happen?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is much to be apprehended,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, solemnly.\r\n\r\nAt that moment the sound of wheels was heard, and Charlotte flew off to\r\nher private post of observation, leaving her brother delighted at having\r\nmystified her. She returned on tip-toe. \xe2\x80\x98Papa and Sir Guy are come, but\r\nnot Philip; I can\xe2\x80\x99t see him anywhere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah you have not looked in Sir Guy\xe2\x80\x99s great-coat pocket.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish you would not plague me so! You are not in earnest?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe pettish inquiring tone was exactly what delighted him. And he\r\ncontinued to tease her in the same style till Laura and Amabel came\r\nrunning in with their report of the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is come!\xe2\x80\x99 they cried, with one voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very gentlemanlike!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very pleasant looking,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98Such fine eyes!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so much expression,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe exclamation, and the start which accompanied it, were caused by\r\nhearing her father\xe2\x80\x99s voice close to the door, which had been left partly\r\nopen. \xe2\x80\x98Here is poor Charles,\xe2\x80\x99 it said, \xe2\x80\x98come in, and see him; get over\r\nthe first introduction--eh, Guy?\xe2\x80\x99 And before he had finished, both he\r\nand the guest were in the room, and Charlotte full of mischievous glee\r\nat her sister\xe2\x80\x99s confusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Charlie, boy, how goes it?\xe2\x80\x99 was his father\xe2\x80\x99s greeting. \xe2\x80\x98Better,\r\neh? Sorry not to find you down-stairs; but I have brought Guy to\r\nsee you.\xe2\x80\x99 Then, as Charles sat up and shook hands with Sir Guy, he\r\ncontinued--\xe2\x80\x98A fine chance for you, as I was telling him, to have a\r\ncompanion always at hand: a fine chance? eh, Charlie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not so unreasonable as to expect any one to be always at hand,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Charles, smiling, as he looked up at the frank, open face, and\r\nlustrous hazel eyes turned on him with compassion at the sight of\r\nhis crippled, helpless figure, and with a bright, cordial promise of\r\nkindness.\r\n\r\nAs he spoke, a pattering sound approached, the door was pushed open,\r\nand while Sir Guy exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98O, Bustle! Bustle! I am very sorry,\xe2\x80\x99 there\r\nsuddenly appeared a large beautiful spaniel, with a long silky black and\r\nwhite coat, jetty curled ears, tan spots above his intelligent eyes, and\r\ntan legs, fringed with silken waves of hair, but crouching and looking\r\nbeseeching at meeting no welcome, while Sir Guy seemed much distressed\r\nat his intrusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O you beauty!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charles. \xe2\x80\x98Come here, you fine fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBustle only looked wistfully at his master, and moved nothing but his\r\nfeather of a tail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! I was afraid you would repent of your kindness,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sir Guy to\r\nMr. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all, not at all!\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer; \xe2\x80\x98mamma never objects to\r\nin-door pets, eh, Amy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A tender subject, papa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98poor Pepper!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy, ashamed of her disposition to cry at the remembrance of the dear\r\ndeparted rough terrier, bent down to hide her glowing face, and held out\r\nher hand to the dog, which at last ventured to advance, still creeping\r\nwith his body curved till his tail was foremost, looking imploringly at\r\nhis master, as if to entreat his pardon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you sure you don\xe2\x80\x99t dislike it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Sir Guy, of Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I? O no. Here, you fine creature.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, then, behave like a rational dog, since you are come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sir\r\nGuy; and Bustle, resuming the deportment of a spirited and well-bred\r\nspaniel, no longer crouched and curled himself into the shape of a\r\ncomma, but bounded, wagged his tail, thrust his nose into his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand and then proceeded to reconnoitre the rest of the company, paying\r\nespecial attention to Charles, putting his fore-paws on the sofa, and\r\nrearing himself up to contemplate him with a grave, polite curiosity,\r\nthat was very diverting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, old fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98did you ever see the like of such a\r\ndressing-gown? Are you satisfied? Give me your paw, and let us swear an\r\neternal friendship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am quite glad to see a dog in the house again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, and,\r\nafter a few more compliments, Bustle and his master followed Mr.\r\nEdmonstone out of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of my father\xe2\x80\x99s well-judged proceedings,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Charles. \xe2\x80\x98That\r\npoor fellow had rather have gone a dozen, miles further than have been\r\nlugged in here. Really, if papa chooses to inflict such dressing-gowns\r\non me, he should give me notice before he brings men and dogs to make me\r\ntheir laughing-stock!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An unlucky moment,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98Will my cheeks ever cool?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps he did not hear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amabel, consolingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You did not ask about Philip?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, with great earnestness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is staying at Thorndale, and then going to St. Mildred\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nLaura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you are relieved,\xe2\x80\x99 said her brother; and she looked in doubt\r\nwhether she ought to laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what do you think of Sir Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98May he only be worthy of his dog!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98many men are neither worthy of their wives, nor of\r\ntheir dogs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dr. Henley, I suppose, is the foundation of that aphorism,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nCharles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If Margaret Morville could marry him, she could hardly be too worthy,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Laura. \xe2\x80\x98Think of throwing away Philip\xe2\x80\x99s whole soul!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O Laura, she could not lose that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amabel.\r\n\r\nLaura looked as if she knew more; but at that moment, both her father\r\nand mother entered, the former rubbing his hands, as he always did when\r\nmuch pleased, and sending his voice before him, as he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98Well,\r\nCharlie, well, young ladies, is not he a fine fellow--eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rather under-sized,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh? He\xe2\x80\x99ll grow. He is not eighteen, you know; plenty of time; a very\r\ngood height; you can\xe2\x80\x99t expect every one to be as tall as Philip; but\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s a capital fellow. And how have you been?--any pain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hem--rather,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, shortly, for he hated answering kind\r\ninquiries, when out of humour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, that\xe2\x80\x99s a pity; I was sorry not to find you in the drawing-room, but\r\nI thought you would have liked just to see him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone,\r\ndisappointed, and apologizing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had rather have had some notice of your intention,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nwould have made myself fit to be seen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry. I thought you would have liked his coming,\xe2\x80\x99 said poor Mr.\r\nEdmonstone, only half conscious of his offence; \xe2\x80\x98but I see you are not\r\nwell this evening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWorse and worse, for it was equivalent to openly telling Charles he was\r\nout of humour; and seeing, as he did, his mother\xe2\x80\x99s motive, he was still\r\nfurther annoyed when she hastily interposed a question about Sir Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You should only hear them talk about him at Redclyffe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nEdmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98No one was ever equal to him, according to them. Every one\r\nsaid the same--clergyman, old Markham, all of them. Such attention to\r\nhis grandfather, such proper feeling, so good-natured, not a bit of\r\npride--it is my firm belief that he will make up for all his family\r\nbefore him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles set up his eyebrows sarcastically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How does he get on with Philip?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Excellently. Just what could be wished. Philip is delighted with him;\r\nand I have been telling Guy all the way home what a capital friend he\r\nwill be, and he is quite inclined to look up to him.\xe2\x80\x99 Charles made an\r\nexaggerated gesture of astonishment, unseen by his father. \xe2\x80\x98I told him\r\nto bring his dog. He would have left it, but they seemed so fond of each\r\nother, I thought it was a pity to part them, and that I could promise it\r\nshould be welcome here; eh, mamma?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly. I am very glad you brought it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are to have his horse and man in a little while. A beautiful\r\nchestnut--anything to raise his spirits. He is terribly cut up about his\r\ngrandfather.\r\n\r\nIt was now time to go down to dinner; and after Charles had made faces\r\nof weariness and disgust at all the viands proposed to him by his\r\nmother, almost imploring him to like them, and had at last ungraciously\r\ngiven her leave to send what he could not quite say he disliked, he was\r\nleft to carry on his teasing of Charlotte, and his grumbling over the\r\ndinner, for about the space of an hour, when Amabel came back to him,\r\nand Charlotte went down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hum!\xe2\x80\x99 he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x98Another swan of my father\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did not you like his looks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I saw only an angular hobbetyhoy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But every one at Redclyffe speaks so well of him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As if the same things were not said of every heir to more acres than\r\nbrains! However, I could have swallowed everything but the disposition\r\nto adore Philip. Either it was gammon on his part, or else the work of\r\nmy father\xe2\x80\x99s imagination.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For shame, Charlie.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it within the bounds of probability that he should be willing, at\r\nthe bidding of his guardian, to adopt as Mentor his very correct and\r\nsententious cousin, a poor subaltern, and the next in the entail? Depend\r\nupon it, it is a fiction created either by papa\xe2\x80\x99s hopes or Philip\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nself-complacency, or else the unfortunate youth must have been brought\r\nvery low by strait-lacing and milk-and-water.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Thorndale is willing to look up to Philip,\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think the Thorndale swan very--very much better than a tame\r\ngoose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98but the coalition is not so monstrous in his\r\ncase, since Philip was a friend of his own picking and choosing, and\r\nso his father\xe2\x80\x99s adoption did not succeed in repelling him. But that\r\nMorville should receive this \xe2\x80\x9cyoung man\xe2\x80\x99s companion,\xe2\x80\x9d on the word of a\r\nguardian whom he never set eyes on before, is too incredible--utterly\r\nmythical I assure you, Amy. And how did you get on at dinner?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, the dog is the most delightful creature I ever saw, so sensible and\r\nwell-mannered.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was of the man that I asked.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He said hardly anything, and sometimes started if papa spoke to him\r\nsuddenly. He winced as if he could not bear to be called Sir Guy, so\r\npapa said we should call him only by his name, if he would do the same\r\nby us. I am glad of it, for it seems more friendly, and I am sure he\r\nwants to be comforted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t waste your compassion, my dear; few men need it less. With his\r\nproperty, those moors to shoot over, his own master, and with health to\r\nenjoy it, there are plenty who would change with him for all your pity,\r\nmy silly little Amy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely not, with that horrible ancestry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All very well to plume oneself upon. I rather covet that ghost myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, if you watched his face, I think you would be sorry for him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am tired of the sound of his name. One fifth of November is enough in\r\nthe year. Here, find something to read to me among that trumpery.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy read till she was summoned to tea, when she found a conversation\r\ngoing on about Philip, on whose history Sir Guy did not seem fully\r\ninformed. Philip was the son of Archdeacon Morville, Mrs. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrother, an admirable and superior man, who had been dead about five\r\nyears. He left three children, Margaret and Fanny, twenty-five and\r\ntwenty-three years of age, and Philip, just seventeen. The boy was at\r\nthe head of his school, highly distinguished for application and good\r\nconduct; he had attained every honour there open to him, won golden\r\nopinions from all concerned with him, and made proof of talents\r\nwhich could not have failed to raise him to the highest university\r\ndistinctions. He was absent from home at the time of his father\xe2\x80\x99s death,\r\nwhich took place after so short an illness, that there had been no time\r\nto summon him back to Stylehurst. Very little property was left to be\r\ndivided among the three; and as soon as Philip perceived how small\r\nwas the provision for his sisters, he gave up his hopes of university\r\nhonours, and obtained a commission in the army.\r\n\r\nOn hearing this, Sir Guy started forward: \xe2\x80\x98Noble!\xe2\x80\x99 he cried, \xe2\x80\x98and yet\r\nwhat a pity! If my grandfather had but known it--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! I was convinced of _that_,\xe2\x80\x99 broke in Mr. Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98and so, I am\r\nsure, was Philip himself; but in fact he knew we should never have given\r\nour consent, so he acted quite by himself, wrote to Lord Thorndale, and\r\nnever said a word, even to his sisters, till the thing was done. I never\r\nwas more surprised in my life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One would almost envy him the opportunity of making such a sacrifice,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Sir Guy, yet one must lament it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was done in a hasty spirit of independence,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe if he had got a fellowship at Oxford, it would have answered\r\nmuch better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now that poor Fanny is dead, and Margaret married, there is all\r\nhis expensive education thrown away, and all for nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nEdmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98he planned for them to go on living at\r\nStylehurst, so that it would still have been his home. It is a\r\ngreat pity, for his talent is thrown away, and he is not fond of his\r\nprofession.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must not suppose, though, that he is not a practical man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nEdmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98I had rather take his opinion than any one\xe2\x80\x99s, especially\r\nabout a horse, and there is no end to what I hear about his good sense,\r\nand the use he is of to the other young men.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You should tell about Mr. Thorndale, papa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah that is a feather in master Philip\xe2\x80\x99s cap; besides, he is your\r\nneighbour--at least, his father is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you know Lord Thorndale?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, in\r\nexplanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have seen him once at the Quarter Sessions,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sir Guy; \xe2\x80\x98but he\r\nlives on the other side of Moorworth, and there was no visiting.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, this youth, James Thorndale, the second son, was Philip\xe2\x80\x99s fag.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip says he was always licking him!\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Charlotte.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He kept him out of some scrape or other, continued Mr. Edmonstone.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lord Thorndale was very much obliged to him, had him to stay at his\r\nhouse, took pretty much to him altogether. It was through him that\r\nPhilip applied for his commission, and he has put his son into the same\r\nregiment, on purpose to have him under Philip\xe2\x80\x99s eye. There he is at\r\nBroadstone, as gentlemanlike a youth as I would wish to see. We will\r\nhave him to dinner some day, and Maurice too--eh, mamma? Maurice--he is\r\na young Irish cousin of my own, a capital fellow at the bottom, but a\r\nregular thoroughgoing rattle. That was my doing. I told his father that\r\nhe could not do better than put him into the --th. Nothing like a steady\r\nfriend and a good example, I said, and Kilcoran always takes my advice,\r\nand I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he has been sorry. Maurice has kept much more out of\r\nscrapes of late.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O papa,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Charlotte, \xe2\x80\x98Maurice has been out riding on a hired\r\nhorse, racing with Mr. Gordon, and the horse tumbled down at the bottom\r\nof East-hill, and broke its knees.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the way,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98the instant my back is turned.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThereupon the family fell into a discussion of home affairs, and thought\r\nlittle more of their silent guest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 3\r\n\r\n     The hues of bliss more brightly glow\r\n     Chastised by sober tints of woe.\r\n                                 --GRAY\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What use shall I make of him?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles to himself, as he studied\r\nSir Guy Morville, who sat by the table, with a book in his hand.\r\n\r\nHe had the unformed look of a growing boy, and was so slender as to\r\nappear taller than he really was. He had an air of great activity; and\r\nthough he sat leaning back, there was no lounging in his attitude, and\r\nat the first summons he roused up with an air of alert attention that\r\nrecalled to mind the eager head of a listening greyhound. He had no\r\npretension to be called handsome; his eyes were his best feature; they\r\nwere very peculiar, of a light hazel, darker towards the outside of\r\nthe iris, very brilliant, the whites tinted with blue, and the lashes\r\nuncommonly thick and black; the eyebrows were also very dark, and of\r\na sharply-defined angular shape, but the hair was much lighter, loose,\r\nsoft, and wavy; the natural fairness of the complexion was shown by\r\nthe whiteness of the upper part of the forehead, though the rest of\r\nthe face, as well as the small taper hands, were tanned by sunshine and\r\nsea-breezes, into a fresh, hardy brown, glowing with red on the cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What use shall I make of him?\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Charles\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts. \xe2\x80\x98He\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t be worth his salt if he goes on in this way; he has got a graver\r\nspecimen of literature there than I ever saw Philip himself read on\r\na week-day; he has been puritanized till he is good for nothing; I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntrouble myself no more about him!\xe2\x80\x99 He tried to read, but presently\r\nlooked up again. \xe2\x80\x98Plague! I can\xe2\x80\x99t keep my thoughts off him. That sober\r\nlook does not sit on that sun-burnt face as if it were native to it;\r\nthose eyes don\xe2\x80\x99t look as if the Redclyffe spirit was extinguished.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone came in, and looking round, as if to find some\r\noccupation for her guest, at length devised setting him to play at chess\r\nwith Charles. Charles gave her an amiable look, expressing that neither\r\nliked it; but she was pretty well used to doing him good against his\r\nwill, and trusted to its coming right in time. Charles was a capital\r\nchess-player, and seldom found any one who could play well enough to\r\nafford him much real sport, but he found Sir Guy more nearly a match\r\nthan often fell to his lot; it was a bold dashing game, that obliged\r\nhim to be on his guard, and he was once so taken by surprise as to be\r\nabsolutely check-mated. His ill-humour evaporated, he was delighted to\r\nfind an opponent worth playing with, and henceforth there were games\r\nalmost every morning or evening, though Sir Guy seemed not to care much\r\nabout them, except for the sake of pleasing him.\r\n\r\nWhen left to himself, Guy spent his time in reading or in walking about\r\nthe lanes alone. He used to sit in the bay-window of the drawing-room\r\nwith his book; but sometimes, when they least expected it, the\r\ngirls would find his quick eyes following them with an air of amused\r\ncuriosity, as Amabel waited on Charles and her flowers, or Laura\r\ndrew, wrote letters, and strove to keep down the piles of books and\r\nperiodicals under which it seemed as if her brother might some day be\r\nstifled--a vain task, for he was sure to want immediately whatever she\r\nput out of his reach.\r\n\r\nLaura and Amabel both played and sung, the former remarkably well, and\r\nthe first time they had any music after the arrival of Sir Guy, his look\r\nof delighted attention struck everyone. He ventured nearer, stood by the\r\npiano when they practised, and at last joined in with a few notes of\r\nso full and melodious a voice, that Laura turned round in surprise,\r\nexclaiming, \xe2\x80\x98You sing better I than any of us!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe coloured. \xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98I could not help it; I know\r\nnothing of music.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, smiling incredulously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t even know the notes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you must have a very good ear. Let us try again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe sisters were again charmed and surprised, and Guy looked gratified,\r\nas people do at the discovery of a faculty which they are particularly\r\nglad to possess. It was the first time he appeared to brighten, and\r\nLaura and her mother agreed that it would do him good to have plenty of\r\nmusic, and to try to train that fine voice. He was beginning to interest\r\nthem all greatly by his great helpfulness and kindness to Charles, as\r\nhe learnt the sort of assistance he required, as well as by the\r\nsilent grief that showed how much attached he must have been to his\r\ngrandfather.\r\n\r\nOn the first Sunday, Mrs. Edmonstone coming into the drawing-room at\r\nabout half-past five, found him sitting alone by the fire, his dog lying\r\nat his feet. As he started up, she asked if he had been here in the dark\r\never since church-time?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have not wanted light,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered with a sigh, long, deep, and\r\nirrepressible, and as she stirred the fire, the flame revealed to her\r\nthe traces of tears. She longed to comfort him, and said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This Sunday twilight is a quiet time for thinking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 he said; \xe2\x80\x98how few Sundays ago--\xe2\x80\x99 and there he paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! you had so little preparation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98None. That very morning he had done business with Markham, and had\r\nnever been more clear and collected.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Were you with him when he was taken ill?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs. Edmonstone,\r\nperceiving that it would be a relief to him to talk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; it was just before dinner. I had been shooting, and went into the\r\nlibrary to tell him where I had been. He was well then, for he spoke,\r\nbut it was getting dark, and I did not see his face. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\r\nwas ten minutes dressing, but when I came down, he had sunk back in his\r\nchair. I saw it was not sleep--I rang--and when Arnaud came, we knew how\r\nit was.\xe2\x80\x99 His, voice became low with strong emotion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did he recover his consciousness?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, that was _the_ comfort,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, eagerly. \xe2\x80\x98It was after he had\r\nbeen bled that he seemed to wake up. He could not speak or move, but he\r\nlooked at me--or--I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I should have done.\xe2\x80\x99 The last words\r\nwere almost inaudible from the gush of tears that he vainly struggled\r\nto repress, and he was turning away to hide them, when he saw that Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s were flowing fast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had great reason to be attached to him!\xe2\x80\x99 said she, as soon as she\r\ncould speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed, indeed I had.\xe2\x80\x99 And after a long silence--\xe2\x80\x98He was everything to\r\nme, everything from the first hour I can recollect. He never let me\r\nmiss my parents. How he attended to all my pleasures and wishes, how he\r\nwatched and cared for me, and bore with me, even I can never know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe spoke in short half sentences of intense feeling, and Mrs. Edmonstone\r\nwas much moved by such affection in one said to have been treated with\r\nan excess of strictness, much compassionating the lonely boy, who had\r\nlost every family tie in one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When the first pain of the sudden parting has passed,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, \xe2\x80\x98you\r\nwill like to remember the affection which you knew how to value.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I had but known!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98but there was I, hasty, reckless,\r\ndisregarding his comfort, rebelling against--O, what would I not give to\r\nhave those restraints restored!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is what we all feel in such losses,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98There is\r\nalways much to wish otherwise; but I am sure you can have the happiness\r\nof knowing you were his great comfort.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was what I ought to have been.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe knew that nothing could have been more filial and affectionate than\r\nhis conduct, and tried to say something of the kind, but he would not\r\nlisten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is worst of all,\xe2\x80\x99 he said; \xe2\x80\x98and you must not trust what they say\r\nof me. They would be sure to praise me, if I was anything short of a\r\nbrute.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA silence ensued, while Mrs. Edmonstone was trying to think of some\r\nconsolation. Suddenly Guy looked up, and spoke eagerly:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want to ask something--a great favour--but you make me venture. You\r\nsee how I am left alone--you know how little I can trust myself. Will\r\nyou take me in hand--let me talk to you--and tell me if I am wrong, as\r\nfreely as if I were Charles? I know it is asking a great deal, but you\r\nknew my grandfather, and it is in his name.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe held out her hand; and with tears answered--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed I will, if I see any occasion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will let me trust to you to tell me when I get too vehement? above\r\nall, when you see my temper failing? Thank you; you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what a\r\nrelief it is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you must not call yourself alone. You are one of us now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; since you have made that promise,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; and for the first\r\ntime she saw the full beauty of his smile--a sort of sweetness and\r\nradiance of which eye and brow partook almost as much as the lips. It\r\nalone would have gained her heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must look on you as a kind of nephew,\xe2\x80\x99 she added, kindly. \xe2\x80\x98I used to\r\nhear so much of you from my brother.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy, lighting up, \xe2\x80\x98Archdeacon Morville was always so kind to\r\nme. I remember him very well!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! I wish--\xe2\x80\x99 there she paused, and added,--t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate \xe2\x80\x98it is not\r\nright to wish such things--and Philip is very like his father.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very glad his regiment is so near. I want to know him better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You knew him at Redclyffe, when he was staying there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, his colour rising; \xe2\x80\x98but I was a boy then, and a\r\nvery foolish, headstrong one. I am glad to meet him again. What a\r\ngrand-looking person he is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are very proud of him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, smiling. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink there has been an hour\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety about him since he was born.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe conversation was interrupted by the sound of Charles\xe2\x80\x99s crutches\r\nslowly crossing the hall. Guy sprang to help him to his sofa, and then,\r\nwithout speaking, hurried up-stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mamma, tete-a-tete with the silent one!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will not tell you all I think of him,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, leaving the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hum!\xe2\x80\x99 soliloquised Charles. \xe2\x80\x98That means that my lady mother has adopted\r\nhim, and thinks I should laugh at her, or straightway set up a dislike\r\nto him, knowing my contempt for heroes and hero-worship. It\xe2\x80\x99s a treat\r\nto have Philip out of the way, and if it was but possible to get out of\r\nhearing of his perfection, I should have some peace. If I thought this\r\nfellow had one spice of the kind, I\xe2\x80\x99d never trouble my head about him\r\nmore; and yet I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe he has such a pair of hawk\xe2\x80\x99s eyes for\r\nnothing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe hawk\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, as Charles called them, shone brighter from that\r\nday forth, and their owner began to show more interest in what passed\r\naround. Laura was much amused by a little conversation she held with\r\nhim one day when a party of their younger neighbours were laughing and\r\ntalking nonsense round Charles\xe2\x80\x99s sofa. He was sitting a little way off\r\nin silence, and she took advantage of the loud laughing to say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think this is not very satisfactory?\xe2\x80\x99 And as he gave a quick glance\r\nof inquiry--\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t mind saying so. Philip and I often agree that it is a\r\npity spend so much time in laughing at nothing--at such nonsense.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is nonsense?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Listen--no don\xe2\x80\x99t, it is too silly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense must be an excellent thing if it makes people so happy,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nGuy thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x98Look at them; they are like--not a picture--that has\r\nno life--but a dream--or, perhaps a scene in a play.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you never see anything like it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, no! All the morning calls I ever saw were formal, every one stiff,\r\nand speaking by rote, or talking politics. How glad I used to be to get\r\non horseback again! But to see these--why, it is like the shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nglimpse at the pixies!--as one reads a new book, or watches what one\r\nonly half understands--a rook\xe2\x80\x99s parliament, or a gathering of sea-fowl\r\non the Shag Rock.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A rook\xe2\x80\x99s parliament?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The people at home call it a rook\xe2\x80\x99s parliament when a whole cloud of\r\nrooks settle on some bare, wide common, and sit there as if they were\r\nconsulting, not feeding, only stalking about, with drooping wings, and\r\nsolemn, black cloaks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have found a flattering simile,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98as you know that\r\nrooks never open their mouths without cause.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy had never heard the riddle, but he caught the pun instantly, and the\r\nclear merry sound of his hearty laugh surprised Charles, who instantly\r\nnoted it as another proof that was some life in him.\r\n\r\nIndeed, each day began to make it evident that he had, on the whole,\r\nrather a superabundance of animation than otherwise. He was quite\r\nconfidential with Mrs. Edmonstone, on whom he used to lavish, with\r\nboyish eagerness, all that interested him, carrying her the passages\r\nin books that pleased him, telling her about Redclyffe\xe2\x80\x99s affairs, and\r\ngiving her his letters from Markham, the steward. His head was full\r\nof his horse, Deloraine, which was coming to him under the charge of a\r\ngroom, and the consultations were endless about the means of transport,\r\nMr. Edmonstone almost as eager about it as he was himself.\r\n\r\nHe did not so quickly become at home with the younger portion of the\r\nfamily, but his spirits rose every day. He whistled as he walked in the\r\ngarden, and Bustle, instead of pacing soberly behind him, now capered,\r\nnibbled his pockets, and drew him into games of play which Charles and\r\nAmabel were charmed to overlook from the dressing-room window. There was\r\nGuy leaping, bounding, racing, rolling the dog over, tripping him up,\r\ntwitching his ears, tickling his feet, catching at his tail, laughing at\r\nBustle\xe2\x80\x99s springs, contortions, and harmless open-mouthed attacks, while\r\nthe dog did little less than laugh too, with his intelligent amber eyes,\r\nand black and red mouth. Charles began to find a new interest in his\r\nlistless life in the attempt to draw Guy out, and make him give one of\r\nhis merry laughs. In this, however, he failed when his wit consisted\r\nin allusions to the novels of the day, of which Guy knew nothing. One\r\nmorning he underwent a regular examination, ending in--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you read anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid I am very ignorant of modern books.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you read the ancient ones?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve had nothing else to read.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing to read but ancient books!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Amabel, with a mixture of\r\npity and astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sanchoniathon, Manetho, Berosus, and Ocellus Lucanus!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy,\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There, Amy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98if he has the Vicar of Wakefield among his\r\nancient books, you need not pity him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is like Philip,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98he was brought up on the old standard\r\nbooks, instead of his time being frittered away on the host of idle\r\nmodern ones.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was free to concentrate his attention on Sir Charles Grandison,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How could any one do so?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98How could any one have any\r\nsympathy with such a piece of self-satisfaction?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who could? Eh, Laura?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never read it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, suspecting malice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is your opinion of perfect heroes?\xe2\x80\x99 continued Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here comes one,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Amy to her brother, blushing at her piece of\r\nnaughtiness, as Philip Morville entered the room.\r\n\r\nAfter the first greetings and inquiries after his sister, whom he had\r\nbeen visiting, Laura told him what they had been saying of the advantage\r\nof a scanty range of reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98I have often been struck by finding how ignorant\r\npeople are, even of Shakspeare; and I believe the blame chiefly rests on\r\nthe cheap rubbish in which Charlie is nearly walled up there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98and who haunts that rubbish at the beginning of\r\nevery month? I suppose to act as pioneer, though whether any one but\r\nLaura heeds his warnings, remains to be proved.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Laura does heed?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Philip, well pleased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I made her read me the part of Dombey that hurts women\xe2\x80\x99s feelings\r\nmost, just to see if she would go on--the part about little Paul--and\r\nI declare, I shall think the worse of her ever after--she was so stony\r\nhearted, that to this day she does not know whether he is dead or\r\nalive.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t quite say I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether he lived or died,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98for I found Amy in a state that alarmed me, crying in the green-house,\r\nand I was very glad to find it was nothing worse than little Paul.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish you would have read it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; and looking shyly at Guy, she\r\nadded--\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well done, Amy!\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98In the very face of the young man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompanion!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip does not really think it wrong,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98those books open fields of thought, and as their\r\nprinciples are negative, they are not likely to hurt a person well armed\r\nwith the truth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Meaning,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98that Guy and Laura have your gracious\r\npermission to read Dombey.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When Laura has a cold or toothache.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not sure about, the expediency for you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip \xe2\x80\x98it would be\r\na pity to begin with Dickens, when there is so much of a higher grade\r\nequally new to you. I suppose you do not understand Italian?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, abruptly, and his dark eyebrows contracted.\r\n\r\nPhilip went on. \xe2\x80\x98If you did, I should not recommend you the translation\r\nof \xe2\x80\x9cI promessi Sponsi,\xe2\x80\x9d one of the most beautiful books in any language.\r\nYou have it in English, I think, Laura.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura fetched it; Guy, with a constrained \xe2\x80\x98thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 was going to take\r\nit up rather as if he was putting a force upon himself, when Philip\r\nmore quickly took the first volume, and eagerly turned over the pages--I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t stand this,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98where is the original?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was soon produced; and Philip, finding the beautiful history of Fra\r\nCristoforo, began to translate it fluently and with an admirable choice\r\nof language that silenced Charles\xe2\x80\x99s attempts to interrupt and criticise.\r\nSoon Guy, who had at first lent only reluctant attention, was entirely\r\nabsorbed, his eyebrows relaxed, a look of earnest interest succeeded,\r\nhis countenance softened, and when Fra Cristoforo humbled himself,\r\nexchanged forgiveness, and received \xe2\x80\x9cil pane del perdono,\xe2\x80\x9d tears hung on\r\nhis eyelashes.\r\n\r\nThe chapter was finished, and with a smothered exclamation of\r\nadmiration, he joined the others in begging Philip to proceed. The story\r\nthus read was very unlike what it had been to Laura and Amy, when they\r\npuzzled it out as an Italian lesson, or to Charles, when he carelessly\r\ntossed over the translation in search of Don Abbondio\xe2\x80\x99s humours;\r\nand thus between reading and conversation, the morning passed very\r\nagreeably.\r\n\r\nAt luncheon, Mr. Edmonstone asked Philip to come and spend a day or two\r\nat Hollywell, and he accepted the invitation for the next week. \xe2\x80\x98I will\r\nmake Thorndale drive me out if you will give him a dinner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98we shall be delighted. We\r\nwere talking of asking him, a day or two ago; eh, mamma?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98a family party is an especial treat to him,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nlaying a particular stress on the word \xe2\x80\x98family party,\xe2\x80\x99 and looking at\r\nhis aunt.\r\n\r\nAt that moment the butler came in, saying, \xe2\x80\x98Sir Guy\xe2\x80\x99s servant is come,\r\nand has brought the horse, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Deloraine come!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy, springing up. \xe2\x80\x98Where?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At the door, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy darted out, Mr. Edmonstone following. In another instant, however,\r\nGuy put his head into the room again. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Edmonstone, won\xe2\x80\x99t you come\r\nand see him? Philip, you have not seen Deloraine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOff he rushed, and the others were just in time to see the cordial look\r\nof honest gladness with which William, the groom, received his young\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s greeting, and the delighted recognition between Guy, Bustle,\r\nand Deloraine. Guy had no attention for anything else till he had heard\r\nhow they had prospered on the journey; and then he turned to claim\r\nhis friend\xe2\x80\x99s admiration for the beautiful chestnut, his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbirthday present. The ladies admired with earnestness that compensated\r\nfor want of knowledge, the gentlemen with greater science and\r\ndiscrimination; indeed, Philip, as a connoisseur, could not but, for the\r\nsake of his own reputation, discover something to criticise. Guy\xe2\x80\x99s brows\r\ndrew together again, and his eyes glanced as if he was much inclined\r\nto resent the remarks, as attacks at once on Deloraine and on his\r\ngrandfather; but he said nothing, and presently went to the stable with\r\nMr. Edmonstone, to see about the horse\xe2\x80\x99s accommodations. Philip stood in\r\nthe hall with the ladies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I perceive you have dropped the title already,\xe2\x80\x99 observed he to\r\nLaura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, replying for her daughter, \xe2\x80\x98it seemed to\r\ngive him pain by reminding him of his loss, and he was so strange and\r\nforlorn just at first, that we were glad to do what we could to make him\r\nfeel himself more at home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you get on pretty well now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe reply was in chorus with variations--\xe2\x80\x98Oh, excellently!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is so entertaining,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He sings so beautifully,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amabel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is so right-minded,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So very well informed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\nThen it all began again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He plays chess so well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bustle is such a dear dog,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is so attentive to Charlie,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, going into the\r\ndrawing-room to her son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Papa says he will make up for the faults of all his ancestors,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nAmabel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His music! oh, his music!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, earnestly, \xe2\x80\x98you really should learn to like\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Learn, impertinent little puss?\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, smiling, \xe2\x80\x98why should I\r\nnot like him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was sure you would try,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, impressively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it hard?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98But, oh, Philip! you could not help liking his\r\nsinging.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never heard such a splendid voice,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98so clear and\r\npowerful, and yet so wonderfully sweet in the low soft notes.
