And a very\r\nfine ear: he has a real talent for music.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! inherited, poor fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, compassionately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you pity him for it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you forget?\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98I would not advise you to make much of\r\nthis talent in public; it is too much a badge of his descent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mamma did not think so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98She thought it a pity he should not\r\nlearn regularly, with such a talent; so the other day, when Mr. Radford\r\nwas giving us a lesson, she asked Guy just to sing up and down the\r\nscale. I never saw anything so funny as old Mr Radford\xe2\x80\x99s surprise,\r\nit was almost like the music lesson in \xe2\x80\x9cLa Figlia del Reggimento\xe2\x80\x9d; he\r\nstarted, and looked at Guy, and seemed in a perfect transport, and now\r\nGuy is to take regular lessons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But do you really mean,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98that if your mother had been a\r\nmusician\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, and you had inherited her talent, that you would be\r\nashamed of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed, Laura,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x98I am equally far from\r\nguessing what I should do if my mother had been anything but what she\r\nwas, as from guessing what I should do if I had a talent for music.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone here called her daughters to get ready for their walk,\r\nas she intended to go to East-hill, and they might as well walk with\r\nPhilip as far as their roads lay together.\r\n\r\nPhilip and Laura walked on by themselves, a little in advance of the\r\nothers. Laura was very anxious to arrive at a right understanding of her\r\ncousin\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure there is much to like in him,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is; but is it the highest praise to say there is much to like?\r\nPeople are not so cautious when they accept a man in toto.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then, do you not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPhilip\xe2\x80\x99s answer was--\r\n\r\n\r\n                  \xe2\x80\x98He who the lion\xe2\x80\x99s whelp has nurst,\r\n                   At home with fostering hand,\r\n                   Finds it a gentle thing at first,\r\n                   Obedient to command,\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think him a lion\xe2\x80\x99s whelp?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid I saw the lion just now in his flashing eyes and contracted\r\nbrow. There is an impatience of advice, a vehemence of manner that I\r\ncan hardly deem satisfactory. I do not speak from prejudice, for I think\r\nhighly of his candour, warmth of heart, and desire to do right; but from\r\nall I have seen, I should not venture as yet to place much dependence on\r\nhis steadiness of character or command of temper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He seems to have been very fond of his grandfather, in spite of his\r\nseverity. He is but just beginning to brighten up a little.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; his disposition is very affectionate,--almost a misfortune to one\r\nso isolated from family ties. He showed remarkably well at Redclyffe,\r\nthe other day; boyish of course, and without much self-command, but very\r\namiably. It is very well for him that he is removed from thence, for\r\nall the people idolize him to such a degree that they could not fail to\r\nspoil him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be a great pity if he went wrong.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Great, for he has many admirable qualities, but still they are just\r\nwhat persons are too apt to fancy compensation for faults. I never\r\nheard that any of his family, except perhaps that unhappy old Hugh,\r\nwere deficient in frankness and generosity, and therefore these do not\r\nsatisfy me. Observe, I am not condemning him; I wish to be perfectly\r\njust; all I say is, that I do not trust him till I have seen him tried.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura did not answer, she was disappointed; yet there was a justice and\r\nguardedness in what Philip said, that made it impossible to gainsay\r\nit, and she was pleased with his confidence. She thought how cool and\r\nprudent he was, and how grieved she should be if Guy justified his\r\ndoubts; and so they walked on in such silence as is perhaps the\r\nstrongest proof of intimacy. She was the first to speak, led to do so\r\nby an expression of sadness about her cousin\xe2\x80\x99s mouth. \xe2\x80\x98What are you\r\nthinking of, Philip?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of Locksley Hall. There is nonsense, there is affectation in that,\r\nLaura, there is scarcely poetry, but there is power, for there is\r\ntruth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of Locksley Hall! I thought you were at Stylehurst.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I was, but the one brings the other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you went to Stylehurst while you were at St. Mildred\xe2\x80\x99s? Did\r\nMargaret take you there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Margaret? Not she; she is too much engaged with her book-club, and her\r\nsoir\xc3\xa9es, and her societies of every sort and kind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How did you get on with the Doctor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I saw as little of him as I could, and was still more convinced that he\r\ndoes not know what conversation is. Hem!\xe2\x80\x99 Philip gave a deep sigh. \xe2\x80\x98No;\r\nthe only thing to be done at St. Mildred\xe2\x80\x99s is to walk across the moors\r\nto Stylehurst. It is a strange thing to leave that tumult of gossip, and\r\nnovelty, and hardness, and to enter on that quiet autumnal old world,\r\nwith the yellow leaves floating silently down, just as they used to do,\r\nand the atmosphere of stillness round the green churchyard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gossip!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Laura.\xe2\x80\x99 Surely not with Margaret?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Literary, scientific gossip is worse than gossip in a primary sense,\r\nwithout pretension.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad you had Stylehurst to go to. How was the old sexton\xe2\x80\x99s wife?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well; trotting about on her pattens as merrily as ever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you go into the garden?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s ivy has entirely covered the south wall, and the acacia is\r\nso tall and spreading, that I longed to have the pruning of it. Old Will\r\nkeeps everything in its former state.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey talked on of the old home, till the stern bitter look of regret and\r\ncensure had faded from his brow, and given way to a softened melancholy\r\nexpression.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 4\r\n\r\n     A fig for all dactyls, a fig for all spondees,\r\n     A fig for all dunces and dominie grandees.\r\n                                         --SCOTT\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How glad I am!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Guy, entering the drawing-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wherefore?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought I was too late, and I am very glad to find no one arrived,\r\nand Mr. and Mrs. Edmonstone not come down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But where have you been?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I lost my way on the top of the down; I fancied some one told me there\r\nwas a view of the sea to be had there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And can\xe2\x80\x99t you exist without a view of the sea?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy laughed. \xe2\x80\x98Everything looks so dull--it is as if the view was dead or\r\nimprisoned--walled up by wood and hill, and wanting that living ripple,\r\nheaving and struggling.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And your fine rocks?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish you could see the Shag stone,--a great island mass, sloping on\r\none side, precipitous on the other, with the spray dashing on it. If you\r\nsee it from ever so far off, there is still that white foam coming and\r\ngoing--a glancing speck, like the light in an eye.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hark! a carriage.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The young man and the young man\xe2\x80\x99s companion,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98What would any one suppose Mr. Thorndale to\r\nbe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not Philip\xe2\x80\x99s valet,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98if it is true that no man is a hero\r\nto his \xe2\x80\x9cvalley-de-sham\xe2\x80\x9d; whereas, what is not Philip to the Honourable\r\nJames Thorndale?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip, Alexander, and Bucephalus into the bargain,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Amy,\r\nin her demure, frightened whisper, sending all but Laura into a fit of\r\nlaughter, the harder to check because the steps of the parties concerned\r\nwere heard approaching.\r\n\r\nMr. Thorndale was a quiet individual, one of those of whom there is\r\nleast to be said, so complete a gentleman that it would have been an\r\ninsult, to call him gentleman-like; agreeable and clever rather than\r\notherwise, good-looking, with a high-bred air about him, so that it\r\nalways seemed strange that he did not make more impression.\r\n\r\nA ring at the front-door almost immediately followed their arrival.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Encore?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Philip, looking at Laura with a sort of displeased\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unfortunately, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, drawing aside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s family parties,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98I wish I had not\r\nbrought Thorndale. Laura, what is to be done to prevent the tittering\r\nthat always takes place when Amy and those Harpers are together?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Some game?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. He signed approval; but she had time to say no\r\nmore, for her father and mother came down, and some more guests entered.\r\n\r\nIt was just such a party that continually grew up at Hollywell, for\r\nMr. Edmonstone was so fond of inviting, that his wife never knew in the\r\nmorning how many would assemble at her table in the evening. But she was\r\nused to it, and too good a manager even to be called so. She liked to\r\nsee her husband enjoy himself in his good-natured, open-hearted way. The\r\nchange was good for Charles, and thus it did very well, and there were\r\nfew houses in the neighbourhood more popular than Hollywell.\r\n\r\nThe guests this evening were Maurice de Courcy, a wild young Irishman,\r\nall noise and nonsense, a great favourite with his cousin, Mr.\r\nEdmonstone; two Miss Harpers, daughters of the late clergyman,\r\ngood-natured, second-rate girls; Dr. Mayerne, Charles\xe2\x80\x99s kind old\r\nphysician, the friend and much-loved counsellor at Hollywell, and the\r\npresent vicar, Mr. Ross with his daughter Mary.\r\n\r\nMary Ross was the greatest friend that the Miss Edmonstones possessed,\r\nthough, she being five-and-twenty, they had not arrived at perceiving\r\nthat they were on the equal terms of youngladyhood.\r\n\r\nShe had lost her mother early, and had owed a great deal to the kindness\r\nof Mrs. Edmonstone, as she grew up among her numerous elder brothers.\r\nShe had no girlhood; she was a boy till fourteen, and then a woman, and\r\nshe was scarcely altered since the epoch of that transition, the same\r\nin likings, tastes, and duties. \xe2\x80\x98Papa\xe2\x80\x99 was all the world to her, and\r\npleasing him had much the same meaning now as then; her brothers were\r\nlike playfellows; her delights were still a lesson in Greek from papa, a\r\nschool-children\xe2\x80\x99s feast, a game at play, a new book. It was only a pity\r\nother people did not stand still too. \xe2\x80\x98Papa,\xe2\x80\x99 indeed, had never grown\r\nsensibly older since the year of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s death: but her brothers\r\nwere whiskered men, with all the cares of the world, and no holidays;\r\nthe school-girls went out to service, and were as a last year\xe2\x80\x99s brood to\r\nan old hen; the very children she had fondled were young ladies, as old,\r\nto all intents and purposes, as herself, and here were even Laura and\r\nAmy Edmonstone fallen into that bad habit of growing up! though little\r\nAmy had still much of the kitten in her composition, and could play\r\nas well as Charlotte or Mary herself, when they had the garden to\r\nthemselves.\r\n\r\nMary took great pains to amuse Charles, always walking to see him in\r\nthe worst weather, when she thought other visitors likely to fall, and\r\nchatting with him as if she was the idlest person in the world, though\r\nthe quantity she did at home and in the parish would be too amazing\r\nto be recorded. Spirited and decided, without superfluous fears and\r\nfineries, she had a firm, robust figure, and a rosy, good-natured face,\r\nwith a manner that, though perfectly feminine, had in it an air of\r\nstrength and determination.\r\n\r\nHollywell was a hamlet, two miles from the parish church of East-hill,\r\nand Mary had thus seen very little of the Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s guest, having\r\nonly been introduced to him after church on Sunday. The pleasure on\r\nwhich Charles chiefly reckoned for that evening was the talking him over\r\nwith her when the ladies came in from the dining-room. The Miss Harpers,\r\nwith his sisters, gathered round the piano, and Mrs. Edmonstone sat at\r\nCharles\xe2\x80\x99s feet, while Mary knitted and talked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you get on well with him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is one of those people who are never in the way, and yet you never\r\ncan forgot their presence,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His manners are quite the pink of courtesy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Like his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98that old-school\r\ndeference and attention is very chivalrous, and sits prettily and\r\nquaintly on his high spirits and animation; I hope it will not wear\r\noff.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A vain hope,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98At present he is like that German myth,\r\nKaspar Hauser, who lived till twenty in a cellar. It is lucky for mamma\r\nthat, in his green state, he is courtly instead of bearish.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lucky for you, too, Charlie; he spoils you finely.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has the rare perfection of letting me know my own mind. I never knew\r\nwhat it was to have my own way before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that your complaint, Charlie? What next?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you think I have my way, do you, Mary? That is all envy, you see,\r\nand very much misplaced. Could you guess what a conflict it is every\r\ntime I am helped up that mountain of a staircase, or the slope of\r\nmy sofa is altered? Last time Philip stayed here, every step cost an\r\nargument, till at last, through sheer exhaustion, I left myself a dead\r\nweight on his hands, to be carried up by main strength. And after all,\r\nhe is such a great, strong fellow, that I am afraid he did not mind it;\r\nso next time I _crutched_ myself down alone, and I hope that did provoke\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir Guy is so kind that I am ashamed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98It seems\r\nas if we had brought him for the sole purpose of waiting on Charles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Half his heart is in his horse,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98Never had man such\r\ndelight in the \xe2\x80\x9cbrute creation.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They have been his chief playfellows,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98The\r\nchief of his time was spent in wandering in the woods or on the beach,\r\nwatching them and their ways.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I fairly dreamt of that Elysium of his last night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98a swamp half frozen on a winter\xe2\x80\x99s night, full of wild ducks. Here,\r\nCharlotte, come and tell Mary the roll of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s pets.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharlotte began. \xe2\x80\x98There was the sea-gull, and the hedgehog, and the fox,\r\nand the badger, and the jay, and the monkey, that he bought because it\r\nwas dying, and cured it, only it died the next winter, and a toad, and a\r\nraven, and a squirrel, and--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That will do, Charlotte.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! but Mary has not heard the names of all his dogs. And Mary, he has\r\ncured Bustle of hunting my Puss. We held them up to each other, and Puss\r\nhissed horribly, but Bustle did not mind it a bit; and the other day,\r\nwhen Charles tried to set him at her, he would not take the least\r\nnotice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Charlotte,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, waving his hand, with a provoking mock\r\npoliteness, \xe2\x80\x98have the goodness to return to your friends.\r\n\r\nTea over, Laura proposed the game of definitions. \xe2\x80\x98You know it. Philip,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid she, \xe2\x80\x98you taught us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes I learnt it of your sisters, Thorndale,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O pray let us have it. It must be charming!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Harper, on\r\nthis recommendation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Definitions!\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, contemptuously. \xe2\x80\x98Dr. Johnson must be the\r\nhand for them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are just the definitions not to be found in Johnson,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nThorndale. \xe2\x80\x98Our standing specimen is adversity, which may be differently\r\nexplained according to your taste, as \xe2\x80\x9ca toad with a precious jewel in\r\nits head,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cthe test of friendship.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The spirit of words,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, looking eager and interested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, we\xe2\x80\x99ll try,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98though I can\xe2\x80\x99t say it sounds to me\r\npromising. Come, Maurice, define an Irishman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, don\xe2\x80\x99t let us be personal,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98I had thought of the\r\nword \xe2\x80\x9chappiness\xe2\x80\x9d. We are each to write a definition on a slip of paper,\r\nthen compare them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe game was carried on with great spirit for more than an hour. It was\r\nhard to say, which made most fun, Maurice, Charles, or Guy; the last\r\nno longer a spectator, but an active contributor to the sport. When the\r\nbreak-up came, Mary and Amabel were standing over the table together,\r\ncollecting the scattered papers, and observing that it had been very\r\ngood fun. \xe2\x80\x98Some so characteristic,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98such as Maurice\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndefinition of happiness,--a row at Dublin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Some were very deep, though,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary; \xe2\x80\x98if it is not treason, I\r\nshould like to make out whose that other was of happiness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean this,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy: \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cGleams from a brighter world, too soon\r\neclipsed or forfeited.\xe2\x80\x9d I thought it was Philip\xe2\x80\x99s, but it is Sir Guy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwriting. How very sad! I should not like to think so. And he was so\r\nmerry all the time! This is his, too, I see; this one about riches being\r\nthe freight for which the traveller is responsible.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is a great deal of character in them,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mary. \xe2\x80\x98I should not\r\nhave wondered at any of us, penniless people, philosophizing in the fox\r\nand grapes style, but, for him, and at his age--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has been brought up so as to make the theory of wisdom come early,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Philip, who was nearer than she thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that intended for disparagement?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked quickly.\r\n\r\nI think very highly of him; he has a great deal of sense and right\r\nfeeling,\xe2\x80\x99 was Philip\xe2\x80\x99s sedate answer; and he turned away to say some\r\nlast words to Mr. Thorndale.\r\n\r\nThe Rosses were the last to depart, Mary in cloak and clogs, while Mr.\r\nEdmonstone lamented that it was in vain to offer the carriage; and Mary\r\nlaughed, and thanked, and said the walk home with Papa was the greatest\r\nof treats in the frost and star-light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t I pity you, who always go out to dinner in a carriage!\xe2\x80\x99 were her\r\nlast words to Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, \xe2\x80\x98how do you like it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very much, indeed. It was very pleasant.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are getting into the fairy ring,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay\xe2\x80\x99 he said, smiling too; \xe2\x80\x98but it does not turn to tinsel. Would it if\r\nI saw more of it?\xe2\x80\x99 and he looked at Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be no compliment to ourselves to say so,\xe2\x80\x99 she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose tinsel or gold depends on the using,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, thoughtfully;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98there are some lumps of solid gold among those papers, I am sure, one,\r\nin particular, about a trifle. May I see that again? I mean--\r\n\r\n\r\n                  \xe2\x80\x98Little things\r\n                   On little wings\r\n                 Bear little souls to heaven.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! that was only a quotation,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, turning over the definitions\r\nagain with him, and laughing at some of the most amusing; while, in the\r\nmean time, Philip went to help Laura, who was putting some books away in\r\nthe ante-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Laura,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98he has thought, mind, and soul; he is no mere\r\nrattle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No indeed. Who could help seeing his superiority over Maurice?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If only he does not pervert his gifts, and if it is not all talk. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like such excess of openness about his feelings; it is too like\r\ntalking for talking\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mamma says it in the transparency of youthfulness. You know he has\r\nnever been at school; so his thoughts come out in security of sympathy,\r\nwithout fear of being laughed at. But it is very late. Good night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nThe frost turned to rain the next morning, and the torrents streamed\r\nagainst the window, seeming to have a kind of attraction for Philip and\r\nGuy, who stood watching them.\r\n\r\nGuy wondered if the floods would be out at Redclyffe and his cousins\r\nwere interested by his description of the sudden, angry rush of the\r\nmountain streams, eddying fiercely along, bearing with them tree and\r\nrock, while the valleys became lakes, and the little mounds islets; and\r\nthe trees looked strangely out of proportion when only their branches\r\nwere visible. \xe2\x80\x98Oh! a great flood is famous fun,\xe2\x80\x99 said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, \xe2\x80\x98I have heard a legend of your being nearly\r\ndrowned in some flood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, \xe2\x80\x98I had a tolerable ducking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, tell us about it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay! I have a curiosity to hear a personal experience of drowning,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nCharles. \xe2\x80\x98Come, begin at the beginning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was standing watching the tremendous force of the stream, when I saw\r\nan unhappy old ram floating along, bleating so piteously, and making\r\nsuch absurd, helpless struggles, that I could not help pulling off my\r\ncoat and jumping in after him. It was very foolish, for the stream was\r\ntoo strong--I was two years younger then. Moreover, the beast was very\r\nheavy, and not at all grateful for any kind intentions, and I found\r\nmyself sailing off to the sea, with the prospect of a good many rocks\r\nbefore long; but just then an old tree stretched out its friendly\r\narms through the water; it stopped the sheep, and I caught hold of the\r\nbranches, and managed to scramble up, while my friend got entangled in\r\nthem with his wool\xe2\x80\x99--\r\n\r\n\r\n                  \xe2\x80\x98Omne quum Proteus pecus egit altos\r\n                                      Visere montes,\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nquoted Philip.\r\n\r\n\r\n                  \xe2\x80\x98Ovium et summa, genus haesit ulmo,\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nadded Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_Ovium_,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Philip, with a face of horror. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that\r\n_O_ in _Ovis_ is short? Do anything but take liberties with Horace!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Get out of the tree first, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98for at present your\r\nhistory seems likely to end with a long ohone!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Triton--not Proteus--came to the rescue at last,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy,\r\nlaughing; \xe2\x80\x98I could not stir, and the tree bent so frightfully with the\r\ncurrent that I expected every minute we should all go together; so I\r\nhad nothing for it but to halloo as loud as I could. No one heard but\r\nTriton, the old Newfoundland dog, who presently came swimming up, so\r\neager to help, poor fellow, that I thought he would have throttled me,\r\nor hurt himself in the branches. I took off my handkerchief and threw it\r\nto him, telling him to take it to Arnaud, who I knew would understand it\r\nas a signal of distress.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did he? How long had you to wait?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know--it seemed long enough before a most welcome boat\r\nappeared, with some men in it, and Triton in an agony. They would never\r\nhave found me but for him, for my voice was gone; indeed the next thing\r\nI remember was lying on the grass in the park, and Markham saying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir, if you do wish to throw away your life, let it be for\r\nsomething better worth saving than Farmer Holt\xe2\x80\x99s vicious old ram!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the language of the great Mr. Toots,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles \xe2\x80\x98I am afraid you\r\ngot very wet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Were you the worse for it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not in the least. I was so glad to hear it was Holt\xe2\x80\x99s! for you must\r\nknow that I had behaved very ill to Farmer Holt. I had been very angry\r\nat his beating our old hound, for, as he thought, worrying his sheep;\r\nnot that Dart ever did, though.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And was the ram saved?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, and next time I saw it, it nearly knocked me down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would you do it again?\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you had a medal from the Humane Society,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That would have been more proper for Triton.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yours should have been an ovation,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, cutting the o\r\nabsurdly short, and looking at Philip.\r\n\r\nLaura saw that the spirit of teasing was strong in Charles this morning\r\nand suspected that he wanted to stir up what he called the deadly\r\nfeud, and she hastened to change the conversation by saying, \xe2\x80\x98You quite\r\nimpressed Guy with your translation of Fra Cristoforo.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed I must thank you for recommending the book,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98how\r\nbeautiful it is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad you entered into it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98it has every quality that\r\na fiction ought to have.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never read anything equal to the repentance of the nameless man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is he your favourite character?\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, looking at him\r\nattentively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh no--of course not--though he is so grand that one thinks most about\r\nhim, but no one can be cared about as much as Lucia.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lucia! She never struck me as more than a well-painted peasant girl,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy, indignantly; then, controlling himself, he continued:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She pretends to no more than she is, but she shows the beauty of\r\ngoodness in itself in a--a--wonderful way. And think of the power of\r\nthose words of hers over that gloomy, desperate man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your sympathy with the Innominato again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. Every subject\r\nseemed to excite Guy to a dangerous extent, as Laura thought, and she\r\nturned to Philip to ask if he would not read to them again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I brought this book on purpose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98I wished to read you a\r\ndescription of that print from Raffaelle--you know it--the Madonna di\r\nSan Sisto?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The one you brought to show us?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98with the two little\r\nangels?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, here is the description,\xe2\x80\x99 and he began to read--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dwell on the form of the Child, more than human in grandeur, seated on\r\nthe arms of the Blessed Virgin as on an august throne. Note the tokens\r\nof divine grace, His ardent eyes, what a spirit, what a countenance is\r\nHis; yet His very resemblance to His mother denotes sufficiently that He\r\nis of us and takes care for us. Beneath are two figures adoring, each in\r\ntheir own manner. On one side is a pontiff, on the other a virgin each\r\na most sweet and solemn example, the one of aged, the other of maidenly\r\npiety and reverence. Between, are two winged boys, evidently presenting\r\na wonderful pattern of childlike piety. Their eyes, indeed, are not\r\nturned towards the Virgin, but both in face and gesture, they show how\r\ncareless of themselves they are in the presence of God.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAll were struck by the description. Guy did not speak at first, but\r\nthe solemn expression of his face showed how he felt its power and\r\nreverence. Philip asked if they would like to hear more, and Charles\r\nassented: Amy worked, Laura went on with her perspective, and Guy sat\r\nby her side, making concentric circles with her compasses, or when she\r\nwanted them he tormented her parallel ruler, or cut the pencils, never\r\nletting his fingers rest except at some high or deep passage, or when\r\nsome interesting discussion arose. All were surprised when luncheon time\r\narrived; Charles held out his hand for the book; it was given with a\r\nslight smile, and he exclaimed\xe2\x80\x99 Latin! I thought you were translating.\r\nIs it your own property?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it very tough? I would read it, if any one would read it with me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you mean me?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98I should like it very much, but you have\r\nseen how little Latin I know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is the very thing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98that Ovis of yours was music; I\r\nwould have made you a Knight of the Golden Fleece on the spot. Tutors I\r\ncould get by shoals, but a fellow-dunce is inestimable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a bargain, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98if Philip has done with the book and\r\nwill lend it to us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe luncheon bell rang, and they all adjourned to the dining-room. Mr.\r\nEdmonstone came in when luncheon was nearly over, rejoicing that his\r\nletters were done, but then he looked disconsolately from the window,\r\nand pitied the weather. \xe2\x80\x98Nothing for it but billiards. People might say\r\nit was nonsense to have a billiard-table in such a house, but for his\r\npart he found there was no getting through a wet day without them.\r\nPhilip must beat him as usual, and Guy might have one of the young\r\nladies to make a fourth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, \xe2\x80\x98but I don\xe2\x80\x99t play.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not play--eh?\xe2\x80\x99 Well, we will teach you in the spinning of a ball, and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll have my little Amy to help me against you and Philip.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Guy, colouring, \xe2\x80\x98I am under a promise.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha! Eh? What? Your grandfather? He could see no harm in such play as\r\nthis. For nothing, you understand. You did not suppose I meant anything\r\nelse?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O no, of course not,\xe2\x80\x99 eagerly replied Guy; \xe2\x80\x98but it is impossible for me\r\nto play, thank you. I have promised never even to look on at a game at\r\nbilliards.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, poor man, he had too much reason.\xe2\x80\x99 uttered Mr. Edmonstone to\r\nhimself, but catching a warning look from his wife, he became suddenly\r\nsilent. Guy, meanwhile, sat looking lost in sad thoughts, till, rousing\r\nhimself, he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me prevent you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Edmonstone needed but little persuasion, and carried Philip off to\r\nthe billiard-table in the front hall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, I am so glad!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charlotte, who had, within the last week,\r\nlearnt Guy\xe2\x80\x99s value as a playfellow. \xe2\x80\x98Now you will never go to those\r\nstupid billiards, but I shall have you always, every rainy day. Come and\r\nhave a real good game at ball on the stairs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe already had hold of his hand, and would have dragged him off at\r\nonce, had he not waited to help Charles back to his sofa; and in the\r\nmean time she tried in vain to persuade her more constant playmate,\r\nAmabel, to join the game. Poor little Amy regretted the being obliged to\r\nrefuse, as she listened to the merry sounds and bouncing balls, sighing\r\nmore than once at having turned into a grown-up young lady; while Philip\r\nobserved to Laura, who was officiating as billiard-marker, that Guy was\r\nstill a mere boy.\r\n\r\nThe fates favoured Amy at last for about half after three, the billiards\r\nwere interrupted, and Philip, pronouncing the rain to be almost over,\r\ninvited Guy to take a walk, and they set out in a very gray wet mist,\r\nwhile Charlotte and Amy commenced a vigorous game at battledore and\r\nshuttle-cock.\r\n\r\nThe gray mist had faded into twilight, and twilight into something like\r\nnight, when Charles was crossing the hall, with the aid of Amy\xe2\x80\x99s arm,\r\nCharlotte carrying the crutch behind him, and Mrs. Edmonstone helping\r\nLaura with her perspective apparatus, all on their way to dress for\r\ndinner; the door opened and in came the two Morvilles. Guy, without,\r\neven stopping to take off his great coat, ran at once up-stairs, and\r\nthe next moment the door of his room was shut with a bang that shook the\r\nhouse, and made them all start and look at Philip for explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Redclyffe temper,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, coolly, with a half-smile curling his short\r\nupper lip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you been doing to him?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing. At least nothing worthy of such ire. I only entered on the\r\nsubject of his Oxford life, and advised him to prepare for it, for his\r\neducation has as yet been a mere farce. He used to go two or three days\r\nin the week to one Potts, a self-educated genius--a sort of superior\r\nwriting-master at the Moorworth commercial school. Of course, though it\r\nis no fault of his, poor fellow, he is hardly up to the fifth form, and\r\nhe must make the most of his time, if he is not to be plucked. I set\r\nall this before him as gently as I could, for I knew with whom I had to\r\ndeal, yet you see how it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did he say?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He said nothing; so far I give him credit; but he strode on furiously\r\nfor the last half mile, and this explosion is the finale. I am very\r\nsorry for him, poor boy; I beg no further notice may be taken of it.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t you want an arm, Charlie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Charles, with a little surliness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had better. It really is too much for Amy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, making a\r\nmove as if to take possession of him, as he arrived at the foot of the\r\nstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Like the camellia, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied; and taking his other crutch\r\nfrom Charlotte, he began determinedly to ascend without assistance,\r\nresolved to keep Philip a prisoner below him as long as he could, and\r\nenjoying the notion of chafing him by the delay. Certainly teasing\r\nPhilip was a dear delight to Charles, though it was all on trust, as, if\r\nhe succeeded, his cousin never betrayed his annoyance by look or sign.\r\n\r\nAbout a quarter of an hour after, there was a knock at the\r\ndressing-room door. \xe2\x80\x98Come in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, looking up from her\r\nletter-writing, and Guy made his appearance, looking very downcast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am come,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98to ask pardon for the disturbance I made just\r\nnow. I was so foolish as to be irritated at Philip\xe2\x80\x99s manner, when he was\r\ngiving me some good advice, and I am very sorry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What has happened to your lip?\xe2\x80\x99 she exclaimed.\r\n\r\nHe put his handkerchief to it. \xe2\x80\x98Is it bleeding still? It is a trick\r\nof mine to bite my lip when I am vexed. It seems to help to keep down\r\nwords. There! I have given myself a mark of this hateful outbreak.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked very unhappy, more so, Mrs. Edmonstone thought, than the\r\nactual offence required. \xe2\x80\x98You have only failed in part,\xe2\x80\x99 she said. \xe2\x80\x98It\r\nwas a victory to keep down words.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The feeling is the _thing_,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98besides, I showed it plainly\r\nenough, without speaking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is not easy to take advice from one so little your elder,\xe2\x80\x99 began\r\nMrs. Edmonstone, but he interrupted her. \xe2\x80\x98It was not the advice. That\r\nwas very good; I--\xe2\x80\x99 but he spoke with an effort,--\xe2\x80\x98I am obliged to\r\nhim. It was--no, I won\xe2\x80\x99t say what,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, his eyes kindling, then\r\nchanging in a moment to a sorrowful, resolute tone, \xe2\x80\x98Yes, but I _will_,\r\nand then I shall make myself thoroughly ashamed. It was his veiled\r\nassumption of superiority, his contempt for all I have been taught.\r\nJust as if he had not every right to despise me, with his talent and\r\nscholarship, after such egregious mistakes as I had made in the morning.\r\nI gave him little reason to think highly of my attainments; but let him\r\nslight me as much as he pleases, he must not slight those who taught me.\r\nIt was not Mr. Potts\xe2\x80\x99 fault.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEven the name could not spoil the spirited sound of the speech, and Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone was full of sympathy. \xe2\x80\x98You must remember,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98that in\r\nthe eyes of a man brought up at public school, nothing compensates for\r\nthe want of the regular classical education. I have no doubt it was very\r\nprovoking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be excused, thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98Oh I am grieved; for\r\nI thought the worst of my temper had been subdued. After all that has\r\npassed--all I felt--I thought it impossible. Is there no hope for--\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHe covered his face with his hands, then recovering and turning to Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone, he said, \xe2\x80\x98It is encroaching too much on your kindness to\r\ncome here and trouble you with my confessions.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, earnestly. \xe2\x80\x98Remember how we agreed that you\r\nshould come to me like one of my own children. And, indeed, I do not see\r\nwhy you need grieve in this despairing way, for you almost overcame the\r\nfit of anger; and perhaps you were off your guard because the trial came\r\nin an unexpected way?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It did, it did,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, eagerly; \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t, mind being told point\r\nblank that I am a dunce, but that Mr. Potts--nay, by implication--my\r\ngrandfather should be set at nought in that cool--But here I am again!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid he, checking himself in the midst of his vehemence; \xe2\x80\x98he did not\r\nmean that, of course. I have no one to blame but myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98that if you always treat your\r\nfailings in this way, you must subdue them at last.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is all failing, and resolving, and failing again!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, but the failures become slighter and less frequent, and the end is\r\nvictory.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The end victory!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Guy, in a musing tone, as he stood leaning\r\nagainst the mantelshelf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, to all who persevere and seek for help,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Edmonstone;\r\nand he raised his eyes and fixed them on her with an earnest look that\r\nsurprised her, for it was almost as if the hope came home to him\r\nas something new. At that moment, however, she was called away, and\r\ndirectly after a voice in the next room exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98Are you there, Guy?\r\nI want an arm!\xe2\x80\x99 while he for the first time perceived that Charles\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndoor was ajar.\r\n\r\nCharles thought all this a great fuss about nothing, indeed he was glad\r\nto find there was anyone who had no patience with Philip; and in his\r\nusual mischievous manner, totally reckless of the fearful evil of\r\ninterfering with the influence for good which it was to be hoped that\r\nPhilip might exert over Guy, he spoke thus: \xe2\x80\x98I begin to think the world\r\nmust be more docile than I have been disposed to give it credit for. How\r\na certain cousin of ours has escaped numerous delicate hints to mind his\r\nown business is to me one of the wonders of the world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No one better deserves that his advice should be followed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy,\r\nwith some constraint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An additional reason against it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98Plague on that bell!\r\nI meant to have broken through your formalities and had a candid opinion\r\nof Don Philip before it rang.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I am glad of it; I could hardly have given you a candid opinion\r\njust at present.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles was vexed; but he consoled himself by thinking that Guy did not\r\nyet feel himself out of his leading-strings, and was still on his good\r\nbehaviour. After such a flash as this there was no fear, but there was\r\nthat in him which would create mischief and disturbance enough. Charles\r\nwas well principled at the bottom, and would have shrunk with horror had\r\nit been set before him how dangerous might be the effect of destroying\r\nthe chance of a friendship between Guy and the only person whose\r\nguidance was likely to be beneficial to him; but his idle, unoccupied\r\nlife, and habit of only thinking of things as they concerned his\r\nimmediate amusement, made him ready to do anything for the sake of\r\nopposition to Philip, and enjoy the vague idea of excitement to be\r\nderived from anxiety about his father\xe2\x80\x99s ward, whom at the same time he\r\nregarded with increased liking as he became certain that what he called\r\nthe Puritan spirit was not native to him.\r\n\r\nAt dinner-time, Guy was as silent as on his first arrival, and there\r\nwould have been very little conversation had not the other gentleman\r\ntalked politics, Philip leading the discussion to bear upon the duties\r\nand prospects of landed proprietors, and dwelling on the extent of\r\ntheir opportunities for doing good. He tried to get Guy\xe2\x80\x99s attention, by\r\nspeaking of Redclyffe, of the large circle influenced by the head of\r\nthe Morville family, and of the hopes entertained by Lord Thorndale\r\nthat this power would prove a valuable support to the rightful cause.\r\nHe spoke in vain; the young heir of Redclyffe made answers as brief,\r\nabsent, and indifferent, as if all this concerned him no more than the\r\nEmperor of Morocco, and Philip, mentally pronouncing him sullen, turned\r\nto address himself to Laura.\r\n\r\nAs soon as the ladies had left the dining-room, Guy roused himself, and\r\nbegan by saying to his guardian that he was afraid he was very deficient\r\nin classical knowledge; that he found he must work hard before going to\r\nOxford; and asked whether there was any tutor in the neighbourhood to\r\nwhom he could apply.\r\n\r\nMr. Edmonstone opened his eyes, as much amazed as if Guy had asked if\r\nthere was any executioner in the neighbourhood who could cut off his\r\nhead. Philip was no less surprised, but he held his peace, thinking it\r\nwas well Guy bad sense enough to propose it voluntarily, as he would\r\nhave suggested it to his uncle as soon as there was an opportunity of\r\ndoing so in private. As soon as Mr. Edmonstone had recollected himself,\r\nand pronounced it to be exceedingly proper, &c., they entered into a\r\ndiscussion on the neighbouring curates, and came at last to a resolution\r\nthat Philip should see whether Mr. Lascelles, a curate of Broadstone,\r\nand an old schoolfellow of his own, would read with Guy a few hours in\r\nevery week.\r\n\r\nAfter this was settled, Guy looked relieved, though he was not himself\r\nall the evening, and sat in his old corner between the plants and the\r\nwindow, where he read a grave book, instead of talking, singing, or\r\nfinishing his volume of \xe2\x80\x98Ten Thousand a Year.\xe2\x80\x99 Charlotte was all this\r\ntime ill at ease. She looked from Guy to Philip, from Philip to Guy; she\r\nshut her mouth as if she was forming some great resolve, then coloured,\r\nand looked confused, rushing into the conversation with something more\r\nmal-apropos than usual, as if on purpose to appear at her ease. At last,\r\njust before her bed-time, when the tea was coming in, Mrs. Edmonstone\r\nengaged with that, Laura reading, Amy clearing Charles\xe2\x80\x99s little table,\r\nand Philip helping Mr. Edmonstone to unravel the confused accounts\r\nof the late cheating bailiff, Guy suddenly found her standing by him,\r\nperusing his face with all the power of her great blue eyes. She started\r\nas he looked up, and put her face into Amabel\xe2\x80\x99s great myrtle as if she\r\nwould make it appear that she was smelling to it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Charlotte?\xe2\x80\x99 said he, and the sound of his voice made her speak,\r\nbut in a frightened, embarrassed whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Guy--Guy--Oh! I beg your pardon, but I wanted to--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, what?\xe2\x80\x99 said he, kindly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wanted to make sure that you are not angry with Philip. You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmean to keep up the feud, do you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Feud?--I hope not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, too much in earnest to be diverted with\r\nher lecture. \xe2\x80\x98I am very much obliged to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you really?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, her head a little on one side. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nthought he had been scolding you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nScolding was so very inappropriate to Philip\xe2\x80\x99s calm, argumentative way\r\nof advising, that it became impossible not to laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not scolding, then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte. \xe2\x80\x98You are too nearly grown up for\r\nthat, but telling you to learn, and being tiresome.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was so foolish as to be provoked at first,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Guy; \xe2\x80\x98but I hope\r\nI have thought better of it, and am going to act upon it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharlotte opened her eyes wider than ever, but in the midst of her\r\namazement Mrs. Edmonstone called to Guy to quit his leafy screen and\r\ncome to tea.\r\n\r\nPhilip was to return to Broadstone the next day, and as Mrs. Edmonstone\r\nhad some errands there that would occupy her longer than Charles liked\r\nto wait in the carriage, it was settled that Philip should drive her\r\nthere in the pony phaeton, and Guy accompany them and drive back, thus\r\nhaving an opportunity of seeing Philip\xe2\x80\x99s print of the \xe2\x80\x98Madonna di San\r\nSisto,\xe2\x80\x99 returning some calls, and being introduced to Mr. Lascelles,\r\nwhilst she was shopping. They appointed an hour and place of meeting,\r\nand kept to it, after which Mrs. Edmonstone took Guy with her to call on\r\nMrs. Deane, the wife of the colonel.\r\n\r\nIt was currently believed among the young Edmonstones that Mamma and\r\nMrs. Deane never met without talking over Mr. Morville\xe2\x80\x99s good qualities,\r\nand the present visit proved no exception. Mrs. Deane, a kind,\r\nopen-hearted, elderly lady was very fond of Mr. Morville, and proud\r\nof him as a credit to the regiment; and she told several traits of his\r\nexcellent judgment, kindness of heart, and power of leading to the right\r\ncourse. Mrs. Edmonstone listened, and replied with delight; and no\r\nless pleasure and admiration were seen reflected in her young friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nradiant face.\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s first question, as they set out on their homeward\r\ndrive, was, whether they had seen Mr. Lascelles?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, \xe2\x80\x98I am to begin to morrow, and go to him every Monday\r\nand Thursday.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is prompt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! I have no time to lose; besides I have been leading too smooth\r\na life with you. I want something unpleasant to keep me in order.\r\nSomething famously horrid,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated he, smacking the whip with a\r\nrelish, as if he would have applied that if he could have found nothing\r\nelse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think you live too smoothly at Hollywell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone,\r\nhardly able, with all her respect for his good impulses, to help\r\nlaughing at this strange boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Happy, thoughtless, vehement; that is what your kindness makes\r\nme. Was it not a proof, that I must needs fly out at such a petty\r\nprovocation?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should not have thought it such a very exciting life; certainly not\r\nsuch as is usually said to lead to thoughtlessness; and we have been\r\neven quieter than usual since you came.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what stuff I am made of,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, gravely,\r\nthough smiling; \xe2\x80\x98your own home party is enough to do me harm; it is so\r\nexceedingly pleasant.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pleasant things do not necessarily do harm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not to you; not to people who are not easily unsettled; but when I\r\ngo up-stairs, after a talking, merry evening, such as the night before\r\nlast, I find that I have enjoyed it too much; I am all abroad! I can\r\nhardly fix my thoughts, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to do, since here I must\r\nbe, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t either be silent, or sit up in my own room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, smiling; \xe2\x80\x98there are duties of society which\r\nyou owe even to us dangerous people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no: don\xe2\x80\x99t misunderstand me. The fault is in myself. If it was\r\nnot for that, I could learn nothing but good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, speaking very\r\neagerly, distressed at her answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe I understand you,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, marvelling at the serious,\r\nascetic temper, coupled with the very high animal spirits. \xe2\x80\x98For your\r\ncomfort, I believe the unsettled feeling you complain of is chiefly the\r\neffect of novelty. You have led so very retired a life, that a lively\r\nfamily party is to you what dissipation would be to other people: and,\r\nas you must meet with the world some time or other, it is better the\r\nfirst encounter with should be in this comparatively innocent form. Go\r\non watching yourself, and it will do you no harm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYes, but if I find it does me harm? It would be cowardly to run away,\r\nand resistance should be from within. Yet, on the other hand, there is\r\nthe duty of giving up, wrenching oneself from all that has temptation in\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Edmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98that has no temptation in it;\r\nbut I should think the rule was plain. If a duty such as that of living\r\namong us for the present, and making yourself moderately agreeable,\r\ninvolves temptations, they must be met and battled from within. In the\r\nsame way, your position in society, with all its duties, could not be\r\nlaid aside because it is full of trial. Those who do such things are\r\nfainthearted, and fail in trust in Him who fixed their station, and\r\nfinds room for them to deny themselves in the trivial round and common\r\ntask. It is pleasure involving no duty that should be given up, if we\r\nfind it liable to lead us astray.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Guy, musingly; \xe2\x80\x98and this reading comes naturally, and\r\nis just what I wanted to keep the pleasant things from getting a full\r\nhold of me. I ought to have thought of it sooner, instead of dawdling a\r\nwhole month in idleness. Then all this would not have happened. I hope\r\nit will be very tough.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have no great love for Latin and Greek?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy, eagerly, \xe2\x80\x98to be sure I delight in Homer and the\r\nGeorgics, and plenty more. What splendid things there are in these old\r\nfellows! But, I never liked the drudgery part of the affair; and now if\r\nI am to be set to work to be accurate, and to get up all the grammar and\r\nthe Greek roots, it will be horrid enough in all conscience.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe groaned as deeply as if he had not been congratulating himself just\r\nbefore on the difficulty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who was your tutor?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Potts,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98He is a very clever man; he had a common\r\ngrammar-school education, but he struggled on--taught himself a great\r\ndeal--and at last thought it great promotion to be a teacher at the\r\nCommercial Academy, as they call it, at Moorworth, where Markham\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnephews went to school. He is very clever, I assure you, and very\r\npatient of the hard, wearing life he must have of it there; and oh! so\r\nenjoying a new book, or an afternoon to himself. When I was about eight\r\nor nine, I began with him, riding into Moorworth three times in a week;\r\nand I have gone on ever since. I am sure he has done the best he could\r\nfor me; and he made the readings very pleasant by his own enjoyment. If\r\nPhilip had known the difficulties that man has struggled through, and\r\nhis beautiful temper, persevering in doing his best and being contented,\r\nI am sure he could never have spoken contemptuously of him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure he would not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98all he meant was,\r\nthat a person without a university education cannot tell what the\r\nrequirements are to which a man must come up in these days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, laughing, \xe2\x80\x98how I wished Mr. Potts had been there to\r\nhave enjoyed listening to Philip and Mr. Lascelles discussing some\r\nnew Lexicon, digging down for roots of words, and quoting passages of\r\nobscure Greek poets at such a rate, that if my eyes had been shut I\r\ncould have thought them two withered old students in spectacles and\r\nsnuff-coloured coats.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip was in his element.\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Guy, with animation, \xe2\x80\x98the more I hear and see of\r\nPhilip, the more I wonder. What a choice collection of books he has--so\r\nmany of them school prizes, and how beautifully bound!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! that is one of Philip\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar ways. With all his prudence\r\nand his love of books, I believe he would not buy one unless he had a\r\nreasonable prospect of being able to dress it handsomely. Did you see\r\nthe print?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes that I did. What glorious loveliness! There is nothing that does\r\nit justice but the description in the lecture. Oh I forgot, you have\r\nnot heard it. You must let me read it to you by and by. Those two little\r\nangels, what faces they have. Perfect innocence--one full of reasoning,\r\nthe other of unreasoning adoration!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see it!\xe2\x80\x99 suddenly exclaimed Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98I see what you are like\r\nin one of your looks, not by any means, in all--it is to the larger of\r\nthose two angels.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very seldom, I should guess,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; and sinking his voice, as if\r\nhe was communicating a most painful fact, he added, \xe2\x80\x98My real likeness\r\nis old Sir Hugh\xe2\x80\x99s portrait at home. But what were we saying? Oh! about\r\nPhilip. How nice those stories were of Mrs. Deane\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is very fond of him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To have won so much esteem and admiration, already from strangers, with\r\nno prejudice in his favour.--It must be entirely his own doing; and well\r\nit may! Every time one hears of him, something comes out to make\r\nhim seem more admirable. You are laughing at me, and I own it is\r\npresumptuous to praise; but I did not mean to praise, only to admire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I like very much to hear my nephew praised; I was only smiling at your\r\nenthusiastic way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I only wonder I am not more enthusiastic,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98I suppose it is\r\nhis plain good sense that drives away that sort of feeling, for he is\r\nas near heroism in the way of self-sacrifice as a man can be in these\r\ndays.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor Philip! if disappointment can make a hero, it has fallen to his\r\nshare. Ah! Guy, you are brightening and looking like one of my young\r\nladies in hopes of a tale of true love crossed, but it was only love of\r\na sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The sister for whom he gave up so much?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, his sister Margaret. She was eight or nine years older, very\r\nhandsome, very clever, a good deal like him--a pattern elder sister;\r\nindeed, she brought him up in great part after his mother died, and he\r\nwas devoted to her. I do believe it made the sacrifice of his prospects\r\nquite easy to him, to know it was for her sake, that she would live\r\non at Stylehurst, and the change be softened to her. Then came Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nillness, and that lead to the marriage with Dr. Henley. It was just what\r\nno one could object to; he is a respectable man in full practice, with a\r\nlarge income; but he is much older than she is, not her equal in mind or\r\ncultivation, and though I hardly like to say so, not at all a religious\r\nman. At any rate, Margaret Morville was one of the last people one could\r\nbear to see marry for the sake of an establishment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Could her brother do nothing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He expostulated with all his might; but at nineteen he could do little\r\nwith a determined sister of twenty-seven; and the very truth and power\r\nof his remonstrance must have made it leave a sting. Poor fellow, I\r\nbelieve he suffered terribly--just as he had lost Fanny, too, which he\r\nfelt very deeply, for she was a very sweet creature, and he was very\r\nfond of her. It was like losing both sisters and home at once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Has he not just been staying with Mrs. Henley?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. There was never any coolness, as people call it. He is the one\r\nthing she loves and is proud of. They always correspond, and he often\r\nstays with her; but he owns to disliking the Doctor, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nhe has much comfort in Margaret herself, for he always comes back more\r\ngrave and stern than he went. Her house, with all her good wishes, can\r\nbe no home to him; and so we try to make Hollywell supply the place of\r\nStylehurst as well as we can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How glad he must be to have you to comfort him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip? Oh no. He was always reserved; open to no one but Margaret, not\r\neven to his father, and since her marriage he has shut himself up within\r\nhimself more than ever. It has, at least I think it is this that has\r\ngiven him a severity, an unwillingness to trust, which I believe is\r\noften the consequence of a great disappointment either in love or in\r\nfriendship.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you for telling me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy: \xe2\x80\x98I shall understand him better,\r\nand look up to him more. Oh! it is a cruel thing to find that what one\r\nloves is, or has not been, all one thought. What must he not have gone\r\nthrough!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone was well pleased to have given so much assistance to\r\nGuy\xe2\x80\x99s sincere desire to become attached to his cousin, one of the most\r\nfavourable signs in the character that was winning so much upon her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 5\r\n\r\n     A cloud was o\xe2\x80\x99er my childhood\xe2\x80\x99s dream,\r\n           I sat in solitude;\r\n     I know not how--I know not why,\r\n     But round my soul all drearily\r\n           There was a silent shroud.\r\n                   --THOUGHTS IN PAST YEARS\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone was anxious to hear Mr. Lascelle\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of his pupil,\r\nand in time she learnt that he thought Sir Guy had very good abilities,\r\nand a fair amount of general information; but that his classical\r\nknowledge was far from accurate, and mathematics had been greatly\r\nneglected. He had been encouraged to think his work done when he had\r\ngathered the general meaning of a passage, or translated it into English\r\nverse, spirited and flowing, but often further from the original than he\r\nor his tutor could perceive. He had never been taught to work, at least\r\nas other boys study, and great application would be requisite to bring\r\nhis attainments to a level with those of far less clever boys educated\r\nat a public school.\r\n\r\nMr. Lascelles told him so at first; but as there were no reflections on\r\nhis grandfather, or on Mr. Potts, Guy\xe2\x80\x99s lip did not suffer, and he\r\nonly asked how many hours a day he ought to read. \xe2\x80\x98Three,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr. Lascelles, with a due regard to a probable want of habits of\r\napplication; but then, remembering how much was undone, he added, that\r\n\xe2\x80\x98it ought to be four or more, if possible.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Four it _shall_ be,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98five if I can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis whole strength of will was set to accomplish these four hours,\r\ntaking them before and after breakfast, working hard all the morning\r\ntill the last hour before luncheon, when he came to read the lectures on\r\npoetry with Charles. Here, for the first time, it appeared that Charles\r\nhad so entirely ceased to consider him as company, as to domineer over\r\nhim like his own family.\r\n\r\nUsed as Guy had been to an active out-of-doors life, and now turned\r\nback to authors he had read long ago, to fight his way through the\r\nconstruction of their language, not excusing himself one jot of the\r\ndifficulty, nor turning aside from one mountain over which his own\r\nefforts could carry him, he found his work as tough and tedious as he\r\ncould wish or fear, and by the end of the morning was thoroughly fagged.\r\nThen would have been the refreshing time for recreation in that pleasant\r\nidling-place, the Hollywell drawing-room. Any other time of day would\r\nhave suited Charles as well for the reading, but he liked to take the\r\nhour at noon, and never perceived that this made all the difference to\r\nhis friend of a toil or a pleasure. Now and then Guy gave tremendous\r\nyawns; and once when Charles told him he was very stupid, proposed a\r\ndifferent time; but as Charles objected, he yielded as submissively as\r\nthe rest of the household were accustomed to do.\r\n\r\nTo watch Guy was one of Charles\xe2\x80\x99s chief amusements, and he rejoiced\r\ngreatly in the prospect of hearing his history of his first\r\ndinner-party. Mr., Mrs. and Miss Edmonstone, and Sir Guy Morville, were\r\ninvited to dine with Mr. and Mrs. Brownlow. Mr. Edmonstone was delighted\r\nas usual with any opportunity of seeing his neighbours; Guy looked as\r\nif he did not know whether he liked the notion or not; Laura told him it\r\nwould be very absurd and stupid, but there would be some good music, and\r\nCharles ordered her to say no more, that he might have the account, the\r\nnext morning, from a fresh and unprejudiced mind.\r\n\r\nThe next morning\xe2\x80\x99s question was, of course, \xe2\x80\x98How did you like your\r\nparty?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, it was great fun.\xe2\x80\x99 Guy\xe2\x80\x99s favourite answer was caught up in the\r\nmidst, as Laura replied, \xe2\x80\x98It was just what parties always are.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, let us have the history. Who handed who in to dinner? I hope Guy\r\nhad Mrs. Brownlow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; we had both the honourables.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not Philip!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98the fidus Achetes was without his pious Aeneas.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, enjoying the laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I could not help thinking of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, rather apologising, \xe2\x80\x98when\r\nI was watching Thorndale\xe2\x80\x99s manner; it is such an imitation of Philip;\r\nlooking droller, I think, in his absence, than in his presence. I wonder\r\nif he is conscious of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It does not suit him at all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; because he has no\r\nnatural dignity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A man ought to be six foot one, person and mind, to suit with that\r\ngrand, sedate, gracious way of Philip\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s Guy\xe2\x80\x99s measure of Philip\xe2\x80\x99s intellect,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98just six\r\nfoot one inch.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As much more than other people\xe2\x80\x99s twice his height,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who was your neighbour, Laura?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dr. Mayerne; I was very glad of him, to keep off those hunting friends\r\nof Mr. Brownlow, who never ask anything but if one has been to the\r\nraces, and if one likes balls.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And how did Mrs. Brownlow behave?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is a wonderful woman,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, in her quiet way;\r\nand Guy with an expression between drollery and simplicity, said, \xe2\x80\x98Then\r\nthere aren\xe2\x80\x99t many like her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is she really a lady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip commonly calls her \xe2\x80\x9cthat woman,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98He has never\r\ngot over her one night classing him with his \xe2\x80\x9cyoung man\xe2\x80\x9d and myself, as\r\nthree of the shyest monkeys she ever came across.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She won\xe2\x80\x99t say so of Maurice,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, as they recovered the laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I heard her deluding some young lady by saying he was the eldest son,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mamma!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Amy, \xe2\x80\x98could she have thought so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I put in a gentle hint on Lord de Courcy\xe2\x80\x99s existence, to which she\r\nanswered, in her quick way, \xe2\x80\x98O ay, I forgot; but then he is the second,\r\nand that\xe2\x80\x99s the next thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you could but have heard the stories she and Maurice were telling\r\neach other!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98He was playing her off, I believe; for whatever\r\nshe told, he capped it with something more wonderful. Is she really a\r\nlady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By birth,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. It is only her high spirits and small\r\njudgment that make her so absurd.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How loud she is, too!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98What was all that about horses,\r\nGuy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She was saying she drove two such spirited horses, that all the grooms\r\nwere afraid of them; and when she wanted to take out her little boy, Mr.\r\nBrownlow said \xe2\x80\x9cYou may do as you like my dear, but I won\xe2\x80\x99t have my son\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneck broken, whatever you do with your own.\xe2\x80\x9d So Maurice answered by\r\ndeclaring he knew a lady who drove not two, but four-in-hand, and when\r\nthe leaders turned round and looked her in the face, gave a little nod,\r\nand said, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m obliged for your civility.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! I wish I had heard that,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you hear her saying she smoked cigars?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEveryone cried out with horror or laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course, Maurice told a story of a lady who had a cigar case hanging\r\nat her chatelaine, and always took one to refresh her after a ball.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy was interrupted by the announcement of his horse, and rode off at\r\nonce to Mr. Lascelles.\r\n\r\nOn his return he went straight to the drawing-room, where Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone was reading to Charles, and abruptly exclaimed,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I told you wrong. She only said she had smoked one cigar.\xe2\x80\x99 Then\r\nperceiving that he was interrupting, he added, \xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nwent away.\r\n\r\nThe next evening, on coming in from a solitary skating, he found the\r\nyounger party in the drawing-room, Charles entertaining the Miss Harpers\r\nwith the story of the cigars. He hastily interposed--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I told you it was but one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, tried one, and went on. She was preparing an order for Havannah.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought I told you I repeated the conversation incorrectly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If it is not the letter, it is the spirit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, vexed at the\r\ninterference with his sport of amazing the Miss Harpers with outrageous\r\nstories of Mrs. Brownlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is just like her,\xe2\x80\x99 said one of them. \xe2\x80\x98I could believe anything of\r\nMrs. Brownlow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must not believe this,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, gently. \xe2\x80\x98I repeated incorrectly\r\nwhat had better have been forgotten, and I must beg my foolish\r\nexaggeration to go no further.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles became sullenly silent; Guy stood thoughtful; and Laura and\r\nAmabel could not easily sustain the conversation till the visitors took\r\ntheir leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s a pother!\xe2\x80\x99 grumbled Charles, as soon as they were gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon for spoiling your story,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; but it was my\r\nfault, so I was obliged to interfere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bosh!\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98Who cares whether she smoked one or twenty? She\r\nis Mrs. Brownlow still.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe point is, what was truth?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Straining at gnats,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Little wings?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, glancing at Amabel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have it your won way,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, throwing his head back; \xe2\x80\x98they must\r\nbe little souls, indeed that stick at such trash.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy\xe2\x80\x99s brows were contracted with vexation, but Laura looked up very\r\nprettily, saying--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind him. We must all honour you for doing such an unpleasant\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will recommend him favourably to Philip,\xe2\x80\x99 growled Charles.\r\n\r\nThere was no reply, and presently Guy asked whether he would go up to\r\ndress? Having no other way of showing his displeasure, he refused, and\r\nremained nursing his ill-humour, till he forgot how slight the offence\r\nhad been, and worked himself into a sort of insane desire--half\r\nmischievous, half revengeful--to be as provoking as he could in his\r\nturn.\r\n\r\nSeldom had he been more contrary, as his old nurse was wont to call it.\r\nNo one could please him, and Guy was not allowed to do anything for him.\r\nWhatever he said was intended to rub on some sore place in Guy\xe2\x80\x99s mind.\r\nHis mother and Laura\xe2\x80\x99s signs made him worse, for he had the pleasure of\r\nteasing them, also; but Guy endured it all with perfect temper, and he\r\ngrew more cross at his failure; yet, from force of habit, at bed-time,\r\nhe found himself on the stairs with Guy\xe2\x80\x99s arm supporting him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98I tried hard to poke up the lion to-night,\r\nbut I see it won\xe2\x80\x99t do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis plea of trying experiments was neither absolutely true nor false;\r\nbut it restored Charles to himself, by saving a confession that he\r\nhad been out of temper, and enabling him to treat with him wonted\r\nindifference the expostulations of father, mother, and Laura.\r\n\r\nNow that the idea of \xe2\x80\x98poking up the lion\xe2\x80\x99 had once occurred, it became\r\nhis great occupation to attempt it. He wanted to see some evidence of\r\nthe fiery temper, and it was a new sport to try to rouse it; one, too,\r\nwhich had the greater relish, as it kept the rest of the family on\r\nthorns.\r\n\r\nHe would argue against his real opinion, talk against his better sense,\r\ntake the wrong side, and say much that was very far from his true\r\nsentiments. Guy could not understand at first, and was quite confounded\r\nat some of the views he espoused, till Laura came to his help, greatly\r\nirritating her brother by hints that he was not in earnest. Next time\r\nshe could speak to Guy alone, she told him he must not take all Charles\r\nsaid literally.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought he could hardly mean it: but why should he talk so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t excuse him; I know it is very wrong, and at the expense of\r\ntruth, and it is very disagreeable of him--I wish he would not; but he\r\nalways does what he likes, and it is one of his amusements, so we must\r\nbear with him, poor fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFrom that time Guy seemed to have no trouble in reining in his temper\r\nin arguing with Charles, except once, when the lion was fairly roused by\r\nsomething that sounded like a sneer about King Charles I.\r\n\r\nHis whole face changed, his hazel eye gleamed with light like an\r\neagle\xe2\x80\x99s, and he started up, exclaiming--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You did not mean that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ask Strafford,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Charles, coolly, startled, but satisfied to\r\nhave found the vulnerable point.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ungenerous, unmanly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, his voice low, but quivering with\r\nindignation; \xe2\x80\x98ungenerous to reproach him with what he so bitterly\r\nrepented. Could not his penitence, could not his own blood\xe2\x80\x99--but as he\r\nspoke, the gleam of wrath faded, the flush deepened on the cheek, and he\r\nleft the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha!\xe2\x80\x99 soliloquized Charles, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve done it! I could fancy his wrath\r\nsomething terrific when it was once well up. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what was\r\ncoming next; but I believe he has got himself pretty well in hand. It is\r\nplaying with edge tools; and now I have been favoured with one flash of\r\nthe Morville eye, I\xe2\x80\x99ll let him alone; but it _ryled_ me to be treated as\r\nsomething beneath his anger, like a woman or a child.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn about ten minutes, Guy came back: \xe2\x80\x98I am sorry that I was hasty just\r\nnow,\xe2\x80\x99 said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I did not know you had such personal feelings about King Charles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you would do me a kindness,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Guy, \xe2\x80\x98you would just say you\r\ndid not mean it. I know you do not, but if you would only say so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad you have the wit to see I have too much taste to be a\r\nroundhead.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98I hope I shall know your jest from your earnest\r\nanother time. Only if you would oblige me, you would never jest again\r\nabout King Charles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis brow darkened into a stern, grave expression, so entirely in\r\nearnest, that Charles, though making no answer, could not do otherwise\r\nthan feel compliance unavoidable. Charles had never been so entirely\r\nconquered, yet, strange to say, he was not, as usual, rendered sullen.\r\n\r\nAt night, when Guy had taken him to his room, he paused and said--\xe2\x80\x98You\r\nare sure that you have forgiven me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What! You have not forgotten that yet?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry you bear so much malice,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What are you imagining?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy. \xe2\x80\x98It was my own part I was\r\nremembering, as I must, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles did not choose to betray that he did not see the necessity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought King Charles\xe2\x80\x99s wrongs were rankling. I only spoke as taking\r\nliberties with a friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, thoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x98it may be foolish, but I do not feel as\r\nif one could do so with King Charles. He is too near home; he suffered\r\nto much from scoffs and railings; his heart was too tender, his\r\nrepentance too deep for his friends to add one word even in jest to the\r\nheap of reproach.
