How one would have loved him!\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Guy, wrapped\r\nup in his own thoughts,--\xe2\x80\x98loved him for the gentleness so little\r\naccordant with the rude times and the part he had to act--served him\r\nwith half like a knight\xe2\x80\x99s devotion to his lady-love, half like devotion\r\nto a saint, as Montrose did--\r\n\r\n\r\n                 \xe2\x80\x98Great, good, and just, could I but rate\r\n                    My grief, and thy too rigid fate,\r\n                  I\xe2\x80\x99d weep the world in such a strain,\r\n                    As it should deluge once again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And, oh!\xe2\x80\x99 cried he, with sudden vehemence, \xe2\x80\x98how one would have fought\r\nfor him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would!\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98I should like to see you and Deloraine\r\ncharging at the head of Prince Rupert\xe2\x80\x99s troopers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, suddenly recalled, and colouring deeply;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe I forgot where I was, and have treated you to one of my old\r\ndreams in my boatings at home. You may quiz me as much as you please\r\ntomorrow. Good night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was a rhapsody!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Charles; \xe2\x80\x98yes it was. I wonder I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlaugh at it; but I was naturally carried along. Fancy that! He did it so\r\nnaturally; in fact, it was all from the bottom of his heart, and I\r\ncould not quiz him--no, no more than Montrose himself. He is a strange\r\narticle! But he keeps one awake, which is more than most people do!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy was indeed likely to keep every one awake just then; for Mr.\r\nEdmonstone was going to take him out hunting for the first time, and\r\nhe was half wild about it. The day came, and half an hour before Mr.\r\nEdmonstone was ready, Guy was walking about the hall, checking many an\r\nincipient whistle, and telling every one that he was beforehand with the\r\nworld, for he had read one extra hour yesterday, and had got through\r\nthe others before breakfast. Laura thought it very true that, as Philip\r\nsaid, he was only a boy, and moralized to Charlotte on his being the\r\nsame age as herself--very nearly eighteen. Mrs. Edmonstone told Charles\r\nit was a treat to see any one so happy, and when he began to chafe at\r\nthe delay, did her best to beguile the time, but without much success.\r\nGuy had ever learned to wait patiently, and had a custom of marching up\r\nand down, and listening with his head thrown back, or, as Charles used\r\nto call it, \xe2\x80\x98prancing in the hall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIf Mrs. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s patience was tried by the preparation for the hunt\r\nin the morning, it was no less her lot to hear of it in the evening. Guy\r\ncame home in the highest spirits, pouring out his delight to every one,\r\nwith animation and power of description giving all he said a charm. The\r\npleasure did not lose by repetition; he was more engrossed by it\r\nevery time; and no one could be more pleased with his ardour than Mr.\r\nEdmonstone, who, proud of him and his riding, gave a sigh to past hopes\r\nof poor Charles, and promoted the hunting with far more glee that he had\r\npromoted the reading.\r\n\r\nThe Redclyffe groom, William, whose surname of Robinson was entirely\r\nforgotten in the appellation of William of Deloraine, was as proud of\r\nSir Guy as Mr. Edmonstone could be; but made representations to his\r\nmaster that he must not hunt Deloraine two days in the week, and ride\r\nhim to Broadstone two more. Guy then walked to Broadstone; but\r\nWilliam was no better pleased, for he thought the credit of Redclyffe\r\ncompromised, and punished him by reporting Deloraine not fit to be\r\nused next hunting day. Mr. Edmonstone perceived that Guy ought to have\r\nanother hunter; Philip heard of one for sale, and after due inspection\r\nall admired--even William, who had begun by remarking that there might\r\nbe so many screw-looses about a horse, that a man did not know what to\r\nbe at with them.\r\n\r\nPhilip, who was conducting the negotiation, came to dine at Hollywell to\r\nsettle the particulars. Guy was in a most eager state; and they and Mr.\r\nEdmonstone talked so long about horses, that they sent Charles to sleep;\r\nhis mother began to read, and the two elder girls fell into a low,\r\nmysterious confabulation of their own till they were startled by a\r\nquestion from Philip as to what could engross them so deeply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98a banshee story in Eveleen de Courcy\xe2\x80\x99s last\r\nletter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never like telling ghost stories to people who don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in\r\nthem,\xe2\x80\x99 half whispered Amabel to her sister.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you believe them?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Philip, looking full at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now I won\xe2\x80\x99t have little Amy asked the sort of question she most\r\ndislikes,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Laura; \xe2\x80\x98I had rather ask if you laugh at us for\r\nthinking many ghost stories inexplicable?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The universal belief could hardly be kept up without some grounds,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That would apply as well to fairies,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Every one has an unexplained ghost story,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98but I would give something to meet any one whose\r\nghost story did not rest on the testimony of a friend\xe2\x80\x99s cousin\xe2\x80\x99s cousin,\r\na very strong-minded person.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine how a person who has seen a ghost could ever speak of\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you not tell us a story of pixies at Redclyffe?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O yes; the people there believe in them firmly. Jonas Ledbury heard\r\nthem laughing one night when he could not get the gate open,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! You are the authority for ghosts,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I forgot that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura: \xe2\x80\x98I wonder we never asked you about your\r\nRedclyffe ghost.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You look as if you had seen it yourself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have not?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Amy, almost frightened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, let us have the whole story,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98Was it your own\r\nreflection in the glass? was it old sir Hugh? or was it the murderer of\r\nBecket? Come, the ladies are both ready to scream at the right moment.\r\nNever mind about giving him a cocked-hat, for with whom may you take a\r\nliberty, if not with an ancestral ghost of your own?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy could not think how Philip could have gone on all this time; perhaps\r\nit was because he was not watching how Guy\xe2\x80\x99s colour varied, how he bit\r\nhis lip; and at last his eyes seemed to grow dark in the middle, and\r\nto sparkle with fire, as with a low, deep tone, like distant thunder,\r\nconveying a tremendous force of suppressed passion, he exclaimed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beware of trifling--\xe2\x80\x99 then breaking off hastened out of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr. Edmonstone, startled from his nap; and\r\nhis wife looked up anxiously, but returned to her book, as her nephew\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x98Nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How could you Philip?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really believe he has seen it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, in a startled whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has felt it, Amy--the Morville spirit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a great pity you spoke of putting a cocked hat to it,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nLaura; \xe2\x80\x98he must have suspected us of telling you what happened about\r\nMrs. Brownlow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And are you going to do it now?\xe2\x80\x99 said her sister in a tone of\r\nremonstrance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think Philip should hear it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; and she proceeded to relate\r\nthe story. She was glad to see that her cousin was struck with it;\r\nhe admired this care to maintain strict truth, and even opened a\r\nmemorandum-book--the sight of which Charles dreaded--and read the\r\nfollowing extract: \xe2\x80\x98Do not think of one falsity as harmless, and another\r\nas slight, and another as unintended. Cast them all aside. They may be\r\nlight and accidental, but they are an ugly soot from the smoke of the\r\npit, for all that; and it is better that our hearts should be swept\r\nclean of them, without over care as to which is the largest or\r\nblackest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura and Amy were much pleased; but he went on to regret that such\r\nexcellent dispositions should be coupled with such vehemence of\r\ncharacter and that unhappy temper. Amy was glad that her sister ventured\r\nto hint that he might be more cautious in avoiding collisions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am cautious\xe2\x80\x99, replied he, quickly and sternly; \xe2\x80\x98I am not to be told\r\nof the necessity of exercising forbearance with this poor boy; but it is\r\nimpossible to reckon on all the points on which he is sensitive.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is sensitive,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean only in temper, but in\r\neverything. I wonder if it is part of his musical temperament to be as\r\nkeenly alive to all around, as his ear is to every note. A bright day,\r\na fine view, is such real happiness to him; he dwells on every beauty of\r\nRedclyffe with such affection; and then, when he reads, Charles says it\r\nis like going over the story again himself to watch his face act it in\r\nthat unconscious manner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He makes all the characters so real in talking them over,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and he does not always know how they will end before they begin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think it hardly safe for so excitable a mind to dwell much on\r\nthe world of fiction,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing has affected him so much as Sintram,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98I never saw\r\nanything like it. He took it up by chance, and stood reading it while\r\nall those strange expressions began to flit over his face, and at last\r\nhe fairly cried over it so much, that he was obliged to fly out of the\r\nroom. How often he has read it I cannot tell; I believe he has bought\r\none for himself, and it is as if the engraving had a fascination for\r\nhim; he stands looking at it as if he was in a dream.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is a great mystery,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All men are mysterious,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip \xe2\x80\x98but he not more than others,\r\nthough he may appear so to you, because you have not had much\r\nexperience, and also because most of the men you have seen have been\r\nrounded into uniformity like marbles, their sharp angles rubbed off\r\nagainst each other at school.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would it be better if there were more sharp angles?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, thus\r\nsetting on foot a discussion on public schools, on which Philip had, of\r\ncourse, a great deal to say.\r\n\r\nAmy\xe2\x80\x99s kind little heart was meanwhile grieving for Guy, and longing to\r\nsee him return, but he did not come till after Philip\xe2\x80\x99s departure. He\r\nlooked pale and mournful, his hair hanging loose and disordered, and\r\nher terror was excited lest he might actually have seen his ancestor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nghost, which, in spite of her desire to believe in ghosts, in general,\r\nshe did not by any means wish to have authenticated. He was surprised\r\nand a good deal vexed to find Philip gone, but he said hardly anything,\r\nand it was soon bedtime. When Charles took his arm, he exclaimed, on\r\nfinding his sleeve wet--\xe2\x80\x98What can you have been doing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Walking up and down under the wall,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Guy, with some reluctance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What, in the rain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, perhaps it was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy, who was just behind, carrying the crutch, dreaded Charles\xe2\x80\x99s making\r\nany allusion to Sintram\xe2\x80\x99s wild locks and evening wanderings, but ever\r\nsince the outburst about King Charles, the desire to tease and irritate\r\nGuy had ceased.\r\n\r\nThey parted at the dressing-room door, and as Guy bade her good night,\r\nhe pushed back the damp hair that had fallen across his forehead,\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x98I am sorry I disturbed your evening. I will tell you the\r\nmeaning of it another time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has certainly seen the ghost!\xe2\x80\x99 said silly little Amy, as she shut\r\nherself into her own room in such a fit of vague \xe2\x80\x98eerie\xe2\x80\x99 fright, that it\r\nwas not till she had knelt down, and with her face hidden in her hands,\r\nsaid her evening prayer, that she could venture to lift up her head and\r\nlook into the dark corners of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Another time!\xe2\x80\x99 Her heart throbbed at the promise.\r\n\r\nThe next afternoon, as she and Laura were fighting with a refractory\r\nbranch of wisteria which had been torn down by the wind, and refused to\r\nreturn to its place, Guy, who had been with his tutor, came in from the\r\nstable-yard, reduced the trailing bough to obedience, and then joined\r\nthem in their walk. He looked grave, was silent at first, and then spoke\r\nabruptly--\xe2\x80\x98It is due to you to explain my behaviour last night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amy thinks you must have seen the ghost,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, trying to be gay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did I frighten you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, turning round, full of compunction.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no. I never saw it. I never even heard of its being seen. I am very\r\nsorry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was very silly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Guy, \xe2\x80\x98when I think of the origin of the ghost story, I\r\ncannot laugh, and if Philip knew all--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! He does not,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Laura; \xe2\x80\x98he only looks on it as we have always\r\ndone, as a sort of romantic appendage to Redclyffe. I should think\r\nbetter of a place for being haunted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I used to be proud of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98I wanted to make out whether it\r\nwas old Sir Hugh or the murderer of Becket, who was said to groan and\r\nturn the lock of Dark Hugh\xe2\x80\x99s chamber. I hunted among old papers, and a\r\nhorrible story I found. That wretched Sir Hugh,--the same who began the\r\nquarrel with your mother\xe2\x80\x99s family--he was a courtier of Charles II, as\r\nbad or worse than any of that crew--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What was the quarrel about?\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was believed to have either falsified or destroyed his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwill, so as to leave his brother, your ancestor, landless; his brother\r\nremonstrated, and he turned him out of doors. The forgery never was\r\nproved, but there was little doubt of it. There are traditions of his\r\ncrimes without number, especially his furious anger and malice. He\r\ncompelled a poor lady to marry him, though she was in love with another\r\nman; then he was jealous; he waylaid his rival, shut him up in the\r\nturret chamber, committed him to prison, and bribed Judge Jeffries\r\nto sentence him--nay it is even said he carried his wife to see the\r\nexecution! He was so execrated that he fled the country; he went to\r\nHolland, curried favour with William of Orange, brought his wealth to\r\nhelp him, and that is the deserving action which got him the baronetcy!\r\nHe served in the army a good many years, and came home when he thought\r\nhis sins would be forgotten. But do you remember those lines?\xe2\x80\x99 and Guy\r\nrepeated them in the low rigid tone, almost of horror, in which he had\r\nbeen telling the story:--\r\n\r\n\r\n                 \xe2\x80\x98On some his vigorous judgments light,\r\n                  In that dread pause \xe2\x80\x98twixt day and night,\r\n                      Life\xe2\x80\x99s closing twilight hour;\r\n                  Round some, ere yet they meet their doom,\r\n                  Is shed the silence of the tomb,\r\n                      The eternal shadows lower.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was so with him; he lost his senses, and after many actions of mad\r\nviolence, he ended by hanging himself in the very room where he had\r\nimprisoned his victim.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Horrible!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98Yet I do not see why, when it is all past, you\r\nshould feel it so deeply.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How should I not feel it?\xe2\x80\x99 answered Guy. \xe2\x80\x98Is it not written that the\r\nsins of the fathers shall be visited on the children? You wonder to\r\nsee me so foolish about Sintram. Well, it is my firm belief that such\r\na curse of sin and death as was on Sintram rests on the descendants of\r\nthat miserable man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe girls were silent, struck with awe and dismay at the fearful reality\r\nwith which he pronounced the words. At last, Amy whispered, \xe2\x80\x98But Sintram\r\nconquered his doom.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt the same time Laura gathered her thoughts together, and said, \xe2\x80\x98This\r\nmust be an imagination. My own\r\npoor father, with his early death, was, perhaps, the happiest!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura saw the idea was too deeply rooted to be treated as a fancy, and\r\nshe found a better argument. \xe2\x80\x98The doom of sin and death is on us all,\r\nbut you should remember that if you are a Morville, you are also a\r\nChristian.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He does remember it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, raising her eyes to his face, and then\r\ncasting them down, blushing at having understood his countenance, where,\r\nin the midst of the gloomy shades, there rested for an instant the gleam\r\nwhich her mother had likened to the expression of Raffaelle\xe2\x80\x99s cherub.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey walked on for some time in silence. At last Laura exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98Are\r\nyou really like the portrait of this unfortunate Sir Hugh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy made a sign of assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! It must have been taken before he grew wicked,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; and Laura\r\nfelt the same conviction, that treacherous revenge could never have\r\nexisted beneath so open a countenance, with so much of highmindedness,\r\npure faith and contempt of wrong in every glance of the eagle eye, in\r\nthe frank expansion of the smooth forehead.\r\n\r\nThey were interrupted by Mr. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s hearty voice, bawling across\r\nthe garden for one of the men. \xe2\x80\x98O Guy! are you there?\xe2\x80\x99 cried he, as\r\nsoon as he saw him. \xe2\x80\x98Just what I wanted! Your gun, man! We are going to\r\nferret a rabbit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy ran off at full speed in search of his gun, whistling to Bustle. Mr.\r\nEdmonstone found his man, and the sisters were again alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will not tell all this to Philip?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would show why he was hurt, and it can be no secret.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I dare say you are right, but I have a feeling against it. Well, I am\r\nglad he had not seen the ghost!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe two girls had taken their walk, and were just going in, when,\r\nlooking round, they saw Philip walking fast and determinedly up the\r\napproach, and as they turned back to meet him, the first thing he said\r\nwas, \xe2\x80\x98Where is Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ferreting rabbits with papa. What is the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And where is my aunt?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDriving out with Charles and Charlotte. What is the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here. Can you tell me the meaning of this which I found on my\r\ntable when I came in this morning?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was a card of Sir Guy Morville, on the back of which was written in\r\npencil, \xe2\x80\x98Dear P., I find hunting and reading don\xe2\x80\x99t agree, so take no\r\nfurther steps about the horse. Many thanks for your trouble.--G.M.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, \xe2\x80\x98is the result of brooding all night on his\r\nresentment.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Oh no!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Laura, colouring with eagerness, \xe2\x80\x98you do not\r\nunderstand him. He could not bear it last night, because, as he has been\r\nexplaining to us, that old Sir Hugh\xe2\x80\x99s story was more shocking than we\r\never guessed, and he has a fancy that their misfortunes are a family\r\nfate, and he could not bear to hear it spoken of lightly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! He has been telling you his own story, has he?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura\xe2\x80\x99s colour grew still deeper, \xe2\x80\x98If you had been there,\xe2\x80\x99 she said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98you would have been convinced. Why will you not believe that he finds\r\nhunting interfere with reading?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He should have thought of that before,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here have I half bought the horse! I have wasted the whole morning on\r\nit, and now I have to leave it on the man\xe2\x80\x99s hands. I had a dozen times\r\nrather take it myself, if I could afford it. Such a bargain as I had\r\nmade, and such an animal as you will not see twice in your life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a great pity,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura. \xe2\x80\x98He should have known his own mind. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like people to give trouble for nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Crazy about it last night, and giving it up this morning! A most\r\nextraordinary proceeding. No, no, Laura, this is not simple fickleness,\r\nit would be too absurd. It is temper, temper, which makes a man punish\r\nhimself, in hopes of punishing others.\r\n\r\nLaura still spoke for Guy, and Amy rejoiced; for if her sister had not\r\ntaken up the defence of the absent, she must, and she felt too strongly\r\nto be willing to speak. It seemed too absurd for one feeling himself\r\nunder such a doom to wrangle about a horse, yet she was somewhat amused\r\nby the conviction that if Guy had really wished to annoy Philip he had\r\ncertainly succeeded.\r\n\r\nThere was no coming to an agreement. Laura\xe2\x80\x99s sense of justice revolted\r\nat the notion of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s being guilty of petty spite; while Philip, firm\r\nin his preconceived idea of his character, and his own knowledge of\r\nmankind, was persuaded that he had imputed the true motive, and was\r\ndispleased at Laura\xe2\x80\x99s attempting to argue the point. He could not wait\r\nto see any one else, as he was engaged to dine out, and he set off again\r\nat his quick, resolute pace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is very unfair!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He did not mean to be so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98and though he is mistaken in\r\nimputing such motives, Guy\xe2\x80\x99s conduct has certainly been vexatious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey were just turning to go in, when they were interrupted by the\r\nreturn of the carriage; and before Charles had been helped up the steps,\r\ntheir father and Guy came in sight. While Guy went to shut up Bustle,\r\nwho was too wet for the drawing-room, Mr. Edmonstone came up to the\r\nothers, kicking away the pebbles before him, and fidgeting with his\r\ngloves, as he always did when vexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty go!\xe2\x80\x99 said he. \xe2\x80\x98Here is Guy telling me he won\xe2\x80\x99t hunt any\r\nmore!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not hunt!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs. Edmonstone and Charles at once; \xe2\x80\x98and why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! something about its taking his mind from his reading; but that\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t be it--impossible, you know; I\xe2\x80\x99d give ten pounds to know what has\r\nvexed him. So keen as he was about it last night, and I vow, one of the\r\nbest riders in the whole field. Giving up that horse, too--I declare\r\nit is a perfect sin! I told him he had gone too far, and he said he had\r\nleft a note with Philip this morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; Philip has just been here about it. Guy left a card,\r\nsaying, hunting and reading would not agree.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is an excuse, depend upon it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98Something has\r\nnettled him, I am sure. It could not be that Gordon, could it, with\r\nhis hail-fellow-well-met manner? I thought Guy did not half like it the\r\nother day, when he rode up with his \xe2\x80\x9cHollo, Morville!\xe2\x80\x9d The Morvilles\r\nhave a touch of pride of their own; eh, mamma?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be inclined to believe his own account of himself,\xe2\x80\x99 said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I tell you, \xe2\x80\x98tis utterly against reason,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone, angrily.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he was a fellow like Philip, or James Ross, I could believe it; but\r\nhe--he make a book-worm! He hates it, like poison, at the bottom of his\r\nheart, I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer for it; and the worst of it is, the fellow putting\r\nforward such a fair reason one can\xe2\x80\x99t--being his guardian, and all--say\r\nwhat one thinks of it oneself. Eh, mamma?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not exactly,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, you take him in hand, mamma. What could I have done to make him think so? I am angry with no one\r\nbut myself. The fact is only this, the hunting is too pleasant; it fills\r\nup my head all day and all night; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t attend rightly to anything\r\nelse. If I am out in the morning and try to pay for it at night, it will\r\nnot do; I can but just keep awake and that\xe2\x80\x99s all; the Greek letters all\r\nseem to be hunting each other, the simplest things grow difficult, and\r\nat last all I can think of, is how near the minute hand of my watch is\r\nnear to the hour I have set myself. Heigho! It is a great bore to be so stupid, for\r\nI thought--But it is of no use to talk of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Edmonstone would be a very unreasonable guardian, indeed, to be\r\ndispleased,\xe2\x80\x99 said his friend, smiling. You say you stopped the purchase\r\nof the horse. Why so? Could you not keep him till you are more sure of\r\nyourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think I might?\xe2\x80\x99 joyously exclaimed Guy. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll write to Philip\r\nthis minute by the post. I believe she was quite a child.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only seventeen when she died,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone went to a drawer, took out two or three bundles of\r\nold letters, and after searching in them by the fire-light, said--\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x99s a little about her; it is in a letter from my sister-in-law,\r\nPhilip\xe2\x80\x99s mother, when they were staying at Stylehurst.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who? She avoided the difficulty thus: \xe2\x80\x98It is hard\r\nto speak of such things when there is so much to be regretted on both\r\nsides; but the fact was, my brother thought your father was harshly\r\ndealt with at that time. Of course he had done very wrong; but he had\r\nbeen so much neglected and left to himself, that it seemed hardly\r\nfair to visit his offence on him as severely as if he had had more\r\nadvantages. So it ended in their coming to spend a day or two at\r\nStylehurst; and this is the letter my sister-in-law wrote at the time:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOur visitors have just left us, and on the whole I am much better\r\npleased than I expected. The little Mrs. Morville is a very pretty\r\ncreature, and as engaging as long flaxen curls, apple-blossom\r\ncomplexion, blue eyes, and the sweetest of voices can make her; so\r\nfull of childish glee and playfulness, that no one would stop to think\r\nwhether she was lady-like any more than you would with a child. She\r\nused to go singing like a bird about the house as soon as the first\r\nstrangeness wore off, which was after her first game of play with Fanny\r\nand Little Philip. She made them very fond of her, as indeed she would\r\nmake every one who spent a day or two in the same house with her. I\r\ncould almost defy Sir Guy not to be reconciled after one sight of\r\nher sweet sunny face. She is all affection and gentleness, and with\r\ntolerable training anything might be made of her; but she is so young\r\nin mind and manners, that one cannot even think of blaming her for her\r\nelopement, for she had no mother, no education but in music; and her\r\nbrother seems to have forced it on, thrown her in Mr. Morville\xe2\x80\x99s way,\r\nand worked on his excitable temperament, until he hurried them into\r\nmarriage. Poor little girl, I suppose she little guesses what she has\r\ndone; but it was very pleasant to see how devotedly attached he seemed\r\nto her; and there was something beautiful in the softening of his\r\nimpetuous tones when he said, \xe2\x80\x98Marianne;\xe2\x80\x99 and her pride in him was very\r\npretty, like a child playing at matronly airs.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy gave a long, heavy sigh, brushed away a tear, and after a long\r\nsilence, said, \xe2\x80\x98Is that all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All that I like to read to you. Indeed, there is no more about her;\r\nand it would be of no use to read all the reports that were going\r\nabout.--Ah! here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, looking into another letter,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98she speaks of your father as a very fine young man, with most generous\r\nimpulses,\xe2\x80\x99--but here again she was obliged to stop, for the next\r\nsentence spoke of \xe2\x80\x98a noble character ruined by mismanagement.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98She\r\nnever saw them again,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Dixon, your\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s brother, had great influence with your father, and made matters\r\nworse--so much worse, that my brother did not feel himself justified in\r\nhaving any more to do with them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! he went to America,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know any more about him\r\nexcept that he came to the funeral and stood with his arms folded, not\r\nchoosing to shake hands with my poor grandfather.\xe2\x80\x99 After another silence\r\nhe said, \xe2\x80\x98Will you read that again?\xe2\x80\x99 and when he had heard it, he sat\r\nshading his brow with his hand, as if to bring the fair, girlish picture\r\nfully before his mind, while Mrs. Edmonstone sought in vain among her\r\nletters for one which did not speak of the fiery passions ignited on\r\neither side, in terms too strong to be fit for his ears.\r\n\r\nWhen next he spoke it was to repeat that he had not been informed of\r\nthe history of his parents till within the last few months. He had,\r\nof course, known the manner of their death, but had only lately become\r\naware of the circumstances attending it.\r\n\r\nThe truth was that Guy had grown up peculiarly shielded from evil, but\r\nignorant of the cause of the almost morbid solicitude with which he was\r\nregarded by his grandfather. He was a very happy, joyous boy, leading\r\nan active, enterprising life, though so lonely as to occasion greater\r\ndreaminess and thoughtfulness than usual at such an early age. He was\r\ndevotedly attached to his grandfather, looking on him as the first and\r\nbest of human beings, and silencing the belief that Sir Hugh Morville\r\nhad entailed a doom of crime and sorrow on the family, by a reference to\r\nhim, as one who had been always good and prosperous.\r\n\r\nWhen, however, Guy had reached an age at which he must encounter the\r\ninfluences which had proved so baneful to others of his family, his\r\ngrandfather thought it time to give him the warning of his own history.\r\n\r\nThe sins, which the repentance of years had made more odious in the\r\neyes of the old man, were narrated; the idleness and insubordination\r\nat first, then the reckless pursuit of pleasure, the craving for\r\nexcitement, the defiance of rule and authority, till folly had become\r\nvice, and vice had led to crime.\r\n\r\nHe had fought no fewer than three duels, and only one had been\r\nbloodless. His misery after the first had well-nigh led to a reform;\r\nbut time had dulled its acuteness--it had been lost in fresh scenes\r\nof excitement--and at the next offence rage had swept away such\r\nrecollections. Indeed, so far had he lost the natural generosity of his\r\ncharacter, that his remorse had been comparatively slight for the last,\r\nwhich was the worst of all, since he had forced the quarrel on his\r\nvictim, Captain Wellwood, whose death had left a wife and children\r\nalmost destitute. His first awakening to a sense of what his course had\r\nbeen, was when he beheld his only child, in the prime of youth, carried\r\nlifeless across his threshold, and attributed his death to his own\r\nintemperance and violence. That hour made Sir Guy Morville an old and a\r\nbroken-hearted man; and he repented as vigorously as he had sinned.\r\n\r\nFrom the moment he dared to hope that his son\xe2\x80\x99s orphan would be spared,\r\nhe had been devoted to him, but still mournfully, envying and pitying\r\nhis innocence as something that could not last.\r\n\r\nHe saw bright blossoms put forth, as the boy grew older; but they were\r\nnot yet fruits, and he did not dare to believe they ever would be.\r\nThe strength of will which had, in his own case, been the slave of his\r\npassions, had been turned inward to subdue the passions themselves, but\r\nthis was only the beginning--the trial was not yet come. He could hope\r\nhis grandson might repent, but this was the best that he dared to think\r\npossible. He could not believe that a Morville could pass unscathed\r\nthrough the world, or that his sins would not be visited on the head of\r\nhis only descendant; and the tone of his narration was throughout such\r\nas might almost have made the foreboding cause its own accomplishment.\r\n\r\nThe effect was beyond what he had expected; for a soul deeply dyed\r\nin guilt, even though loathing its own stains, had not the power of\r\nconceiving how foul was the aspect of vice, to one hitherto guarded from\r\nits contemplation, and living in a world of pure, lofty day-dreams. The\r\nboy sat the whole time without a word, his face bent down and hidden\r\nby his clasped hands, only now and then unable to repress a start or\r\nshudder at some fresh disclosure; and when it was ended, he stood up,\r\ngazed round, and walked uncertainly, as if he did not know where he\r\nwas. His next impulse was to throw himself on his knee beside his\r\ngrandfather, and caress him as he used to when a child. The \xe2\x80\x98good-night\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwas spoken, and Guy was shut into his room, with his overwhelming\r\nemotions.\r\n\r\nHis grandfather a blood-stained, remorseful man! The doom was complete,\r\nhimself heir to the curse of Sir Hugh, and fated to run the same career;\r\nand as he knew full well, with the tendency to the family character\r\nstrong within him, the germs of these hateful passions ready to take\r\nroot downwards and bear fruit upwards, with the very countenance of Sir\r\nHugh, and the same darkening, kindling eyes, of which traditions had\r\npreserved the remembrance.\r\n\r\nHe was crushed for awhile. The consciousness of strength not his own,\r\nof the still small voice that could subdue the fire, the earthquake, and\r\nthe whirlwind, was slow in coming to him; and when it came, he, like his\r\ngrandfather, had hope rather of final repentance than of keeping himself\r\nunstained.\r\n\r\nHis mind had not recovered the shock when his grandfather died,--died\r\nin faith and fear, with good hope of accepted repentance, but unable to\r\nconvey the assurance of such hope to his grandson. Grief for the only\r\nparent he had ever known, and the sensation of being completely alone in\r\nthe world, were joined to a vague impression of horror at the suddenness\r\nof the stroke, and it was long before the influence of Hollywell, or the\r\nelasticity of his own youthfulness, could rouse him from his depression.\r\n\r\nEven then it was almost against his will that he returned to enjoyment,\r\nunable to avoid being amused, but feeling as if joy was not meant for\r\nhim, and as if those around were walking \xe2\x80\x98in a world of light,\xe2\x80\x99 where he\r\ncould scarcely hope to tread a few uncertain steps. In this despondency\r\nwas Guy\xe2\x80\x99s chief danger, as it was likely to make him deem a struggle\r\nwith temptation fruitless, while his high spirits and powers of keen\r\nenjoyment increased the peril of recklessness in the reaction.\r\n\r\nIt was Mrs. Edmonstone who first spoke with him cheerfully of\r\na successful conflict with evil, and made him perceive that his\r\ntemptations were but such as is common to man. She had given him a clue\r\nto discover when and how to trust himself to enjoy; the story of Sintram\r\nhad stirred him deeply, and this very day, Amy\xe2\x80\x99s words, seemingly\r\nunheeded and unheard, had brought home to him the hope and encouragement\r\nof that marvellous tale.\r\n\r\nThey had helped him in standing, looking steadfastly upwards, and\r\ntreading down not merely evil, but the first token of coming evil,\r\nregardless of the bruises he might inflict on himself. Well for him if\r\nhe was constant.\r\n\r\nSuch was Guy\xe2\x80\x99s inner life; his outward life, frank and joyous, has been\r\nshown, and the two flowed on like a stream, pure as crystal, but into\r\nwhich the eye cannot penetrate from its depth. The surface would be\r\nsometimes obscured by cloud or shade, and reveal the sombre wells\r\nbeneath; but more often the sunshine would penetrate the inmost\r\nrecesses, and make them glance and sparkle, showing themselves as clear\r\nand limpid as the surface itself.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 6\r\n\r\n      Can piety the discord heal,\r\n      Or stanch the death-feud\xe2\x80\x99s enmity?\r\n                                --Scott\r\n\r\n\r\nIt must not be supposed that such a history of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s mind was expressed\r\nby himself, or understood by Mrs. Edmonstone; but she saw enough to\r\nguess at his character, perceive the sort of guidance he needed, and be\r\ndoubly interested in him. Much did she wish he could have such a friend\r\nas her brother would have been, and hope that nothing would prevent a\r\nfriendship with her nephew.\r\n\r\nThe present question about the horse was, she thought, unfortunate,\r\nsince, though Guy had exercised great self-denial, it was no wonder\r\nPhilip was annoyed. Mr. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s vexation was soon over. As soon as\r\nshe had persuaded him that there had been no offence, he strove to say\r\nwith a good grace, that it was very proper, and told Guy he would be\r\na thorough book-worm and tremendous scholar, which Guy took as an\r\nexcellent joke.\r\n\r\nPhilip had made up his mind to be forbearing, and to say no more about\r\nit. Laura thought this a pity, as they could thus never come to an\r\nunderstanding; but when she hinted it, he wore such a dignified air of\r\nnot being offended, that she was much ashamed of having tried to direct\r\none so much better able to judge. On his side Guy had no idea the\r\ntrouble he had caused; so, after bestowing his thanks in a gay, off-hand\r\nway, which Philip thought the worst feature of the case, he did his best\r\nto bring Hecuba back into his mind, drive the hunters out of it, and\r\nappease the much-aggrieved William of Deloraine.\r\n\r\nWhen all William\xe2\x80\x99s manoeuvres resulted in his master\xe2\x80\x99s not hunting at\r\nall, he was persuaded it was Mr. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s fault, compassionated\r\nSir Guy with all his heart, and could only solace himself by taking\r\nDeloraine to exercise where he was most likely to meet the hounds. He\r\nfurther chose to demonstrate that he was not Mr. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s servant,\r\nby disregarding some of his stable regulations; but as soon as this came\r\nto his master\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge, a few words were spoken so sharp and stern,\r\nthat William never attempted to disobey again.\r\n\r\nIt seemed as if it was the perception that so much was kept back by a\r\nstrong force, that made Guy\xe2\x80\x99s least token of displeasure so formidable.\r\nA village boy, whom he caught misusing a poor dog, was found a few\r\nminutes after, by Mr. Ross, in a state of terror that was positively\r\nludicrous, though it did not appear that Sir Guy had said or done much\r\nto alarm him; it was only the light in his eyes, and the strength\r\nof repressed indignation in his short broken words that had made the\r\nimpression.\r\n\r\nIt appeared as if the force of his anger might be fearful, if once it\r\nbroke forth without control; yet at the same time he had a gentleness\r\nand attention, alike to small and great, which, with his high spirit\r\nand good nature, his very sweet voice and pleasant smile, made him a\r\npeculiarly winning and engaging person; and few who saw him could help\r\nbeing interested in him.\r\n\r\nNo wonder he had become in the eyes of the Edmonstones almost a part of\r\ntheir family. Mrs. Edmonstone had assumed a motherly control over him,\r\nto which he submitted with a sort of affectionate gratitude.\r\n\r\nOne day Philip remarked, that he never saw any one so restless as\r\nGuy, who could neither talk nor listen without playing with something.\r\nScissors, pencil, paper-knife, or anything that came in his way, was\r\nsure to be twisted or tormented; or if nothing else was at hand, he\r\nopened and shut his own knife so as to put all the spectators in fear\r\nfor his fingers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98I saw how it tortured your eyebrows all the time you\r\nwere translating Schiller to us. I wondered you were not put out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I consider that to be put out--by which you mean to have the intellect\r\nat the mercy of another\xe2\x80\x99s folly--is beneath a reasonable creature,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Philip; \xe2\x80\x98but that I was annoyed, I do not deny. It is a token of a\r\nrestless, ill-regulated mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Restless, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone \xe2\x80\x98but not necessarily\r\nill-regulated. I should think it rather a sign that he had no one to\r\ntell him of the tricks which mothers generally nip in the bud.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was going to say that I think he fidgets less,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98but I\r\nthink his chief contortions of the scissors have been when Philip has\r\nbeen here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They have, I believe,\xe2\x80\x99 said her mother, I was thinking of giving him a\r\nhint.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, aunt, you are a tamer of savage beasts if you venture on such a\r\nsubject,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you dare me?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, I don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose he would do more than give you one of his\r\nlightning glances: but that, I think, is more than you desire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Considerably,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98for his sake as much as my own.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98mamma has nearly cured him of pawing like a horse in\r\nthe hall when he is kept waiting. He said he knew it was impatience,\r\nand begged her to tell him how to cure it. So she treated him as an old\r\nfairy might, and advised him in a grave, mysterious way, always to go\r\nand play the \xe2\x80\x9cHarmonious Blacksmith,\xe2\x80\x9d when he found himself getting\r\ninto \xe2\x80\x9ca taking\xe2\x80\x9d, just as if it was a charm. And he always does it most\r\ndutifully.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It has a very good effect,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98for it is apt to act\r\nas a summons to the other party, as well as a sedative to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must say I am curious to see what you will devise this time,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nPhilip; \xe2\x80\x98since you can\xe2\x80\x99t set him to play on the piano; and very few can\r\nbear to be told of a trick of the kind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn the course of that evening, Philip caused the great atlas to be\r\nbrought out in order to make investigations on the local habitation of\r\na certain Khan of Kipchack, who existed somewhere in the dark ages. Then\r\nhe came to Marco Polo, and Sir John Mandeville; and Guy, who knew both\r\nthe books in the library at Redclyffe, grew very eager in talking them\r\nover, and tracing their adventures--then to the Genoese merchants, where\r\nGuy confessed himself perfectly ignorant. Andrea Doria was the only\r\nGenoese he ever heard of; but he hunted out with great interest all the\r\nlocalities of their numerous settlements. Then came modern Italy, and\r\nits fallen palaces; then the contrast between the republican merchant\r\nand aristocratic lord of the soil; then the corn laws; and then, and not\r\ntill then, did Philip glance at his aunt, to show her Guy balancing a\r\nVenetian weight on as few of his fingers as could support it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, smiling, \xe2\x80\x98does that unfortunate glass inspire you with\r\nany arguments in favour of the Venetians?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy put it down at once, and Philip proceeded to improved methods of\r\nfarming, to enable landlords to meet the exigencies of the times. Guy\r\nhad got hold of Mr. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s spectacle-case, and was putting its\r\nspring to a hard trial. Mrs. Edmonstone doubted whether to interfere\r\nagain; she knew this was not the sort of thing that tried his temper,\r\nyet she particularly disliked playing him off, as it were for Philip\xe2\x80\x99s\r\namusement, and quite as much letting him go on, and lower himself in her\r\nnephew\xe2\x80\x99s estimation. The spectacle-case settled the matter--a crack was\r\nheard, it refused to snap at all; and Guy, much discomfited, made many\r\napologies.\r\n\r\nAmy laughed; Philip was much too well-bred to do anything but curl his\r\nlip unconsciously. Mrs. Edmonstone waited till he was gone, then, when\r\nshe was wishing Guy \xe2\x80\x98good-night\xe2\x80\x99 at Charles\xe2\x80\x99s door, she said,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The spectacle-case forestalled me in giving you a lecture on sparing\r\nour nerves. Don\xe2\x80\x99t look so very full of compunction--it is only a trick\r\nwhich your mother would have stopped at five years old, and which you\r\ncan soon stop for yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, I will!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98I hardly knew I did it, but I am very\r\nsorry it has teased you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThenceforward it was curious to see how he put down and pushed away all\r\nhe had once begun to touch and torture. Mrs. Edmonstone said it was\r\nself command in no common degree; and Philip allowed that to cure so\r\ninveterate a habit required considerable strength of will.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98I always gave the Morvilles credit for an iron\r\nresolution. Yes, Amy, you may laugh; but if a man is not resolute in a\r\nlittle, he will never be resolute in great matters.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And Guy has been resolute the right way this time,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98May he always be the same,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\nPhilip had undertaken, on his way back to Broadstone, to conduct\r\nCharlotte to East-hill, where she was to spend the day with a little\r\nniece of Mary Ross. She presently came down, her bonnet-strings tied\r\nin a most resolute-looking bow, and her little figure drawn up so as to\r\nlook as womanly is possible for her first walk alone with Philip. She\r\nwished the party at home \xe2\x80\x98goodbye;\xe2\x80\x99 and as Amy and Laura stood watching\r\nher, they could not help laughing to see her tripping feet striving to\r\nkeep step, her blue veil discreetly composed and her little head turned\r\nup, as if she was trying hard to be on equal terms with the tall cousin,\r\nwho meanwhile looked graciously down from his height, patronising her\r\nlike a very small child. After some space, Amy began to wonder what\r\nthey could talk about, or whether they would talk at all; but Laura said\r\nthere was no fear of Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s tongue ever being still, and Charles\r\nrejoined,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that Philip considers it due to himself that his\r\naudience should never be without conversation suited to their capacity?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense, Charlie!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nay, I give him credit for doing it as well as it is in nature of\r\nthings for it to be done. The strongest proof I know of his being a\r\nsuperior man, is the way he adapts himself to his company. He lays down\r\nthe law to us, because he knows we are all born to be his admirers; he\r\ncalls Thorndale his dear fellow and conducts him like a Mentor; but\r\nyou may observe how different he is with other people--Mr. Ross, for\r\ninstance. It is not showing off; it is just what the pattern hero should\r\nbe with the pattern clergyman. At a dinner party he is quite in his\r\nplace; contents himself with leaving an impression on his neighbour that\r\nMr. Morville is at home on every subject; and that he is the right thing\r\nwith his brother officers is sufficiently proved, since not even Maurice\r\neither hates or quizzes him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Charlie,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, well pleased, I am glad you are convinced\r\nat last.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think I ever wanted to be convinced that we were created for\r\nno other end than to applaud Philip? I was fulfilling the object of our\r\nexistence by enlarging on a remark of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s, that nothing struck him\r\nmore than the way in which Philip could adapt his conversation to the\r\nhearers. So the hint was not lost on me; and I came to the conclusion\r\nthat it was a far greater proof of his sense than all the maxims he\r\nlavishes on us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder Guy was the person to make the remark,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98for it is\r\nstrange that those two never appear to the best advantage together.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Laura, that would be the very reason,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The very reason?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. Draw out your meaning, Miss.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, colouring, \xe2\x80\x98If Guy--if a generous person, I mean--were\r\nvexed with another sometimes, it would be the very reason he would make\r\nthe most of all his goodness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Heigh-ho!\xe2\x80\x99 yawned Charles. What o\xe2\x80\x99clock is it? I wonder when Guy is\r\never coming back from that Lascelles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your wonder need not last long,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98for I see him riding into\r\nthe stable yard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn a few minutes he had entered; and, on being asked if he had met\r\nPhilip and Charlotte, and how they were getting on, he replied,--\xe2\x80\x98A good\r\ndeal like the print of Dignity and Impudence,\xe2\x80\x99 at the same time throwing\r\nback his shoulders, and composing his countenance to imitate Philip\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlofty deportment and sedate expression, and the next moment putting his\r\nhead on one side with a sharp little nod, and giving a certain espiegle\r\nglance of the eye, and knowing twist of one corner of the mouth, just\r\nlike Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By the by,\xe2\x80\x99 added he, \xe2\x80\x98would Philip have been a clergyman if he had\r\ngone to Oxford?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it was settled,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98Why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I could never fancy him one\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98He would not have been what\r\nhe is now if he had gone to Oxford,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98He would have lived\r\nwith men of the same powers and pursuits with himself, and have found\r\nhis level.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And that would have been a very high one,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would; but there would be all the difference there is between a\r\nfeudal prince and an Eastern despot. He would know what it is to live\r\nwith his match.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you don\xe2\x80\x99t attempt to call him conceited!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy, with a sort of\r\nconsternation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is far above that; far too grand,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should as soon think of calling Jupiter conceited,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; and\r\nLaura did not know how far to be gratified, or otherwise.\r\n\r\nCharles had not over-estimated Philip\xe2\x80\x99s readiness of self adaptation.\r\nCharlotte had been very happy with him, talking over the \xe2\x80\x9cLady of the\r\nLake\xe2\x80\x9d, which she had just read, and being enlightened, partly to\r\nher satisfaction, partly to her disappointment, as to how much was\r\nhistorical. He listened good-naturedly to a fit of rapture, and threw in\r\na few, not too many, discreet words of guidance to the true principles\r\nof taste; and next told her about an island, in a pond at Stylehurst,\r\nwhich had been by turns Ellen\xe2\x80\x99s isle and Robinson Crusoe\xe2\x80\x99s. It was at\r\nthis point in the conversation that Guy came in sight, riding slowly,\r\nhis reins on his horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck, whistling a slow, melancholy tune, his\r\neyes fixed on the sky, and so lost in musings, that he did not perceive\r\nthem till Philip arrested him by calling out, \xe2\x80\x98That is a very bad plan.\r\nNo horse is to be trusted in that way, especially such a spirited one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGuy started, and gathered up his reins, owning it was foolish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You look only half disenchanted yet,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98Has Lascelles put\r\nyou into what my father\xe2\x80\x99s old gardener used to call a stud?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing so worthy of a stud,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, smiling and colouring a little.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was only dreaming over a picture of ruin--\r\n\r\n\r\n                 \xe2\x80\x98The steed is vanish\xe2\x80\x99d from the stall,\r\n                  No serf is seen in Hassan\xe2\x80\x99s hall,\r\n                  The lonely spider\xe2\x80\x99s thin grey pall\r\n                  Waves, slowly widening o\xe2\x80\x99er the wall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Byron!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Philip. \xe2\x80\x98I hope you are not dwelling on him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only a volume I found in my room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, the \xe2\x80\x9cGiaour\xe2\x80\x9d!\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98Well, there is no great damage done;\r\nbut it is bad food for excitable minds. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let it get hold of you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well;\xe2\x80\x99 and there was a cloud, but it cleared in a moment, and,\r\nwith a few gay words to both, he rode off at a quick pace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Foolish fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Philip, looking after him.\r\n\r\nAfter some space of silence, Charlotte began in a very grave tone--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnother \xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 and another long pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Philip, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether you\xe2\x80\x99ll be angry with me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, marvelling at what was coming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Guy says he does not want to keep up the feud, and I wish you would\r\nnot.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The deadly feud!\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What nonsense is this?\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely--Oh Philip, there always was a deadly feud between our\r\nancestors, and the Redclyffe Morvilles, and it was very wrong, and ought\r\nnot to be kept up now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is not I that keep it up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it not?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte. \xe2\x80\x98But I am sure you don\xe2\x80\x99t like Guy. And I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t think why not, unless it is the deadly feud, for we are all so\r\nfond of him. Laura says it is a different house since he came.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hum!\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98Charlotte, you did well to make me promise not to\r\nbe angry with you, by which, I presume, you mean displeased. I should\r\nlike to know what put this notion into your head.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Charlie told me,\xe2\x80\x99 almost whispered Charlotte, hanging down her head.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And--and--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what? I can\xe2\x80\x99t hear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharlotte was a good deal frightened; but either from firmness, or from\r\nthe female propensity to have the last word, or it might be the spirit\r\nof mischief, she got out--\xe2\x80\x98You have made me quite sure of it yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was so alarmed at having said this, that had it not been\r\nundignified, she would have run quite away, and never stopped till\r\nshe came to East-hill. Matters were not mended when Philip said\r\nauthoritatively, and as if he was not in the least bit annoyed (which\r\nwas the more vexatious), \xe2\x80\x98What do you mean, Charlotte?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe had a great mind to cry, by way of getting out of the scrape; but\r\nhaving begun as a counsellor and peacemaker, it would never do to be\r\nbabyish; and on his repeating the question, she said, in a tone which\r\nshe could not prevent from being lachrymose, \xe2\x80\x98You make Guy almost angry,\r\nyou tease him, and when people praise him, you answer as if it would not\r\nlast! And it is very unfair of you,\xe2\x80\x99 concluded she, with almost a sob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Charlotte,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Philip, much more kindly than she thought she\r\ndeserved, after the reproach that seemed to her so dreadfully naughty,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98you may dismiss all fear of deadly feud, whatever you may mean by it.\r\nCharles has been playing tricks on you. You know, my little cousin, that\r\nI am a Christian, and we live in the nineteenth century.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharlotte felt as if annihilated at the aspect of her own folly. He\r\nresumed--\xe2\x80\x98You misunderstood me. I do think Guy very agreeable. He is\r\nvery attentive to Charles, very kind to you, and so attractive, that I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t wonder you like him. But those who are older than you see that he\r\nhas faults, and we wish to set him on his guard against them. It may be\r\npainful to ourselves, and irritating to him, but depend upon it, it is\r\nthe proof of friendship. Are you satisfied, my little cousin?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe could only say humbly, \xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You need not ask pardon. Since you had the notion, it was right to\r\nspeak, as it was to me, one of your own family. When you are older, you\r\nneed never fear to speak out in the right place. I am glad you have\r\nso much of the right sort of feminine courage, though in this case you\r\nmight have ventured to trust to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo ended Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s anxieties respecting the deadly feud, and she had\r\nnow to make up her mind to the loss of her playfellow, who was to go to\r\nOxford at Easter, when he would be just eighteen, his birthday being the\r\n28th of March. Both her playmates were going, Bustle as well as Guy, and\r\nit was at first proposed that Deloraine should go too, but Guy bethought\r\nhimself that Oxford would be a place of temptation for William; and not\r\nchoosing to trust the horse to any one else, resolved to leave both at\r\nHollywell.\r\n\r\nHis grandfather had left an allowance for Guy, until his coming of age,\r\nsuch as might leave no room for extravagance, and which even Philip\r\npronounced to be hardly sufficient for a young man in his position. \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nknow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr. Edmonstone, in his hesitating, good-natured way, \xe2\x80\x98if\r\never you have occasion sometimes for a little--a little more--you need\r\nonly apply to me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, anything rather than run into debt.\r\nYou know me, and \xe2\x80\x98tis your own.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This shall do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, in the same tone as he had fixed his hours of\r\nstudy.\r\n\r\nEach of the family made Guy a birthday present, as an outfit for Oxford;\r\nMr. Edmonstone gave him a set of studs, Mrs. Edmonstone a Christian\r\nYear, Amabel copied some of his favourite songs, Laura made a drawing\r\nof Sintram, Charlotte worked a kettle-holder, with what was called by\r\ncourtesy a likeness of Bustle. Charles gave nothing, professing that he\r\nwould do nothing to encourage his departure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t know what a bore it is to lose the one bit of quicksilver in\r\nthe house!\xe2\x80\x99 said he, yawning. \xe2\x80\x98I shall only drag on my existence till\r\nyou come back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You, Charles, the maker of fun!\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, amazed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a case of flint and steel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98but be it owing to who\r\nit will, we have been alive since you came here. You have taken care\r\nto be remembered. We have been studying you, or laughing at you, or\r\nwondering what absurdity was to come next.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very sorry--that is, if you are serious. I hoped at least I\r\nappeared like other people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what you appear like. Just what I would be if I was a\r\nfree man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never say that, Charlie!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nay, wait a bit. I would never be so foolish. I would never give my\r\nsunny mornings to Euripides; I would not let the best hunter in the\r\ncounty go when I had wherewithal to pay for him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would not have such an ill-conditioned self to keep in rule.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98After all,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Charles, yawning, \xe2\x80\x98it is no great compliment to\r\nsay I am sorry you are going. If you were an Ethiopian serenader, you\r\nwould be a loss to me. It is something to see anything beyond this old\r\ndrawing-room, and the same faces doing the same things every day. Laura\r\npoking over her drawing, and meditating upon the last entry in Philip\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmemorandum-book, and Amy at her flowers or some nonsense or other,\r\nand Charlotte and the elders all the same, and a lot of stupid people\r\ndropping in and a lot of stupid books to read, all just alike. I can\r\ntell what they are like without looking in!\xe2\x80\x99 Charles yawned again,\r\nsighed, and moved wearily. \xe2\x80\x98Now, there came some life and freshness with\r\nyou. You talk of Redclyffe, and your brute creation there, not like\r\na book, and still less like a commonplace man; you are innocent and\r\nunsophisticated, and take new points of view; you are something to\r\ninterest oneself about; your coming in is something to look forward\r\nto; you make the singing not such mere milk-and-water, your reading the\r\nPraelectiones is an additional landmark to time; besides the mutton of\r\nto-day succeeding the beef of yesterday. Heigh-ho! I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what,\r\nGuy. Though I may carry it off with a high hand, \xe2\x80\x98tis no joke to be\r\na helpless log all the best years of a man\xe2\x80\x99s life,--nay, for my whole\r\nlife,--for at the very best of the contingencies the doctors are always\r\nflattering me with, I should make but a wretched crippling affair of it.\r\nAnd if that is the best hope they give me, you may guess it is likely to\r\nbe a pretty deal worse. Hope? I\xe2\x80\x99ve been hoping these ten years, and much\r\ngood has it done me. I say, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 he proceeded, in a tone of extreme\r\nbitterness, though with a sort of smile, \xe2\x80\x98the only wonder is that I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t hate the very sight of you! There are times when I feel as if I\r\ncould bite some men,--that Tomfool Maurice de Courcy, for instance, when\r\nI hear him rattling on, and think--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know I have often talked thoughtlessly, I have feared afterwards I\r\nmight have given you pain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, you never have; you have carried me along with you. I like\r\nnothing better than to hear of your ridings, and shootings, and\r\nboatings. It is a sort of life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles had never till now alluded seriously to his infirmity before\r\nGuy, and the changing countenance of his auditor showed him to be\r\nmuch affected, as he stood leaning over the end of the sofa, with his\r\nspeaking eyes earnestly fixed on Charles, who went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now you are going to Oxford. You will take your place among the men\r\nof your day. You will hear and be heard of. You will be somebody. And\r\nI!--I know I have what they call talent--I could be something. They\r\nthink me an idle dog; but where\xe2\x80\x99s the good of doing anything? I only\r\nknow if I was not--not condemned to--to this--this life,\xe2\x80\x99 (had it not\r\nbeen for a sort of involuntary respect to the gentle compassion of the\r\nsoftened hazel eyes regarding him so kindly, he would have used the\r\nviolent expletive that trembled on his lip;) \xe2\x80\x98if I was not chained down\r\nhere, Master Philip should not stand alone as the paragon of the family.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve as much mother wit as he.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That you have,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98How fast you see the sense of a passage. You\r\ncould excel very much if you only tried.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tried?\xe2\x80\x99 And what am I to gain by it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that one ought to let talents rust,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy,\r\nthoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x98I suppose it is one\xe2\x80\x99s duty not; and surely it is a pity\r\nto give up those readings.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall not get such another fellow dunce as you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98as I\r\ntold you when we began, and it would be a mere farce to do it alone. I\r\ncould not make myself, if I would.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t you make yourself do what you please?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, as if it was the\r\nsimplest thing in the world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit, if the other half of me does not like it. I forget it, or\r\nput it off, and it comes to nothing. I do declare, though, I would get\r\nsomething to break my mind on, merely as a medical precaution, just to\r\nfreshen myself up, if I could find any one to do it with. No, nothing in\r\nthe shape of a tutor, against that I protest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your sisters,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hum\xe2\x80\x99! Laura is too intellectual already, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to poach on\r\nPhilip\xe2\x80\x99s manor; and if I made little Amy cease to be silly, I should do\r\naway with all the comfort I have left me in life. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, though,\r\nif she swallowed learning after Mary Ross\xe2\x80\x99s pattern, that it need do her\r\nmuch harm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy came into the room at the moment. \xe2\x80\x98Amy, here is Guy advising me to\r\ntake you to read something awfully wise every day, something that will\r\nmake you as dry as a stick, and as blue--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a gentianella,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should not mind being like a gentianella,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98But what\r\ndreadful thing were you setting him to do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To make you read all the folios in my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s old library,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nCharles. \xe2\x80\x98All that Margaret has in keeping against Philip has a house of\r\nhis own.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sancho somebody, and all you talked of when first you came?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We were talking of the hour\xe2\x80\x99s reading that Charlie and I have had\r\ntogether lately,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was thinking how Charlie would miss that hour,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; \xe2\x80\x98and we\r\nshall be very sorry not to have you to listen to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then, Amy, suppose you read with me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Charlie, thank you! Should you really like it?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Amy,\r\ncolouring with delight. \xe2\x80\x98I have always thought it would be so very\r\ndelightful if you would read with me, as James Ross used with Mary, only\r\nI was afraid of tiring you with my stupidity. Oh, thank you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo it was settled, and Charles declared that he put himself on honour to\r\ngive a good account of their doings to Guy, that being the only way of\r\nmaking himself steady to his resolution; but he was perfectly determined\r\nnot to let Philip know anything about the practice he had adopted,\r\nsince he would by no means allow him to guess that he was following his\r\nadvice.\r\n\r\nCharles had certainly grown very fond of Guy, in spite of his propensity\r\nto admire Philip, satisfying himself by maintaining that, after all, Guy\r\nonly tried to esteem his cousin because he thought it a point of duty,\r\njust as children think it right to admire the good boy in a story book;\r\nbut that he was secretly fretted and chafed by his perfection. No one\r\ncould deny that there were often occasions when little misunderstandings\r\nwould arise, and that, but for Philip\xe2\x80\x99s coolness and Guy\xe2\x80\x99s readiness to\r\napologise they might often have gone further; but at the same time no\r\none could regret these things more than Guy himself, and he was willing\r\nand desirous to seek Philip\xe2\x80\x99s advice and assistance when needed. In\r\nespecial, he listened earnestly to the counsel which was bestowed on him\r\nabout Oxford: and Mrs. Edmonstone was convinced that no one could have\r\nmore anxiety to do right and avoid temptation. She had many talks\r\nwith him in her dressing-room, promising to write to him, as did also\r\nCharles; and he left Hollywell with universal regrets, most loudly\r\nexpressed by Charlotte, who would not be comforted without a lock of\r\nBustle\xe2\x80\x99s hair, which she would have worn round her neck if she had not\r\nbeen afraid that Laura would tell Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He goes with excellent intentions,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, as they watched him\r\nfrom the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do hope he will do well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish he may,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98the agreeableness of his whole character\r\nmakes one more anxious. It is very dangerous. His name, his wealth, his\r\nsociable, gay disposition, that very attractive manner, all are so many\r\nperils, and he has not that natural pleasure in study that would be of\r\nitself a preservative from temptation. However, he is honestly anxious\r\nto do right, and has excellent principles. I only fear his temper and\r\nhis want of steadiness. Poor boy, I hope he may do well!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 7\r\n\r\n                    --Pray, good shepherd, what\r\n      Fair swain is this that dances with your daughter?\r\n        *         *         *         *          *\r\n      He sings several times faster than you\xe2\x80\x99ll tell money;\r\n      he utters them as he had eaten ballads, and all men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      ears grow to his tunes.\r\n                                  --WINTER\xe2\x80\x99S TALE\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was a glorious day in June, the sky of pure deep dazzling blue, the\r\nsunshine glowing with brightness, but with cheerful freshness in the\r\nair that took away all sultriness, the sun tending westward in his\r\nlong day\xe2\x80\x99s career, and casting welcome shadows from the tall firs and\r\nhorse-chestnuts that shaded the lawn. A long rank of haymakers--men\r\nand women--proceeded with their rakes, the white shirt-sleeves, straw\r\nbonnets, and ruddy faces, radiant in the bath of sunshine, while in the\r\nshady end of the field were idler haymakers among the fragrant piles,\r\nCharles half lying on the grass, with his back against a tall haycock;\r\nMrs. Edmonstone sitting on another, book in hand; Laura sketching the\r\nbusy scene, the sun glancing through the chequered shade on her glossy\r\ncurls; Philip stretched out at full length, hat and neck-tie off,\r\nluxuriating in the cool repose after a dusty walk from Broadstone; and a\r\nlittle way off, Amabel and Charlotte pretending to make hay, but really\r\nbuilding nests with it, throwing it at each other, and playing as\r\nheartily as the heat would allow.\r\n\r\nThey talked and laughed, the rest were too hot, too busy, or too sleepy\r\nfor conversation, even Philip being tired into enjoying the \xe2\x80\x9cdolce far\r\nniente\xe2\x80\x9d; and they basked in the fresh breezy heat and perfumy hay with\r\nonly now and then a word, till a cold, black, damp nose was suddenly\r\nthrust into Charles\xe2\x80\x99s face, a red tongue began licking him; and at the\r\nsame moment Charlotte, screaming \xe2\x80\x98There he is!\xe2\x80\x99 raced headlong across\r\nthe swarths of hay, to meet Guy, who had just ridden into the field.\r\nHe threw Deloraine\xe2\x80\x99s rein to one of the haymakers, and came bounding to\r\nmeet her, just in time to pick her up as she put her foot into a hidden\r\nhole, and fell prostrate.\r\n\r\nIn another moment he was in the midst of the whole party, who crowded\r\nround and welcomed him as if he had been a boy returning from his\r\nfirst half-year\xe2\x80\x99s schooling; and never did little school-boy look more\r\nholiday-like than he, with all the sunshine of that June day reflected,\r\nas it were, in his glittering eyes and glowing face, while Bustle\r\nescaping from Charles\xe2\x80\x99s caressing arm, danced round, wagging his tail\r\nin ecstasy, and claiming his share of the welcome. Then Guy was on\r\nthe ground by Charles, rejoicing to find him out there, and then, some\r\ndropping into their former nests on the hay, some standing round, they\r\ntalked fast and eagerly in a confusion of sound that did not subside for\r\nthe first ten minutes so as to allow anything to be clearly heard. The\r\nfirst distinct sentence was Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Bustle, darling old fellow, you\r\nare handsomer than ever!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a delicious day!\xe2\x80\x99 next exclaimed Guy, following Philip\xe2\x80\x99s example,\r\nby throwing off hat and neck-tie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A spontaneous tribute to the beauty of the day,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really it is so ultra-splendid as to deserve notice!\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip,\r\nthrowing himself completely back, and looking up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One cannot help revelling in that deep blue!\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99ll be the happiest time of all the glad new year,\xe2\x80\x99 hummed Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah you will teach us all now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, \xe2\x80\x98after your grand singing\r\nlessons.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know what is in store for you, Guy?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98Oh! haven\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nheard about Lady Kilcoran\xe2\x80\x99s ball?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are to go, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte. \xe2\x80\x98I am glad I am not. I hate\r\ndancing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I know as much about it as Bustle,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, catching the dog by\r\nhis forepaws, and causing him to perform an uncouth dance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind, they will soon teach you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Must I really go?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He begins to think it serious,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Philip going?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Guy, looking as if he was taken by\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is going to say something about dancing being a healthful recreation\r\nfor young people,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll be disappointed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98It is much too hot to moralize.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Apollo unbends his bow,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Charles. \xe2\x80\x98The captain yields the\r\nfield.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! Captain Morville, I ought to have congratulated you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nmust come to Broadstone early enough to see you on parade.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come to Broadstone! You aren\xe2\x80\x99t still bound to Mr. Lascelles,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nCharles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he has time for me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98I am too far behind the rest of the\r\nworld to afford to be idle this vacation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s right, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Philip, sitting up, and looking full of\r\napproval. \xe2\x80\x98With so much perseverance, you must get on at last. How did\r\nyou do in collections?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tolerably, thank you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must be able to enter into the thing now,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Philip. \xe2\x80\x98What\r\nare you reading?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thucydides.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you come to Pericles\xe2\x80\x99 oration? I must show you some notes that I\r\nhave on that. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you get into the spirit of it now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Up-hill work still,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Guy, disentangling some cinders from the\r\nsilky curls of Bustle\xe2\x80\x99s ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which do you like best--that or the ball?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The hay-field best of all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, releasing Bustle, and blinding\r\nhim with a heap of hay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course!\xe2\x80\x99 said Charlotte, \xe2\x80\x98who would not like hay-making better than\r\nthat stupid ball?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor Charlotte!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; commiseration which irritated\r\nCharlotte into standing up and protesting,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mamma, you know I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No more do I, Charlotte,\xe2\x80\x99 said her brother, in a mock consoling tone.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You and I know what is good for us, and despise sublunary vanities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you will go, Guy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura;
