All my teaching thrown away!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry for you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And how do you mean to face Maurice?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell him his first bugle has so distracted me that I can\xe2\x80\x99t answer for\r\nthe consequences if I come to-night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Edmonstone came in, saying,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, I have kept you waiting shamefully, but I have been consoling\r\nmyself by thinking you must be well entertained, as I heard no\r\nHarmonious Blacksmith. Papa will be wondering where we are.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, mamma! Guy won\xe2\x80\x99t go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Guy! is anything the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing, thank you, only idleness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This will never do. You really must go, Guy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed! I think not. Pray don\xe2\x80\x99t order me, Mrs. Edmonstone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What o\xe2\x80\x99clock is it, Amy? Past ten! Papa will be in despair! What is to\r\nbe done? How long do you take to dress, Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not under an hour,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense! But if there was time I should certainly send you.\r\nSelf-discipline may be carried too far, Guy. But now it can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nhelped--I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to keep papa waiting any longer. Laura, what\r\nshall I do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me go to Charles,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Guy. \xe2\x80\x98Perhaps I can read him to sleep.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you; but don\xe2\x80\x99t talk, or he will be too excited. Reading would be\r\nthe very thing! It will be a pretty story to tell every one who asks for\r\nyou that I have left you to nurse my son!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, for no such good reason,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy; \xe2\x80\x98only because I am a great\r\nfool.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Sir Guy, I am glad you can say one sensible word,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lady\r\nEveleen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too true, I assure you,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered, as he handed her in. \xe2\x80\x98Good night!\r\nYou will keep the quadrille for me till I am rational.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe handed the others in, and shut the door. Mrs. Edmonstone, ruffled out\r\nof her composure, exclaimed,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, this is provoking!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Every one will be vexed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It will be so stupid,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I give him up,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen. \xe2\x80\x98I once had hopes of him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If it was not for papa, I really would turn back this moment and fetch\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs. Edmonstone, starting forward. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure it will give\r\noffence. I wish I had not consented.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He can\xe2\x80\x99t be made to see that his presence is of importance to any\r\nliving creature,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is the reason of this whim?\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Eveleen, it is not whim,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura; \xe2\x80\x98it is because he thinks\r\ndissipation makes him idle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then if he is idle I wonder what the rest of the world is!\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nEveleen. \xe2\x80\x98I am sure we all ought to stay at home too.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98I know I shall feel all night as if I was wrong\r\nto be there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am angry,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98and yet I believe it is a great\r\nsacrifice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, mamma; after all our looking forward to it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98Oh! yes,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand her voice lost its piteous tone, \xe2\x80\x98it is a real sacrifice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he was not a mere boy, I should say a lover\xe2\x80\x99s quarrel was at the\r\nbottom of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen. \xe2\x80\x98Depend upon it, Laura, it is all your\r\nfault. You only danced once with him at our ball, and all this week you\r\nhave played for us, as if it was on purpose to cut him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura was glad of the darkness, and her mother, who had a particular\r\ndislike to jokes of this sort, went on,--\xe2\x80\x98If it were only ourselves I\r\nshould not care, but there are so many who will fancy it caprice, or\r\nworse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The only comfort is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98that it is Charlie\xe2\x80\x99s gain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope they will not talk,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98But Charlie will\r\nnever hold his tongue. He will grow excited, and not sleep all night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPoor Mrs. Edmonstone! her trials did not end here, for when she replied\r\nto her husband\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry for Guy, Mr. Edmonstone said offence had\r\nalready been taken at his absence from the dinner; he would not have had\r\nthis happen for fifty pounds; she ought not to have suffered it; but it\r\nwas all her nonsense about Charles, and as to not being late, she should\r\nhave waited till midnight rather than not have brought him. In short,\r\nhe said as much more than he meant, as a man in a pet is apt to say, and\r\nnevertheless Mrs. Edmonstone had to look as amiable and smiling as if\r\nnothing was the matter.\r\n\r\nThe least untruthful answer she could frame to the inquiries for Sir Guy\r\nMorville was, that young men were apt to be lazy about balls, and\r\nthis sufficed for good-natured Mrs. Deane, but Maurice poured out many\r\nexclamations about his ill-behaviour, and Philip contented himself with\r\nthe mere fact of his not being there, and made no remark.\r\n\r\nLaura turned her eyes anxiously on Philip. They had not met since the\r\nimportant conversation on Ashen-down, and she found herself looking with\r\nmore pride than ever at his tall, noble figure, as if he was more her\r\nown; but the calmness of feeling was gone. She could not meet his eye,\r\nnor see him turn towards her without a start and tremor for which she\r\ncould not render herself a reason, and her heart beat so much that it\r\nwas at once a relief and a disappointment that she was obliged to accept\r\nher other cousin as her first partner. Philip had already asked Lady\r\nEveleen, for he neither wished to appear too eager in claiming Laura,\r\nnor to let his friend think he had any dislike to the Irish girl.\r\n\r\nEveleen was much pleased to have him for her partner, and told herself\r\nshe would be on her good behaviour. It was a polka, and there was not\r\nmuch talk, which, perhaps, was all the better for her. She admired the\r\nreview, and the luncheon, and spoke of Charles without any sauciness,\r\nand Philip was condescending and agreeable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must indulge myself in abusing that stupid cousin of yours!\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nshe. Did you ever know a man of such wonderful crotchets?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is a very unexpected one,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It came like a thunder clap. I thought till the last moment he was\r\njoking, for he likes dancing so much; he was the life of our ball, and\r\nhow could any one suppose he would fly off at the last moment?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He seems rather to enjoy doing things suddenly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I tell Laura she has affronted him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen, laughing. \xe2\x80\x98She has\r\nbeen always busy of late when we have wanted her; and I assure her his\r\npride has been piqued. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think that is an explanation, Captain\r\nMorville?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was Captain Morvilles belief, but he would not say so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Isn\xe2\x80\x99t Laura looking lovely?\xe2\x80\x99 Eveleen went on. \xe2\x80\x98I am sure she is\r\nthe beauty of the night!\xe2\x80\x99 She was pleased to see Captain Morville\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattention gained. \xe2\x80\x98She is even better dressed than at our ball--those\r\nVenetian pins suit the form of her head so well. Her beauty is better\r\nthan almost any one\xe2\x80\x99s, because she has so much countenance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How proud Maurice looks of having her on his arm. Does not he? Poor\r\nMaurice! he is desperately in love with her!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As is shown by his pining melancholy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEveleen laughed with her clear hearty laugh. \xe2\x80\x98I see you know what we\r\nmean by being desperately in love! No,\xe2\x80\x99 she added more gravely, \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nvery glad it is only _that_ kind of desperation. One could not think of\r\nMaurice and Laura together. He does not know the best part of Laura.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEveleen was highly flattered by Captain Morville conducting her a second\r\ntime round the room, instead of at once restoring her to her aunt.\r\n\r\nHe secured Laura next, and leading her away from her own party, said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Laura, have you been overdoing it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is not that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, wishing she could keep from blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is the only motive that could excuse his extraordinary behaviour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely you know he says that he is growing unsettled. It is part of his\r\nrule of self discipline.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Absurd!--exaggerated!--incredible! This is the same story as there was\r\nabout the horse. It is either caprice or temper, and I am convinced\r\nthat some change in your manner--nay, I say unconscious, and am far from\r\nblaming you--is the cause. Why else did he devote himself to Charles,\r\nand leave you all on my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s hands in the crowd?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We could shift for ourselves much better than Charlie.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This confirms my belief that my warning was not mistimed. I wish it\r\ncould have been done without decidedly mortifying him and rousing his\r\ntemper, because I am sorry others should be slighted; but if he takes\r\nyour drawing back so much to heart, it shows that it was time you should\r\ndo so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I thought I had!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was visible to others--to another, I should say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, that is only Eveleen\xe2\x80\x99s nonsense! The only difference I am conscious\r\nof having made, was keeping more up-stairs, and not trying to persuade\r\nhim to come here to-night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no doubt it was this that turned the scale, He only waited for\r\npersuasion, and you acted very wisely in not flattering his self-love.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did I?--I did not know it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A woman\xe2\x80\x99s instinct is often better than reasoning, Laura; to do the\r\nright thing without knowing why. But come, I suppose we must play our\r\npart in the pageant of the night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFor that evening Laura, contrary to the evidence of her senses, was\r\npersuaded by her own lover that Guy was falling in love with her; and\r\nafter musing all through the dance, she said, \xe2\x80\x98What do you think of the\r\nscheme that has been started for my going to Ireland with papa?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your going to Ireland?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; you know none of us, except papa, have seen grandmamma since\r\nCharles began to be ill, and there is some talk of his taking me with\r\nhim when he goes this summer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knew he was going, but I thought it was not to be till later in the\r\nyear--not till after the long vacation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So he intended, but he finds he must be at home before the end of\r\nOctober, and it would suit him best to go in August.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then what becomes of Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He stays at Hollywell. It will be much better for Charles to have him\r\nthere while papa is away. I thought when the plan was first mentioned I\r\nshould be sorry, except that it is quite right to go to grandmamma; but\r\nif it is so, about Guy, this absence would be a good thing--it would\r\nmake a break, and I could begin again on different terms.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wisely judged, Laura. Yes, on that account it would be very desirable,\r\nthough it will be a great loss to me, and I can hardly hope to be so\r\nnear you on your return.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! yes, so I feared!\xe2\x80\x99 sighed Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But we must give up something; and for Guy\xe2\x80\x99s own sake, poor fellow, it\r\nwill be better to make a break, as you say. It will save him pain by and\r\nby.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I dare say papa will consult you about when his journey is to be. His\r\nonly doubt was whether it would do to leave Guy so long alone, and if\r\nyou say it would be safe, it would decide him at once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see little chance of mischief. Guy has few temptations here, and a\r\nstrong sense of honour; besides, I shall be at hand. Taking all things\r\ninto consideration, Laura, I think that, whatever the sacrifice to\r\nourselves, it is expedient to recommend his going at once, and your\r\naccompanying him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAll the remainder of the evening Philip was occupied with attentions\r\nto the rest of the world, but Laura\xe2\x80\x99s eyes followed him everywhere, and\r\nthough she neither expected nor desired him to bestow more time on her,\r\nshe underwent a strange restlessness and impatience of feeling. Her\r\nnumerous partners teased her by hindering her from watching him moving\r\nabout the room, catching his tones, and guessing what he was talking\r\nof;--not that she wanted to meet his eye, for she did not like to blush,\r\nnor did she think it pleased him to see her do so, for he either looked\r\naway immediately or conveyed a glance which she understood as monitory.\r\nShe kept better note of his countenance than of her own partner\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nMr. Thorndale, meanwhile, kept aloof from Lady Eveleen de Courcy, but\r\nCaptain Morville perceived that his eyes were often turned towards her,\r\nand well knew it was principle, and not inclination, that held him at a\r\ndistance. He did indeed once ask her to dance, but she was engaged,\r\nand he did not ask her to reserve a future dance for him, but contented\r\nhimself with little Amy.\r\n\r\nAmy was doing her best to enjoy herself, because she thought it\r\nungrateful not to receive pleasure from those who wished to give it,\r\nbut to her it wanted the zest and animation of Lady Kilcoran\xe2\x80\x99s ball.\r\nBesides, she knew she had been as idle as Guy, or still more so, and she\r\nthought it wrong she should have pleasure while he was doing penance.\r\nIt was on her mind, and damped her spirits, and though she smiled, and\r\ntalked, and admired, and danced lightly and gaily, there was a sensation\r\nof weariness throughout, and no one but Eveleen was sorry when Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone sent Maurice to see for the carriage.\r\n\r\nPhilip was one of the gentlemen who came to shawl them. As he put\r\nLaura\xe2\x80\x99s cloak round her shoulders he was able to whisper, \xe2\x80\x98Take care;\r\nyou must be cautious--self-command.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura, though blushing and shrinking the moment before was braced by his\r\nwords and tone to attempt all he wished. She looked up in what she meant\r\nto be an indifferent manner, and made some observation in a careless\r\ntone--anything rather than let Philip think her silly. After what he had\r\nsaid, was she not bound more than ever to exert herself to the utmost,\r\nthat he might not be disappointed in her? She loved him only the better\r\nfor what others might have deemed a stern coldness of manner, for it\r\nmade the contrast of his real warmth of affection more precious. She\r\nmused over it, as much as her companions\xe2\x80\x99 conversation would allow, on\r\nthe road home. They arrived, Mrs. Edmonstone peeped into Charles\xe2\x80\x99s room,\r\nannounced that he was quietly asleep, and they all bade each other good\r\nnight, or good morning, and parted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 10\r\n\r\n      Leonora. Yet often with respect he speaks of thee.\r\n      Tasso.   Thou meanest with forbearance, prudent, subtle,\r\n               \xe2\x80\x98Tis that annoys me, for he knows to use\r\n               Language so smooth and so conditional,\r\n               That seeming praise from him is actual blame.\r\n                                            --GOETHE\xe2\x80\x99S Tasso\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the Hollywell party met at breakfast, Charles showed himself by no\r\nmeans the worse for his yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s experiment. He said he had gone to\r\nsleep in reasonable time, lulled by some poetry, he knew not what, of\r\nwhich Guy\xe2\x80\x99s voice had made very pretty music, and he was now full of\r\ntalk about the amusement he had enjoyed yesterday, which seemed likely\r\nto afford food for conversation for many a week to come. After all the\r\ncare Guy had taken of him, Mrs. Edmonstone could not find it in her\r\nheart to scold, and her husband, having spent his vexation upon her, had\r\nnone left to bestow on the real culprit. So when Guy, with his bright\r\nmorning face, and his hair hanging shining and wet round it, opened\r\nthe dining-room door, on his return from bathing in the river, Mr.\r\nEdmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s salutation only conveyed that humorous anger that no one\r\ncares for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good morning to you, Sir Guy Morville! I wonder what you have to say\r\nfor yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, smiling; then, as he took his place by Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone, \xe2\x80\x98I hope you are not tired after your hard day\xe2\x80\x99s work?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all, thank you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amy, can you tell me the name of this flower?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! have you really found the arrow-head? How beautiful! Where did you\r\nget it? I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know it grew in our river.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is plenty of it in that reedy place beyond the turn. I thought it\r\nlooked like something out of the common way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes! What a purple eye it has! I must draw it. O, thank you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And, Charlotte, Bustle has found you a moorhen\xe2\x80\x99s nest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How delightful! Is it where I can go and see the dear little things?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is rather a swamp; but I have been putting down stepping-stones for\r\nyou, and I dare say I can jump you across. It was that which made me\r\nso late, for which I ought to have asked pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 said he to Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone, with his look of courtesy.\r\n\r\nNever did man look less like an offended lover, or like a morose\r\nself-tormentor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There are others later,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, looking at Lady\r\nEveleen\xe2\x80\x99s empty chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you think that is all you have to ask pardon for,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr.\r\nEdmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98I advise you to study your apologies, for you are in pretty\r\ntolerable disgrace.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed, I am very sorry,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, with such a change of countenance\r\nthat Mr. Edmonstone\xe2\x80\x99s good nature could not bear to see it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, \xe2\x80\x98tis no concern of mine! It would be going rather the wrong way,\r\nindeed, for you to be begging my pardon for all the care you\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\ntaking of Charlie; but you had better consider what you have to say for\r\nyourself before you show your face at Broadstone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, puzzled for a moment, but quickly looking relieved, and\r\nlaughing, \xe2\x80\x98What! Broadstone in despair for want of me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And we perfectly exhausted with answering questions as to what was\r\nbecome of Sir Guy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dreadful,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, now laughing heartily, in the persuasion that it\r\nwas all a joke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, Lady Eveleen, good morning; you are come in good time to give me the\r\nstory of the ball, for no one else tells me one word about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because you don\xe2\x80\x99t deserve it,\xe2\x80\x99 said she. \xe2\x80\x98I hope you have repented by\r\nthis time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you want to make me repent, you should give me a very alluring\r\ndescription.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shan\xe2\x80\x99t say one word about it; I shall send you to Coventry, as\r\nMaurice and all the regiment mean to do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen, turning away\r\nfrom him with a very droll arch manner of offended dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear, hear! Eveleen send any one to Coventry!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charles. \xe2\x80\x98See what\r\nthe regiment say to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, when I am sent to Coventry?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, Paddy, Paddy!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charles, and there was a general laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Laura seems to be doing it in good earnest without announcing it,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nadded Charles, when the laugh was over, \xe2\x80\x98which is the worst sign of\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense, Charles,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, hastily; then afraid she had owned to\r\nannoyance, she blushed and was angry with herself for blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Laura, _do_ tell me who your partners were?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVery provoking, thought Laura, that I cannot say what is so perfectly\r\nnatural and ordinary, without my foolish cheeks tingling. He may think\r\nit is because he is speaking to me. So she hurried on: \xe2\x80\x98Maurice first,\r\nthen Philip,\xe2\x80\x99 and then showed, what Amy and Eveleen thought, strange\r\noblivion of the rest of her partners.\r\n\r\nThey proceeded into the history of the ball; and Guy thought no more of\r\nhis offences till the following day, when he went to Broadstone. Coming\r\nback, he found the drawing-room full of visitors, and was obliged to\r\nsit down and join in the conversation; but Mrs. Edmonstone saw he was\r\ninwardly chafing, as he betrayed by his inability to remain still, the\r\ntwitchings of his forehead and lip, and a tripping and stumbling of the\r\nwords on his tongue. She was sure he wanted to talk to her, and longed\r\nto get rid of Mrs. Brownlow; but the door was no sooner shut on the\r\nvisitors, than Mr. Edmonstone came in, with a long letter for her\r\nto read and comment upon. Guy took himself out of the way of the\r\nconsultation, and began to hurry up and down the terrace, until, seeing\r\nAmabel crossing the field towards the little gate into the garden, he\r\nwent to open it for her.\r\n\r\nShe looked up at him, and exclaimed--\xe2\x80\x98Is anything the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing to signify,\xe2\x80\x99 he said; \xe2\x80\x98I was only waiting for your mother. I\r\nhave got into a mess, that is all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry,\xe2\x80\x99 began Amy, there resting in the doubt whether she might\r\ninquire further, and intending not to burthen him with her company, any\r\nlonger than till she reached the house door; but Guy went on,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, you have no occasion to be sorry; it is all my own fault; at least,\r\nif I was clear how it is my fault, I should not mind it so much. It\r\nis that ball. I am sure I had not the least notion any one would care\r\nwhether I was there or not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure we missed you very much.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are all so kind; beside, I belong in a manner you; but what could\r\nit signify to any one else? And here I find that I have vexed every\r\none.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98mamma said she was afraid it would give offence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ought to have attended to her. It was a fit of self-will in managing\r\nmyself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, murmuring low, as if trying to find the real\r\nindictment; \xe2\x80\x98yet I thought it a positive duty; wrong every way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What has happened?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, turning back with him, though she had\r\nreached the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, the first person I met was Mr. Gordon; and he spoke like your\r\nfather, half in joke, and I thought entirely so; he said something about\r\nall the world being in such a rage, that I was a bold man to venture\r\ninto Broadstone. Then, while I was at Mr. Lascelles\xe2\x80\x99, in came Dr.\r\nMayerne. \xe2\x80\x98We missed you at the dinner,\xe2\x80\x99 he said; \xe2\x80\x98and I hear you shirked\r\nthe ball, too.\xe2\x80\x99 I told him how it was, and he said he was glad that\r\nwas all, and advised me to go and call on Colonel Deane and explain. I\r\nthought that the best way--indeed, I meant it before, and was walking\r\nto his lodgings when Maurice de Courcy met me. \xe2\x80\x98Ha!\xe2\x80\x99 he cries out,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Morville! I thought at least you would have been laid up for a month\r\nwith the typhus fever! As a friend, I advise you to go home and catch\r\nsomething, for it is the only excuse that will serve you. I am not quite\r\nsure that it will not be high treason for me to be seen speaking to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99 I tried to get at the rights of it, but he is such a harum-scarum\r\nfellow there was no succeeding. Next I met Thorndale, who only bowed\r\nand passed on the other side of the street--sign enough how it was with\r\nPhilip; so I thought it best to go at once to the Captain, and get a\r\nrational account of what was the matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, who, though concerned and rather alarmed, had been\r\nsmiling at the humorous and expressive tones with which he could not\r\nhelp giving effect to his narration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Philip was at home, and very--very--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gracious?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Amy, as he hesitated for a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so. Only the vexatious thing was, that we never could succeed in\r\ncoming to an understanding. He was ready to forgive; but I could not\r\ndisabuse him of an idea--where he picked it up I cannot guess--that I\r\nhad stayed away out of pique. He would not even tell me what he thought\r\nhad affronted me, though I asked him over and over again to be only\r\nstraightforward; he declared I knew.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How excessively provoking!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Amy. \xe2\x80\x98You cannot guess what he\r\nmeant?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not the least in the world. I have not the most distant suspicion. It\r\nwas of no use to declare I was not offended with any one; he only looked\r\nin that way of his, as if he knew much better than I did myself, and\r\ntold me he could make allowances.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Worse than all! How horrid of him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, don\xe2\x80\x99t spoil me. No doubt he thinks he has grounds, and my\r\nirritation was unjustifiable. Yes, I got into my old way. He cautioned\r\nme, and nearly made me mad! I never was nearer coming to a regular\r\noutbreak. Always the same! Fool that I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Guy, that is always your way; when other people are provoking,\r\nyou abuse yourself. I am sure Philip was so, with his calm assertion of\r\nbeing right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The more provoking, the more trial for me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you endured it. You say it was only _nearly_ an outbreak. You\r\nparted friends? I am sure of that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, it would have been rather too bad not to do that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then why do you scold yourself, when you really had the victory?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The victory will be if the inward feeling as well as the outward token\r\nis ever subdued.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, that must be in time, of course. Only let me hear how you got on\r\nwith Colonel Deane.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was very good-natured, and would have laughed it off, but Philip\r\nwent with me, and looked grand, and begged in a solemn way that no more\r\nmight be said. I could have got on better alone; but Philip was very\r\nkind, or, as you say, gracious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And provoking,\xe2\x80\x99 added Amy, \xe2\x80\x98only I believe you do not like me to say\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is more agreeable to hear you call him so at this moment than is\r\ngood for me. I have no right to complain, since I gave the offence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The offence?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The absenting myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! that you did because you thought it right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want to be clear that it was right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 cried she, astonished. \xe2\x80\x98It was a great piece of\r\nself-denial, and I only felt it wrong not to be doing the same.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nay, how should such creatures as you need the same discipline as I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe exclaimed to herself how far from his equal she was--how weak, idle,\r\nand self-pleasing she felt herself to be; but she could not say so--the\r\nwords would not come; and she only drooped her little head, humbled by\r\nhis treating her as better than himself.\r\n\r\nHe proceeded:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Something wrong I have done, and I want the clue. Was it self-will in\r\nchoosing discipline contrary to your mother\xe2\x80\x99s judgment? Yet she could\r\nnot know all. I thought it her kindness in not liking me to lose the\r\npleasure. Besides, one must act for oneself, and this was only my own\r\npersonal amusement.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, timidly hesitating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 said he, with the gentle, deferential tone that contrasted with\r\nhis hasty, vehement self-accusations. \xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 and he waited, though not\r\nso as to hurry or frighten her, but to encourage, by showing her words\r\nhad weight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was thinking of one thing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; \xe2\x80\x98is it not sometimes right\r\nto consider whether we ought to disappoint people who want us to be\r\npleased?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There it is, I believe,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, stopping and considering, then going\r\non with a better satisfied air, \xe2\x80\x98that is a real rule. Not to be so bent\r\non myself as to sacrifice other people\xe2\x80\x99s feelings to what seems best for\r\nme. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t see whose pleasure I interfered with.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy could have answered, \xe2\x80\x98Mine;\xe2\x80\x99 but the maidenly feeling checked her\r\nagain, and she said, \xe2\x80\x98We all thought you would like it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I had no right to sacrifice your pleasure! I see, I see. The\r\npleasure of giving pleasure to others is so much the best there is on\r\nearth, that one ought to be passive rather than interfere with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98just as I have seen Mary Ross let herself be swung\r\ntill she was giddy, rather than disappoint Charlotte and Helen, who\r\nthought she liked it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If one could get to look at everything with as much indifference as\r\nthe swinging! But it is all selfishness. It is as easy to be selfish for\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s own good as for one\xe2\x80\x99s own pleasure; and I dare say, the first is\r\nas bad as the other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was thinking of something else,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy. \xe2\x80\x98I should think it more\r\nlike the holly tree in Southey. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know it? The young leaves are\r\nsharp and prickly, because they have so much to defend themselves from,\r\nbut as the tree grows older, it leaves off the spears, after it has won\r\nthe victory.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very kind of you, and very pretty, Amy,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, smiling; \xe2\x80\x98but, in the\r\nmeantime, it is surely wrong to be more prickly than is unavoidable, and\r\nthere is the perplexity. Selfish! selfish! selfish! Oneself the first\r\nobject. That is the root.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Guy, if it is not impertinent to ask, I do wish you would tell me\r\none thing. Why did you think it wrong to go to that ball?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy,\r\ntimidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that I thought it wrong to go to that individual ball,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Guy; \xe2\x80\x98but my notion was, that altogether I was getting into a\r\nrattling idle way, never doing my proper quantity of work, or doing\r\nit properly, and talking a lot of nonsense sometimes. I thought, last\r\nSunday, it was time to make a short turn somewhere and bring myself up.\r\nI could not, or did not get out of the pleasant talks as Laura does, so\r\nI thought giving up this ball would punish me at once, and set me on a\r\nnew tack of behaving like a reasonable creature.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t call yourself too many names, or you won\xe2\x80\x99t be civil to us. We\r\nall, except Laura, have been quite as bad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; but you had not so much to do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We ought,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; \xe2\x80\x98but I meant to be reasonable when Eveleen is\r\ngone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerhaps I ought to have waited till then, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Lady Eveleen\r\nis so amusing that it leads to farther dawdling, and it would not do to\r\nwait to resist the temptation till it is out of the way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs he spoke, they saw Mrs. Edmonstone coming out, and went to meet her.\r\nGuy told her his trouble, detailing it more calmly than before he\r\nhad found out his mistake. She agreed with him that this had been in\r\nforgetting that his attending the ball did not concern only himself, but\r\nhe then returned to say that he could not see what difference it made,\r\nexcept to their own immediate circle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If it was not you, Guy, who made that speech, I should call it fishing\r\nfor a compliment. You forget that rank and station make people sought\r\nafter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose there is something in that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, thoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x98at any\r\nrate, it is no bad thing to think so, it is so humiliating.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is not the way most people would take it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No? Does not it prevent one from taking any attention as paid to one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreal self? The real flattering thing would be to be made as much of as\r\nPhilip is, for one\xe2\x80\x99s own merits, and not for the handle to one\xe2\x80\x99s name.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I think so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then,\xe2\x80\x99 as if he wished to gather the whole conversation into\r\none resolve, the point is to consider whether abstaining from innocent\r\nthings that may be dangerous to oneself mortifies other people. If so,\r\nthe vexing them is a certain wrong, whereas the mischief of taking the\r\npleasure is only a possible contingency. But then one must take it out\r\nof oneself some other way, or it becomes an excuse for self-indulgence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hardly with you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I had rather go at it at once, and forget all about other\r\npeople. You must teach me consideration, Mrs. Edmonstone, and in the\r\nmeantime will you tell me what you think I had better do about this\r\nscrape?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let it alone,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone. \xe2\x80\x98You have begged every one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npardon, and it had better be forgotten as fast as possible. They have\r\nmade more fuss already than it is worth. Don\xe2\x80\x99t torment yourself about it\r\nany more; for, if you have made a mistake, it is on the right side; and\r\non the first opportunity, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and call on Mrs. Deane, and see if she\r\nis very implacable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe dressing-bell rang, and Amy ran up-stairs, stopping at Laura\xe2\x80\x99s door,\r\nto ask how she prospered in the drive she had been taking with Charles\r\nand Eveleen.\r\n\r\nAmy told her of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s trouble, and oh! awkward question, inquired if\r\nshe could guess what it could be that Philip imagined that Guy had been\r\noffended at.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t he guess?\xe2\x80\x99 said poor Laura, to gain time, and brushing her hair\r\nover her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, he has no idea, though Philip protested that he knew, and would not\r\ntell him. Philip must have been most tiresome.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What? Has Guy been complaining?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, only angry with himself for being vexed. I can\xe2\x80\x99t think how Philip\r\ncan go on so!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush! hush, Amy, you know nothing about it. He has reasons--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, indignantly; \xe2\x80\x98but what right has he to go on\r\nmistrusting? If people are to be judged by their deeds, no one is\r\nso good as Guy, and it is too bad to reckon up against him all his\r\nancestors have done. It is wolf and lamb, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He does not!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Laura. \xe2\x80\x98He never is unjust! How can you say so,\r\nAmy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then why does he impute motives, and not straightforwardly tell what he\r\nmeans?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is impossible in this case,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know what it is?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, perfectly truthful, and feeling herself in a dreadful\r\npredicament.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you can\xe2\x80\x99t tell me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor Guy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not for worlds,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Laura, in horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t you get Philip to tell him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh no, no! I can\xe2\x80\x99t explain it, Amy; and all that can be done is to let\r\nit die away as fast as possible. It is only the rout about it that is of\r\nconsequence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is very odd,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98but I must dress,\xe2\x80\x99 and away she ran, much\r\npuzzled, but with no desire to look into Philip\xe2\x80\x99s secrets.\r\n\r\nLaura rested her head on her hand, sighed, and wondered why it was so\r\nhard to answer. She almost wished she had said Philip had been advising\r\nher to discourage any attachment on Guy\xe2\x80\x99s part; but then Amy might have\r\nlaughed, and asked why. No! no! Philip\xe2\x80\x99s confidence was in her keeping,\r\nand cost her what it might, she would be faithful to the trust.\r\n\r\nThere was now a change. The evenings were merry, but the mornings were\r\noccupied. Guy went off to his room, as he used to do last winter; Laura\r\ncommenced some complicated perspective, or read a German book with a\r\ngreat deal of dictionary; Amy had a book of history, and practised her\r\nmusic diligently; even Charles read more to himself, and resumed the\r\nstudy with Guy and Amy; Lady Eveleen joined in every one\xe2\x80\x99s pursuits,\r\nenjoyed them, and lamented to Laura that it was impossible to be\r\nrational at her own home.\r\n\r\nLaura tried to persuade her that there was no need that she should be on\r\nthe level of the society round her, and it ended in her spending an hour\r\nin diligent study every morning, promising to continue it when she went\r\nhome, while Laura made such sensible comments that Eveleen admired her\r\nmore than ever; and she, knowing that some were second-hand from Philip,\r\nothers arising from his suggestions, gave him all the homage paid to\r\nherself, as a tribute to him who reigned over her whole being.\r\n\r\nYet she was far from happy. Her reserve towards Guy made her feel stiff\r\nand guarded; she had a craving for Philip\xe2\x80\x99s presence, with a dread of\r\nshowing it, which made her uncomfortable. She wondered he had not been\r\nat Hollywell since the bail, for he must know that she was going to\r\nIreland in a fortnight, and was not likely to return till his regiment\r\nhad left Broadstone.\r\n\r\nAn interval passed long enough for her not to be alone in her surprise\r\nat his absenting himself before he at length made his appearance, just\r\nbefore luncheon, so as to miss the unconstrained morning hours he used\r\nso much to enjoy. He found Guy, Charles, and Amy, deep in Butler\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nAnalogy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you making poor little Amy read that?\xe2\x80\x99 said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bravo!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charles; \xe2\x80\x98he is so disappointed that it is not Pickwick\r\nthat he does not know what else to say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose I take much in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; \xe2\x80\x98but I like to be told what\r\nit means.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t imagine I can do that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never spent much time over it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98but I should think you\r\nwere out of your depth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98we will return to Dickens to oblige you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is your pleasure to wrest my words,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Philip, in his own calm\r\nmanner, though he actually felt hurt, which he had never done before.\r\nHis complacency was less secure, so that there was more need for\r\nself-assertion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where are the rest?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Laura and Eveleen are making a dictation lesson agreeable to\r\nCharlotte,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; \xe2\x80\x98I found Eva making mistakes on purpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How much longer does she stay?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Till Tuesday. Lord Kilcoran is coming to fetch her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharlotte entered, and immediately ran up-stairs to announce her\r\ncousin\xe2\x80\x99s arrival. Laura was glad of this previous notice, and hoped her\r\nblush and tremor were not observed. It was a struggle, through luncheon\r\ntime, to keep her colour and confusion within bounds; but she succeeded\r\nbetter than she fancied she did, and Philip gave her as much help as he\r\ncould, by not looking at her. Seeing that he dreaded nothing so much as\r\nher exciting suspicion, she was at once braced and alarmed.\r\n\r\nHer father was very glad to see him, and reproached him for making\r\nhimself a stranger, while her sisters counted up the days of his\r\nabsence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There was the time, to be sure, when we met you on Ashen-down, but that\r\nwas a regular cheat. Laura had you all to herself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura bent down to feed Bustle, and Philip felt _his_ colour deepening.\r\n\r\nMr. Edmonstone went on to ask him to come and stay at Hollywell for a\r\nweek, vowing he would take no refusal. \xe2\x80\x98A week was out of the question,\r\nsaid Philip; \xe2\x80\x98but he could come for two nights.\xe2\x80\x99 Amabel hinted that\r\nthere was to be a dinner-party on Thursday, thinking it fair to give\r\nhim warning of what he disliked, but he immediately chose that very day.\r\nAgain he disconcerted all expectations, when it was time to go out. Mrs.\r\nEdmonstone and Charles were going to drive, the young ladies and Guy to\r\nwalk, but Philip disposed himself to accompany his uncle in a survey of\r\nthe wheat.\r\n\r\nLaura perceived that he would not risk taking another walk with her when\r\nthey might be observed. It showed implicit trust to leave her to his\r\nrival; but she was sorry to find that caution must put an end to the\r\nfreedom of their intercourse, and would have stayed at home, but that\r\nEveleen was so wild and unguarded that Mrs. Edmonstone did not like her\r\nto be without Laura as a check on her, especially when Guy was of the\r\nparty. There was some comfort in that warm pressure of her hand when she\r\nbade Philip good-bye, and on that she lived for a long time. He stood at\r\nthe window watching them till they were out of sight, then moved\r\ntowards his aunt, who with her bonnet on, was writing an invitation for\r\nThursday, to Mr. Thorndale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was thinking,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x98if it would not be as well,\r\nif you liked, to ask Thorndale here for those two days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If _you_ think so,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs. Edmonstone, looking at him more\r\ninquiringly than he could well bear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know how he enjoys being here, and I owe them all so much\r\nkindness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly; I will speak to your uncle,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, going in search of\r\nhim. She presently returned, saying they should be very glad to see Mr.\r\nThorndale, asking him at the same time, in her kind tones of interest,\r\nafter an old servant for whom he had been spending much thought and\r\npains. The kindness cut him to the heart, for it evidently arose from\r\na perception that he was ill at ease, and his conscience smote him. He\r\nanswered shortly, and was glad when the carriage came; he lifted Charles\r\ninto it, and stood with folded arms as they drove away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The air is stormy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, looking back at him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You thought so, too?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You did!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have wondered for some time past.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was very decided to-day--that long absence--and there was no\r\nprovoking him to be sententious. His bringing his young man might be\r\nonly to keep him in due subjection; but his choosing the day of the\r\nparty, and above all, not walking with the young ladies.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It not like himself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, in a leading tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Either the sweet youth is in love, or in the course of some strange\r\ntransformation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In love!\xe2\x80\x99 she exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x98Have you any reason for thinking so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only as a solution of phenomena; but you look as if I had hit on the\r\ntruth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope it is no such thing; yet--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yet?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Charles, seriously. \xe2\x80\x98I think he has discovered the\r\ndanger.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The danger of falling in love with Laura? Well, it would be odd if he\r\nwas not satisfied with his own work. But he must know how preposterous\r\nthat would be.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you think that would prevent it?\xe2\x80\x99 said his mother, smiling. \xe2\x80\x98He\r\nis just the man to plume himself on making his judgment conquer his\r\ninclination, setting novels at defiance. How magnanimously he would\r\nresolve to stifle a hopeless attachment!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is exactly what I think he is doing. I think he has found out the\r\nstate of his feelings, and is doing all in his power to check them by\r\navoiding her, especially in tete-a-tetes, and an unconstrained family\r\nparty. I am nearly convinced that is his reason for bringing Mr.\r\nThorndale, and fixing on the day of the dinner. Poor fellow, it must\r\ncost him a great deal, and I long to tell him how I thank him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hm! I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it unlikely,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles. \xe2\x80\x98It agrees with what\r\nhappened the evening of the Kilcoran ball, when he was ready to eat me\r\nup for saying something he fancied was a hint of a liking of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfor Laura. It was a wild mistake, for something I said about Petrarch,\r\nforgetting that Petrarch suggested Laura; but it put him out to a\r\ndegree, and he made all manner of denunciations on the horror of Guy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfalling in love with her. Now, as far as I see, Guy is much more in\r\nlove with you, or with Deloraine, and the idea argues far more that the\r\nCaptain himself is touched.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Depend upon it, Charlie, it was this that led to his detecting the true\r\nstate of the case. Ever since that he has kept away. It is noble!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what do you think about Laura?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor child! I doubt if it was well to allow so much intimacy; yet I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t see how it could have been helped.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you think she is in for it? I hope not; but she has not been herself\r\nof late.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think she misses what she has been used to from him, and thinks him\r\nestranged, but I trust it goes no further. I see she is out of spirits;\r\nI wish I could help her, dear girl, but the worst of all would be to let\r\nher guess the real name and meaning of all this, so I can\xe2\x80\x99t venture to\r\nsay a word.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is very innocent of novels,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98and that is well. It\r\nwould be an unlucky business to have our poor beauty either sitting\r\n\xe2\x80\x98like Patience on a monument\xe2\x80\x99, or \xe2\x80\x98cockit up on a baggage-waggon.\xe2\x80\x99 But\r\nthat will never be. Philip is not the man to have a wife in barracks. He\r\nwould have her like his books, in morocco, or not at all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He would never involve her in discomforts. He may be entirely trusted,\r\nand as long as he goes on as he has begun, there is no harm done; Laura\r\nwill cheer up, will only consider him as her cousin and friend, and\r\nnever know he has felt more for her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her going to Ireland is very fortunate.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It has made me still more glad that the plan should take place at\r\nonce.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you say \xe2\x80\x9cnothing to nobody\xe2\x80\x9d?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course not. We must not let him guess we have observed anything;\r\nthere is no need to make your father uncomfortable, and such things need\r\nnot dawn on Amy\xe2\x80\x99s imagination.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt may be wondered at that Mrs. Edmonstone should confide such a subject\r\nto her son, but she knew that in a case really affecting his sister,\r\nand thus introduced, his silence was secure. In fact, confidence was the\r\nonly way to prevent the shrewd, unscrupulous raillery which would have\r\ncaused great distress, and perhaps led to the very disclosure to be\r\ndeprecated. Of late, too, there had been such a decrease of petulance\r\nin Charles, as justified her in trusting him, and lastly, it must be\r\nobserved that she was one of those open-hearted people who cannot make a\r\ndiscovery nor endure an anxiety without imparting it. Her tact, indeed,\r\nled her to make a prudent choice of confidants, and in this case her son\r\nwas by far the best, though she had spoken without premeditation. Her\r\nnature would never have allowed her to act as her daughter was doing;\r\nshe would have been without the strength to conceal her feelings,\r\nespecially when deprived of the safety-valve of free intercourse with\r\ntheir object.\r\n\r\nThe visit took place as arranged, and very uncomfortable it was to all\r\nwho looked deeper than the surface. In the first place, Philip found\r\nthere the last person he wished his friend to meet--Lady Eveleen, who\r\nhad been persuaded to stay for the dinner-party; but Mr. Thorndale was,\r\nas Charles would have said, on his good behaviour, and, ashamed of the\r\nfascination her manners exercised over him, was resolved to resist it,\r\nanswered her gay remarks with brief sentences and stiff smiles, and\r\nconsorted chiefly with the gentlemen.\r\n\r\nLaura was grave and silent, trying to appear unconscious, and only\r\nsucceeding in being visibly constrained. Philip was anxious and stern in\r\nhis attempts to appear unconcerned, and even Guy was not quite as bright\r\nand free as usual, being puzzled as to how far he was forgiven about the\r\nball.\r\n\r\nAmabel could not think what had come to every one, and tried in vain to\r\nmake them sociable. In the evening they had recourse to a game, said\r\nto be for Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s amusement, but in reality to obviate some of the\r\nstiffness and constraint; yet even this led to awkward situations. Each\r\nperson was to set down his or her favourite character in history and\r\nfiction, flower, virtue, and time at which to have lived, and these were\r\nall to be appropriated to the writers. The first read was--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lily of the valley--truth--Joan of Arc--Padre Cristoforo--the present\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amy!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see you are right,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles; \xe2\x80\x98but tell me your grounds!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Padre Cristoforo,\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fancy little Amy choosing Joan of Arc,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen, \xe2\x80\x98she who is\r\nafraid of a tolerable sized grasshopper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to have been Joan\xe2\x80\x99s sister, and heard her tell about her\r\nvisions,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would have taught her to believe them,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Taught her!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy. \xe2\x80\x98Surely you take the high view of her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip, \xe2\x80\x98that she is a much injured person, as much\r\nby her friends as her enemies; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to enter either\r\nenthusiastically or philosophically into her character.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhat was it that made Guy\xe2\x80\x99s brow contract, as he began to strip the\r\nfeather of a pen, till, recollecting himself, he threw it from him with\r\na dash, betraying some irritation, and folded his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lavender,\xe2\x80\x99 read Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What should make any one choose that?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Eveleen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone, looking up. \xe2\x80\x98I shall never forget the\r\ntufts of lavender round the kitchen garden at Stylehurst.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPhilip smiled. Charlotte proceeded, and Charles saw Laura\xe2\x80\x99s colour\r\ndeepening as she bent over her work.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cLavender--steadfastness--Strafford--Cordelia in \xe2\x80\x98King Lear\xe2\x80\x99--the\r\nlate war.\xe2\x80\x9d How funny!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charlotte. \xe2\x80\x98For hear the next:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoneysuckle--steadfastness--Lord Strafford--Cordelia--the present\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d Why, Laura, you must have copied it from Philip\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLaura neither looked nor spoke. Philip could hardly command his\r\ncountenance as Eveleen laughed, and told him he was much flattered by\r\nthose becoming blushes. But here Charles broke in,--\xe2\x80\x98Come, make haste,\r\nCharlotte, don\xe2\x80\x99t be all night about it;\xe2\x80\x99 and as Charlotte paused, as if\r\nto make some dangerous remark, he caught the paper, and read the next\r\nhimself. Nothing so startled Philip as this desire to cover their\r\nconfusion. Laura was only sensible of the relief of having attention\r\ndrawn from her by the laugh that followed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A shamrock--Captain Rock--the tailor that was \xe2\x80\x9cblue moulded for want of\r\na bating\xe2\x80\x9d--Pat Riotism--the time of Malachy with the collar of gold.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eva!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen; \xe2\x80\x98I am glad I know your tastes, Charles. They\r\ndo you honour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98More than yours do, if these are yours,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, reading them\r\ncontemptuously; \xe2\x80\x98Rose--generosity--Charles Edward--Catherine Seyton--the\r\ncivil wars.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had better not have disowned Charlie\xe2\x80\x99s, Lady Eveleen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nay do you think I would put up with such a set as these?\xe2\x80\x99 retorted\r\nCharles; \xe2\x80\x98I am not fallen so low as the essence of young ladyism.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What can you find to say against them?\xe2\x80\x99 said Eveleen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, \xe2\x80\x98No one ever can find anything to say for or\r\nagainst young ladies\xe2\x80\x99 tastes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You seem to be rather in the case of the tailor yourself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ready to do battle, if you could but get any opposition.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only tell me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, \xe2\x80\x98how you could wish to live in the civil\r\nwars?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, because they would be so entertaining.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s Paddy, genuine Paddy at last!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Charles. \xe2\x80\x98Depend upon\r\nit, the conventional young lady won\xe2\x80\x99t do, Eva.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter much more discussion, and one or two more papers, came Guy\xe2\x80\x99s--the\r\nlast. \xe2\x80\x98Heather--Truth--King Charles--Sir Galahad--the present time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir how much? exclaimed Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know him?\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy. \xe2\x80\x98Sir Galahad--the Knight of the Siege\r\nPerilous--who won the Saint Greal.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What language is that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know the Morte d\xe2\x80\x99Arthur! I thought every one did! Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou, Philip!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I once looked into it. It is very curious, in classical English; but it\r\nis a book no one could read through.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Guy, indignantly; then, \xe2\x80\x98but you only looked into it. If you\r\nhad lived with its two fat volumes, you could not help delighting in it.\r\nIt was my boating-book for at least three summers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That accounts for it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; \xe2\x80\x98a book so studied in boyhood\r\nacquires a charm apart from its actual merits.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it has actual merits. The depth, the mystery, the allegory--the\r\nbeautiful characters of some of the knights.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You look through the medium of your imagination,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip; but\r\nyou must pardon others for seeing a great sameness of character and\r\nadventure, and for disapproving of the strange mixture of religion and\r\nromance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ve never read it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, striving to speak patiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A cursory view is sufficient to show whether a book will repay the time\r\nspent in reading it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A cursory view enable one to judge better than making it your study?\r\nEh, Philip?\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is no paradox. The actual merits are better seen by an unprejudiced\r\nstranger than by an old friend who lends them graces of his own\r\ndevising.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharles laughed: Guy pushed back his chair, and went to look out at the\r\nwindow. Perhaps Philip enjoyed thus chafing his temper; for after all he\r\nhad said to Laura, it was satisfactory to see his opinion justified, so\r\nthat he might not feel himself unfair. It relieved his uneasiness lest\r\nhis understanding with Laura should be observed. It had been in great\r\nperil that evening, for as the girls went up to bed, Eveleen gaily said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, Laura, have you quarrelled with Captain Morville?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you say such things, Eva? Good night.\xe2\x80\x99 And Laura escaped into\r\nher own room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the meaning of it, Amy?\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Eveleen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only a stranger makes us more formal,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What an innocent you are! It is of no use to talk to you!\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nEveleen, running away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; but Eva,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, pursuing her, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t go off with a wrong fancy.\r\nCharles has teased Laura so much about Philip, that of course it makes\r\nher shy of him before strangers; and it would never have done to laugh\r\nabout their choosing the same things when Mr. Thorndale was there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must be satisfied, I suppose. I know that is what you think, for you\r\ncould not say any other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what do you think?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, puzzled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t tell you, little innocence--it would only shock you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing you _really_ _thought_ about Laura could shock me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean what you might say in play.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, then, shall you think me in play or earnest when I say that I\r\nthink Laura likes Philip very much?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In play\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy; \xe2\x80\x98for you know that if we had not got our own Charlie\r\nto show us what a brother is, we should think of Philip as just the same\r\nas a brother.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A brother! You are pretending to be more simple than you really are,\r\nAmy! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know what I mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, her cheeks lighting up, \xe2\x80\x98that must be only play, for he\r\nhas never asked her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, but suppose she was in the state just ready to be asked?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, that could never be, for he could never ask her,\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why not, little Amy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because we are cousins, and everything,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, confused. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntalk any more about it, Eva; for though I know it is all play, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlike it, and mamma, would not wish me to talk of such things. And\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t you laugh about it, dear Eva, pray; for it only makes every one\r\nuncomfortable. Pray!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy had a very persuasive way of saying \xe2\x80\x98pray,\xe2\x80\x99 and Eveleen thought she\r\nmust yield to it. Besides, she respected Laura and Captain Morville too\r\nmuch to resolve to laugh at them, whatever she might do when her fear of\r\nthe Captain made her saucy.\r\n\r\nMrs. Edmonstone thought it best on all accounts to sit in the\r\ndrawing-room the next morning; but she need not have taken so much pains\r\nto chaperon her young ladies, for the gentlemen did not come near them.\r\n\r\nLaura was more at ease in manner, though very far from happy, for she\r\nwas restlessly eager for a talk with Philip; while he was resolved not\r\nto seek a private interview, sure that it would excite suspicion, and\r\nwilling to lose the consciousness of his underhand proceedings.\r\n\r\nThis was the day of the dinner-party, and Laura\xe2\x80\x99s heart leaped as she\r\ncalculated that it must fall to Philip\xe2\x80\x99s lot to hand her in to dinner.\r\nShe was not mistaken, he did give her his arm; and they found themselves\r\nmost favourably placed, for Philip\xe2\x80\x99s other neighbour was Mrs. Brownlow,\r\ntalking at a great rate to Mr. de Courcy, and on Laura\xe2\x80\x99s side was the\r\nrather deaf Mr. Hayley, who had quite enough to do to talk to Miss\r\nBrownlow. Charles was not at table, and not one suspicious eye could\r\nrest on them, yet it was not till the second course was in progress that\r\nhe said anything which the whole world might not have heard. Something\r\nhad passed about Canterbury, and its distance from Hollywell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can be here often,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you can only be guarded,--and I think you are becoming so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is this a time to speak of--? Oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is the only time. No one is attending, and I have something to say\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOverpowering her dire confusion, in obedience to him, she looked at the\r\nepergne, and listened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have acted prudently. You have checked--\xe2\x80\x99 and he indicated\r\nGuy--\xe2\x80\x98without producing more than moderate annoyance. You have only to\r\nguard your self-possession.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is very foolish,\xe2\x80\x99 she murmured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ordinary women say so, and rest contented with the folly. You can do\r\nbetter things.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a thrill of joy at finding him conversing with her as his\r\n\xe2\x80\x98own;\xe2\x80\x99 it overcame her embarrassment and alarm, and wishes he would not\r\nchoose such a time for speaking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How shall I?\xe2\x80\x99 said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Employ yourself. Employ and strengthen your mind!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How shall I, and without you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Find something to prevent you from dwelling on the future. That drawing\r\nis dreamy work, employing the fingers and leaving the mind free.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been trying to read, but I cannot fix my mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose you take what will demand attention. Mathematics, algebra. I\r\nwill send you my first book of algebra, and it will help you to work\r\ndown many useless dreams and anxieties.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you; pray do; I shall be very glad of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will find it give a power and stability to your mind, and no longer\r\nhave to complain of frivolous occupation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel frivolous now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura, sadly; \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why it is\r\nthat everything is so altered, I am really happier, but my light heart\r\nis gone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have but now learnt the full powers of your soul, Laura, you have\r\nleft the world of childhood, with the gay feelings which have no depth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have what is better,\xe2\x80\x99 she whispered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have, indeed. But those feelings must be regulated, and\r\nstrengthening the intellect strengthens the governing power.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPhilip, with all his sense, was mystifying himself, because he was\r\ndeparting from right, the only true \xe2\x80\x98good sense.\xe2\x80\x99 His right judgment\r\nin all things was becoming obscured, so he talked metaphysical jargon,\r\ninstead of plain practical truth, and thought he was teaching Laura to\r\nstrengthen her powers of mind, instead of giving way to dreams, when\r\nhe was only leading her to stifle meditation, and thus securing her\r\ncomplete submission to himself.\r\n\r\nShe was happier after this conversation, and better able to pay\r\nattention to the guests, nor did she feel guilty when obliged to play\r\nand sing in the evening--for she knew he must own that she could do no\r\notherwise.\r\n\r\nLady Eveleen gave, however, its brilliancy to the party. She had\r\nsomething wonderfully winning and fascinating about her, and Philip\r\nowned to himself that it took no small resolution on the part of Mr.\r\nThorndale to keep so steadily aloof from the party in the bay window,\r\nwhere she was reigning like a queen, and inspiring gaiety like a fairy.\r\nShe made Guy sing with her; it was the first time he had ever sung,\r\nexcept among themselves, as Mrs. Edmonstone had never known whether he\r\nwould like to be asked; but Eveleen refused to sing some of the Irish\r\nmelodies unless he would join her, and without making any difficulty he\r\ndid so. Mrs. Brownlow professed to be electrified, and Eveleen declaring\r\nthat she knew she sung like a peacock, told Mrs. Brownlow that the thing\r\nto hear was Sir Guy singing glees with Laura and Amy. Of course, they\r\nwere obliged to sing. Mrs. Brownlow was delighted; and as she had\r\nconsiderable knowledge of music, they all grew eager and Philip thought\r\nit very foolish of Guy to allow so much of his talent and enthusiasm to\r\ndisplay themselves.\r\n\r\nWhen all the people were gone, and the home party had wished each other\r\ngood-night, Philip lingered in the drawing-room to finish a letter. Guy,\r\nafter helping Charles up-stairs, came down a few moments after, to fetch\r\nsomething which he had forgotten. Philip looked up,--\xe2\x80\x98You contributed\r\ngreatly to the entertainment this evening,\xe2\x80\x99 he said.\r\n\r\nGuy coloured, not quite sure that this was not said sarcastically, and\r\nprovoked with himself for being vexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think one devoid of the sixth sense has no right to speak,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nPhilip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t expect all to think it, as I do, one of the best things in this\r\nworld or out of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Guy, speaking quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it is so felt by those who understand its secrets,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would not depreciate it; so you may hear me patiently, Guy. I only\r\nmeant to warn you, that it is often the means of bringing persons into\r\nundesirable intimacies, from which they cannot disentangle themselves as\r\neasily as they enter them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA flush crossed Guy\xe2\x80\x99s cheek, but it passed, and he simply said--\xe2\x80\x98I\r\nsuppose it may. Good-night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPhilip looked after him, and pondered on what it was that had annoyed\r\nhim--manner, words, or advice. He ascribed it to Guy\xe2\x80\x99s unwillingness to\r\nbe advised, since he had observed that his counsel was apt to irritate\r\nhim, though his good sense often led him to follow it. In the present\r\ncase, Philip thought Mrs. Brownlow and her society by no means desirable\r\nfor a youth like Guy; and he was quite right.\r\n\r\nPhilip and his friend went the next morning; and in the afternoon Laura\r\nreceived the book of algebra--a very original first gift from a lover.\r\nIt came openly, with a full understanding that she was to use it by his\r\nrecommendation; her mother and brother both thought they understood the\r\nmotive, which one thought very wise, and the other very characteristic.\r\n\r\nLord Kilcoran and Lady Eveleen also departed. Eveleen very sorry to go,\r\nthough a little comforted by the prospect of seeing Laura so soon\r\nin Ireland, where she would set her going in all kinds of\r\n\xe2\x80\x98rationalities--reading, and school teaching, and everything else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay,\xe2\x80\x99 said Charles, when all were out of hearing but his mother; \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nI shrewdly suspect the comfort would be still greater if it was Sir Guy\r\nMorville who was coming.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be no bad thing,\xe2\x80\x99 said his mother: \xe2\x80\x98Eveleen is a nice creature\r\nwith great capabilities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Capabilities! but will they ever come to anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a few years,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs. Edmonstone; \xe2\x80\x98and he is a mere boy at\r\npresent, so there is plenty of time for both to develop themselves.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Most true, madame mere; but it remains to be proved whether the liking\r\nfor Sir Guy, which has taken hold of my lady Eveleen, is strong enough\r\nto withstand all the coquetting with young Irishmen, and all the idling\r\nat Kilcoran.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope she has something better to be relied on than the liking for Sir\r\nGuy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may well do so, for I think he has no notion of throwing off his\r\nallegiance to you--his first and only love. He liked very well to make\r\nfun with Eva; but he regarded her rather as a siren, who drew him off\r\nfrom his Latin and Greek.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; I am ashamed of myself for such a fit of match-making! Forget it,\r\nCharlie, as fast as you can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER 11\r\n\r\n     This warld\xe2\x80\x99s wealth, when I think o\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\n     Its pride, and a\xe2\x80\x99 the lave o\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\n     Fie, fie on silly coward man,\r\n     That he should be the slave o\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\n                             --BURNS\r\n\r\n\r\nIn another week Mr. Edmonstone and his eldest daughter were to depart\r\non their Irish journey. Laura, besides the natural pain in leaving home,\r\nwas sorry to be no longer near Philip, especially as it was not likely\r\nthat he would be still at Broadstone on their return; yet she was so\r\nrestless and dissatisfied, that any change was welcome, and the fear of\r\nbetraying herself almost took away the pleasure of his presence.\r\n\r\nHe met them at the railway station at Broadstone, where Mr. Edmonstone,\r\nfinding himself much too early, recollected something he had forgotten\r\nin the town, and left his daughter to walk up and down the platform\r\nunder Philip\xe2\x80\x99s charge. They felt it a precious interval, but both were\r\nout of spirits, and could hardly profit by it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will be gone long before we come back,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a fortnight or three weeks, probably.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you will still be able to come to Hollywell now and then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so. It is all the pleasure I can look for. We shall never see\r\nsuch a summer again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, it has been a memorable one!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Memorable! Yes. It has given me an assurance that compensates for all\r\nI have lost; yet it has made me feel, more than ever before, how poverty\r\nwithers a man\xe2\x80\x99s hopes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O Philip, I always thought your poverty a great, noble thing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You thought like a generous-tempered girl who has known nothing of its\r\neffects.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And do you know that Guy says the thing to be proud of is of holding\r\nthe place you do, without the aid of rank or riches.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would not have it otherwise--I would not for worlds that my father\r\nhad acted otherwise,\xe2\x80\x99 said Philip. \xe2\x80\x98You understand that, Laura.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But when you speak--when Guy speaks of my holding the place I do, you\r\nlittle know what it is to feel that powers of usefulness are wasted--to\r\nknow I have the means of working my way to honour and distinction, such\r\nas you would rejoice in Laura, to have it all within, yet feel it thrown\r\naway. Locksley Hall, again--\xe2\x80\x9cevery door is barred with gold, and opens\r\nbut to golden keys.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish there was anything to be done,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is my profession that is the bar to everything. I have sold the best\r\nyears of my life, and for what? To see my sister degrade herself by that\r\nmarriage.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is the real grief,\xe2\x80\x99 said Laura.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But for that, I should never have cast a look back on what I\r\nrelinquished. However, why do I talk of these things, these vain\r\nregrets? They only occurred because my welfare does not concern myself\r\nalone--and here\xe2\x80\x99s your father.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr. Edmonstone returned, out of breath, in too much bustle remark his\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s blushes. Even when the train was moving off, he still had\r\nhis head out at the window, calling to Philip that they should expect\r\na visit from him as soon as ever they returned. Such cordiality gave\r\nPhilip a pang; and in bitterness of spirit he walked back to the\r\nbarracks. On the way he met Mrs. Deane who wanted to consult him about\r\ninviting his cousin, Sir Guy to a dinner-party she intended to give next\r\nweek. \xe2\x80\x98Such an agreeable, sensible youth, and we feel we owe him some\r\nattention, he took so much pains to make apologies about the ball.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I dare say he will be very happy to come.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We will write at once. He is a very fine young man, without a shade of\r\nvanity or nonsense.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; he has very pleasant, unaffected manners.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure he will do credit to his estate. It is a very handsome\r\nfortune, is it not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a very large property.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad of it; I have no doubt we shall see him one of the first men\r\nof his time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThese words brought into contrast in Philip\xe2\x80\x99s mind the difference\r\nbetween Guy\xe2\x80\x99s position and his own. The mere possession of wealth was\r\nwinning for Guy, at an age when his merits could only be negative, that\r\nestimation which his own tried character had scarcely achieved, placing\r\nhim not merely on a level with himself, but in a situation where\r\nhappiness and influence came unbidden. His own talents, attainments, and\r\nequal, if not superior claims, to gentle blood, could not procure him\r\nwhat seemed to lie at Guy\xe2\x80\x99s feet. His own ability and Laura\xe2\x80\x99s heart\r\nalone were what wealth could not affect; yet when he thought how the\r\nwant of it wasted the one, and injured the hopes of the other, he\r\nrecurred to certain visions of his sister Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s, in days gone\r\nby, of what he was to do as Sir Philip, lord of Redclyffe. He was\r\nspeculating on what would have happened had Guy died in his sickly\r\ninfancy, when, suddenly recollecting himself, he turned his mind to\r\nother objects.\r\n\r\nGuy was not much charmed with Mrs. Deane\xe2\x80\x99s invitation. He said he knew\r\nhe must go to make up for his rudeness about the ball; but he grumbled\r\nenough to make Mrs. Edmonstone laugh at him for being so stupid as\r\nto want to stay hum-drum in the chimney corner. No doubt it was very\r\npleasant there. There was that peculiar snugness which belongs to a\r\nremnant of a large party, when each member of it feels bound to prevent\r\nthe rest from being dull. Guy devoted himself to Charles more than\r\never, and in the fear that he might miss the late variety of amusement,\r\nexerted even more of his powers of entertainment than Lady Eveleen had\r\ncalled forth.\r\n\r\nThere were grave readings in the mornings, and long walks in the\r\nafternoons, when he dragged Charles, in his chair, into many a place he\r\nhad never expected to see again, and enabled him to accompany his mother\r\nand sisters in many a delightful expedition.
